Started the slow downhill slide with a Corpse Reviver #2, which I believe was a mix of gin, absinthe, triple sec and some other goodies. Solid drink, but I didn't want to hammer 6 of these home so when the bartender asked me what I was thinking for the next drink I explained to him about this vodka I had tried out a while back called Zubrowka. Sure enough Rye places one single bottle of vodka on it's shelf....and it's Zu. Win. I kicked back two Zu martini's and was feelin the flow....doin the bull. Rye's chill atmosphere and skilled 'tenders make it a must stop locale on any future trips to the SF. Rye, f rest, you may have any Sunday of mine that you would like.
author: Drew A.

description:
We came to Rye for the first time for my friend's birthday. I was a bit worried since it was in the tender-nob. Nonetheless, its located right next door to the osha thai near the corner. Entrance is just a huge wooden door, so you cannot miss that. The ambiance is gently lit that gives the atmosphere a chill, and relaxing vibe. There are some pool tables located in the back of the venue.  
 
Of course, I ordered the Basil Gimlet: refreshing and sweet for about nine dollars. Generally, the bar is speakeasy themed with the usual lemon, orange, basil garnishes or the mixology usage of egg whites. There are plenty of tables for groups to sit and chat. In addition, a safely lit smoking area is within feet of the second extended room to the right of the establishment. Overall, a lovely place to grab some drinks.
author: Becky Q.

description:
My favorite bar, 15 Romolo, has some serious competition from Rye. Of course that means they're quite similar, with seriously innovative cocktails. Here's what I got:

- Juan E. Appleseed: roughly speaking, bourbon, tequila, ginger beer, and bitters.
- Birds of a Feather: tequila, orange oil (very fragrant), bitters, and vermouth.

Both AMAZING drinks! They are expensive, maybe a dollar or two higher than the ones at 15 Romolo, but when you're already paying more than $10 for a drink, another dollar is fairly inconsequential.

Our bartender was also super nice (probably connected to the fact that it was a bit of a slow night), and after hearing that one of our friends didn't have a taste for gin, she came up with a delicious shooter involving gin, cucumber, and mint, to change her mind. And she brought not just one, but five, one for everyone in our party to try. It was nominally on the house, but of course we tipped her a fiver! :)

Big plus for the place being really empty (good, more space for me), good patio (slight minus, it doubles as a smoking patio, but you can't have it all) and also holla to the nice, FREE pool table!

I'm certain I'll be back at Rye soon.
author: Josh K.

description:
It's been almost 4 years since my last review of Rye and I've probably been here more than any bar in Chicago. It's typically my last stop of the night so most Rye experiences are a bit hazy, but thanks to the future Baby R I have no problem remembering my most recent experience.

I walked in with the infamous Nish N and of course the bartender knew his name. You could say that he's a bit of a regular here. He asked the lovely bartender to make him, his wife and our friend one of their infamous cocktail concoctions. And then for me he asked for a virgin cocktail that was so good I'd feel drunk. The bartender worked her magic and I ended up with a fruity drink that was way tastier than any cocktail I've had in the past. Who needs alcohol?

We were able to score a table (not too crowded on a Wed evening) and enjoy our cocktails. While the cocktail was quite tasty it didn't make me feel drunk, but that's probably a good thing for Baby R's sake.
author: Andrea R.

description:
Definitely trendy. 

Dark leather couches and mirrors on the walls to make this tiny bar look bigger.

Fancy drinks (read: Pimm's cup!).

Very loud.

Unisex bathroom.

Good for one drink, but not for a full night out.
author: Jennifer C.

description: First time in this place was great! Bartenders are talented and have a great taste pallet. The place has a pool table, which is great. Also liked the decor a lot. Great experience overall.
author: Julia G.

description:
Very neat place. Ambiance was cool, music was great, drinks were great. One of my party did order a drink that had flower petals in it that got in the way, though--not sure why he didn't get a straw. It was a great place to grab a drink and chat with friends. Our booth was right next to the bathroom door which got kind of gross (really, really gross at times) but other than that it was a nice, clean place and our server was very nice!

We almost couldn't find it because the name of the bar is hard to see unless you look in the window and see it lit up, but it was a good experience so I'm glad we did end up finding it.

I can't remember which drink I got other than the fact that it was a swizzle and tasted magical. My boyfriend had a cocktail with ginger liquor in it that he liked so much that he got three of them. Overall I'd come back again if I was in the area with friends--pretty yummy!
author: Katie V.

description:
Great vibe, great music that helped me relive my teen years in the '90s, great service, SPECTACULAR drinks!

Came here on a Saturday night with a group to celebrate a friend's birthday. Not too crowded, but lively. Not too swanky, but nice.

I asked the pretty brunette with the ponytail for something gingery, lemony, vodka-y. I know, lame. Anyway, her response was what she referred to as the English Garden and what I now refer to as Perfection. Since my attention span isn't that long, I lost track of what went into my glass along with muddled fresh cucumber, house-made ginger simple syrup, fresh lemon juice, vodka, basil and bitters (I think!). All I know is that I had to have another and they were both BLISSFUL.

Definitely a spot I'll hit up again.
author: Meadow G.

description: Cocktails run a little sweet and waitstaff runs a little slow (even with no other customers). But the environment was very cool.
author: Meagan S.

description: Walked in on a whim for a pre-dinner drink with my wife. Asked for a drink based on our moods and received a magnificent concoction.
author: K. C.

description:
Their bar menu has a lot of classic cocktails, such as the Pimm's Cup and Old Pal, that aren't typically featured at other bars (Pimm's and Campari aren't very popular liquors). Given that, you'd expect a bit of the pretentiousness that accompanies good alcohol, but Rye's atmosphere gives way to a more casual experience.

Besides all that, though, the bartenders were both dressed in suit vests, which was pretty cool in a classy way.
author: Andrew W.

description:
Nice bar for being located in the tenderloin.  They have lots of cocktail selections to choose from. I got the popular basil gimlet and was pleasantly surprised. A very refreshing drink indeed.  The atmosphere is low key, ambient lighting, with a modern rustic feel.  They don't play music or have TVs so normal conversation is encouraged.  Also, a pool table is available in the back area next to the restrooms.  The table is missing an extra pool cue and 9 ball, but we managed. 

I would return just to sample the vast selection of cocktails available.  Maybe you will find a new favorite drink here.
author: Devin N.

description:
The drinks are delicious, the bartenders are fun, and the ambiance is pretty rad.

I ordered a mojito and it was delicious with a heavy-handed pour of booze, just the way I like it. I had a Pimm's Cup too which had a great over-all gingery taste and was garnished with a crispy cucumber slice. The bartender chick making the tasty drinks was adorable and engaging. The dudes working with her were appropriately clad in hipster ensemble -- blue and red plaid button downs with straight black ties -- and I couldn't help remarking on the matching coincidence. 

Comfy love seats to sit on, and a little enclosed patio area is available for smoking. 

Oh! Happy hour from 6pm to 9pm, I believe. Pretty swell.
author: Najla A.

description: Regarded as one of SF's top spots for drinks, yet largely forgettable.  The crowd's lively, clearly on the younger side and packed into rather cramped quarters.  Drinks included The Natural Selection (a literally meaty finish that thankfully started to taste more fruit forward), 5 Island Milk Punch whose flavor profile could be described as "Nutmeg's saucy stepsister" per Michelle L. and my Carosello that served as a pleasantly light way to finish off our night of drinking.  Not bad on the whole...I've just had far better elsewhere.
author: Eric F.

description: My favorite neighborhood bar. They make well crafted drinks, just bring a little bit of patience when waiting for your drink, they'll get to you.  The ambiance is great, just enough lighting to see your drink and your friends.  I always have a good time.
author: Y L.

description:
Quite an average upscale bar. Was packed, music was good, drinks are expensive and the party is on, even though the bartenders were a bit arrogant.

Tried the much-hyped basil drink - it was OK but not that special.
author: Phil D.

description: Classic bar with excellent cocktails. Try the Pimm's Cup and enjoy the funky 70s music mix.
author: Kelly R.

description:
Spent New Year's Eve 2013 at Rye. For such a classy little joint, I expected it to be super slammed on such a big day, but though it was busy, it was surprisingly not packed. Perhaps because it is tucked away in the Tenderloin it's far enough off the touristy beaten path of Union Square.

This place is known for hand-crafted cocktails -- in the tradition of the speakeasies that have popped up all over recently. I tasted quite a few, some better than others. I'd definitely like to come back on a quieter night and enjoy them more thoroughly.

Decor is chic and subdued. Service was a little scattered, but I guess that's to be expected on a holiday. Music selection confused me very much. Didn't start playing anything remotely upbeat 'til about midnight. 

I can see myself becoming a regular here if it kicks into gear a little earlier in the evening and gets out of that sleepier mode sooner.
author: John C.

description:
Ditto Farah S. Whiskey Sour was incredibly disappointing for a place called Rye. We sent it back. However, the rest of the drinks did live up to expectation, so that must have been a fluke. 
Basil gimlet was as good as they claim. I had the drink special of the night, a woman scorned, which was delicious. We tried at least ten different drinks between the seven of us and all of them were quite tasty. 
The place blends in well, so it's not loud or showy from the outside. It makes it a little incognito if you do a quick drive by down Geary, making it easy to miss.
Not such a big fan of the unisex bathrooms. In drinking establishments there should be one bathroom dedicated to the cleanlier sex. Two single stall bathrooms didn't seem sufficient for the amount of crowd that streamed in.
Two bartenders were working their tails off trying to keep up with orders and the complicated drinks. The server was also working extremely hard to get  all those drinks  distributed, but with the crowd that came in on Saturday night, you would think they would up their staff numbers. Service was quite slow as a result. I guess they want to make sure you don't throw down those potent drinks too fast.
author: Naomi K.

description:
If Nish N says you should have a drink at Rye...well, you have a drink at Rye. Of course. 

Flash, Flash. 
Champagne. 
Flash. 

Flash
English cucumber, *pummeled fresh kiwi, fresh lemon juice, Gin, organic simple syrup, cute little glass. 

*that poor kiwi, right? Pummeled into submission, strained, chilled...and perfect. I think it's a sacrifice they just have to make for me. 

Champagne. Why? I don't know. But, it was beautiful. Also small glasses...but, probably for the best. 

Nish N is right. I concur. 

That Flash is snappy, so is the service. So is Rye.
author: Colleen C.

description:
All I want is whiskey. Not as in "all I want in life", that would be rather alcoholicish and I prefer to keep my life within the range of "lush". When I crave a drink I don't really want a mixer and I don't relish beer. Wine is fine but truly I just want a smooth glass of whiskey or bourbon tossed on some rocks and I'm a happy camper.

Enter Rye. I've been here a few times now, it's dangerous. Dangerous in terms of I could spend a stack of cash here consistently if I don't watch my step. The vibe and ambiance are upscale lounge, inviting you off the cold streets of the TL right up to the bar. Glancing about you'll see the exposed brick, candles, modern woodwork, casual art, and may think pretentious but I assure you the welcoming tenders of the bar are far from aloof.

I'm no veteran in the world of whiskey and thankfully on several occasions the bartenders have walked me through tastes to make sure I found a good fit. I tend to prefer smoky/peaty whiskeys but I have no clue which distillery to select or what region or age I favor. That's where the guidance and samples are much appreciated, they make sure I'm headed in the right direction. I've tried a whiskey cocktail or two here as well and Rye has certainly hit their mark.

I love the Tenderloin but at times a dive bar just doesn't fit my mood. Crazy I know. Maybe I want to enjoy a setting other than a vomit stained floor with a loud drunk man at the pool table. Maybe I want to lazily gaze at art on the walls not of the beer advertisement variety. When I don't want to leave the TL but want to step up my drink game, money says you'll find me at Rye.
author: Justin N.

description: The venue itself is nice and the interior is great. However, the actual location of the bar is oddly placed in comparison to the rest of the neighborhood. It's one of those fresh ingredient speak-easy-ish kinda places. The concept is nice but really challenging to implement as bars typically are meant for fast-paced service. The fresh ingredient crafted drink model doesn't work very well in high-volume scenarios. I waited in line for at least 10 minutes to order a ginger ale. It might be better to have a craft-only area and non-craft drink sections. This would at least let patrons who don't want a specialty drink get theirs quicker while others who are expecting to wait longer do so. It's not a huge spot but it was clean and seemed to be trendy. I would probably visit again but with a small group of friends. Big plus for having two bathrooms in different locations.
author: Richard B.

description:
sosososo impressed. Rye is my new favorite spot--perfect location, awesome patrons, the bartenders are really nice, LOVE the hip hop, it's the chillest vibe. 

The basil gimlet is to die for.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
My partner in crime and I came here after a disappointing experience at an event at the Hilton. We came in and the place was pretty packed, but we went straight to the bar and managed to get the bartender's attention rather quickly. It was here that we finally got a dark n' stormy, which is something we've been looking for for quite some time now; it's actually quite difficult finding a place with ginger beer. The drink and bartender didn't disappoint, and after a couple more drinks we left to continue our night of drunken fun.

All in all it's a great place to grab a few drinks, but maybe not a place to stay since it's so crowded and has limited seating.
author: Ada C.

description: Completely fantastic drinks by a entertaining and talented bartender in a fun atmosphere... Definitely going back! Try as many cocktails as you can handle.
author: Peter R.

description:
Pretty chill and relaxed bar.  I wasn't here for very long but I enjoyed my very strong vodka cran. here.  I sat at the bar and the bartenders were very friendly.  Drinks are around $7, not too bad.  Very pretty decorations and I LOVED how the walls were brick.  I would definitely come back here!

However, this neighborhood is sketchy.  I don't like walking around here late at night.
author: Brittany A.

description:
Rye, noooo! I'm so heartbroken! We're regulars. We spend WAY too much money on cocktails here several times a week. After talking up my all-time favorite SF bar to everyone, I took a group of 12 here to absolutely disastrous service. Comically bad service. The bartenders took ages to make our drinks on a mellow Monday night. After mixing our whiskey sours in the cocktail shaker on of the bartenders walked away to do a shot with a friend and talk for literally 5 minutes while we stood there staring at the cocktail shaker. She then finished the drinks and walked away. We had to call out to her and follow her across the bar to pay for the drinks. 

One of my friends ordered a sidecar only to be told that it would cost extra because it's not on the menu. What does that even mean? You're a cocktail bar. You can make a sidecar. It's not hard. It's what you do. You're a bar. 

I'm praying that this was just an off-night with bartenders who will soon be let go. I love Rye bar and hope it continues to be my go-to.
author: Rachael S.

description: Pretty sweet vibe here pretty much any given day of the week. Good drinks...and if you like pool they have a crooked table you can play on for free. I don't know why you would but it's there
author: James T.

description:
Rye isn't located in the safest neighborhood, but I love it's modern decor and back room dark living room feel.  They offer a variety of special cocktails to choose from depending if you like whiskey, gin, or vodka.  I ordered the Merchant Mule and was pleasantly surprised.  It was kind of like a mint gimlet only made with vodka in this absurd copper cup which you have to put down your credit card in order to drink out of this cup.  You also have to return the cup to the counter in order to get your credit card.

I'll definitely be back and Osha is next door!
author: Carli F.

description: One of my favorite spots...the staff are great with mad talents. Just tell them what you like to drink and they can come up with something delicious.
author: Lulu R.

description:
If I visited twice in less than a week, then a fan I am!

Rye is what I'd like to all a divey cocktail lounge. Sleek and chic? Maybe, but something about the extremely dim lighting, pool table, and crowd of no more than a dozen people (most of them within our group), makes this little sexy escape a bit more "personal" than "panache."

I didn't stray from my choice of cocktail, Pimm's Cup, and I really didn't have any reason too. It was just as refreshing as my beloved Anvil in Houston ... albeit, a tad smaller in size for the same price. (What can I say? Everything's bigger in Tejas.)

Only reason it slightly misses that solid five-star rating is due to the somewhat slow service on slow nights. However, the barkeep was friendly once we flagged 'em away from the regulars.
author: Farrah A.

description: This is a great place for fresh cocktails -- I would highly recommend the Basil Gimlet over most of the other options. The wait at the bar can be long at times, but well worth it. And if you can snag a table, good for you (I've never been able to).
author: Shirley L.

description:
A rare ruby in the largely vacant sand dunes of the Tenderloin, Rye offers refreshingly creative mixed drinks and much-needed atmosphere in a neighborhood populated by convenience stores, bad pizza chains, and standard pubs. 

With its bare-brick walls, reclaimed wood paneling, exposed pipes, and wire grating, the interior of the bar is reminiscent of a New York City loft. The bar is often hectic, and always spread with eccentric ingredients (kumquat, falernum, maple syrup, and purmusuled kiwi). The ladies and gentlemen working behind it are mixologist-bartender hybrids of the highest caliber. Knowledgeable and witty, they're capable of giving recommendations tailored to any patron's taste, or conducting a snappy conversation over the sounds of ice rattling in tumblers and bottles clinking in toasts. With local beers on tap and fancier ones in bottles, Rye has got a selection that will quench most anyone's thirst.

Up-and-coming young entrepreneurs love this spot just as much as the classic barfly or the addled local relishing the revitalizing fresh ambiance, and if you're not lounging on a leather-upholstered custom bench or having a cigarette in the designated smoking area, a glance out the front door might be rewarded with a view of a passing troupe of pub-crawlers or a late-night bike parade.
author: Lauren H.

description:
I came here on a Sunday night with Wendy C., and we had some pretty delicious and very creative drinks.  As Wendy mentions, this place has super original cocktails with VERY interesting ingredients.  Chili? Egg whites? Maple syrup? Yes, you heard that right! 

I ordered the basil gimlet and the Added Bonus.  They were each $10 (a bit steep in my opinion).  The gimlet was actually not very basil-y, but very strong otherwise.  I'm not sure how it got on that 7X7 "Must Eat Before You Die" list; it's admittedly good, but certainly not "last meal on earth"-good.  I also ordered the Added Bonus solely based on the strangeness of the ingredients, which included basil, maple syrup, and egg whites.  It was a STRONG drink; I watched them take their time making it, and our bartender poured a ton of alcohol into it.  Thank you! 

I tried my friend's drinks too, the Bella (a special they had that night, with huckleberries) and the Sao Paolo Sin, which she ordered also because of one of its interesting ingredients: Thai chili!  SPICY.  Too much spice for me, but it was a good drink.  Very new and interesting. 

The bartenders take their time with the drinks, maybe it's more appropriate to call them mixologists.  I noticed all the fresh fruits and other ingredients lying around, and it seems like they take making drinks pretty seriously.  I also liked the atmosphere here, very chill and at the same time, it's a pretty nice place.  

So, overall:
+ Creative, good drinks with fresh, interesting ingredients
- Somewhat steep pricing 
+ Chill atmosphere
+ Good bartenders/mixologists

Oh, and the final awesome point: you have a great selection of post-drink food choices within walking distance, ranging from Osha Thai next door to Bang San Thai down the block to Shalimar down the street!  Great food options after some great drinks!  Or, if you want to continue drinking, Bourbon and Branch is also just down the street. Yum.
author: Vivian C.

description:
The decor and ambiance make this place for a great meetup for small group of friends or even a date-night. I would probably start or end the night here if you're going bar hopping!

The drinks are made to perfection! I love how the bartenders take the time to craft the cocktails.
author: Elizabeth D.

description:
I have bittersweet memories of winter 2010 at Rye.

I once  stumbled through the debris of a heart wrenching break up and found myself  in front of a rather unforgettable old fashioned. It sent warm sensations throughout my body and ruined me for any cocktail to come.  I do wish I had a reason to brave the tenderloin again because I miss the place . It  has the power to make me forget the terrible things and only remember the healing power of whiskey.

 Perhaps the next time I need whiskey, crack, a hooker, or leave a man I care for ...we will meet again.
author: Hannah A.

description:
This was one of the first bars I visited after moving to SF. And I've liked it ever since! Even once the new-to-SF wore off, it was still cool. Good cocktails. Good dark vibe. And around the corner from some dirty-restaurant-but-yummy Indian food.

I'd say this is a good 3rd date spot. It's a little too dark and loud for a first date. But once you're past the original get-to-know-you questions, this place will do nicely. There are lounge booths in one half, and a cool bar in the other. Even a pool table.

I like their moscow mule (although it's called something else) - they'll take your ID as collateral for the bronze mug, so make sure you don't forget it. Not that I did. Ok I did. Don't judge me.

Their Pimm's cup is also dangerously tasty.

Go for it, give it a try.
author: Shanee B.

description: They have mezcal! And my fave gin Uncle Val's. And the bartender was drunker then me before and after I walked out... Kudos young man kudos
author: Mangione M.

description:
Came here for Yelp Drink Week since they had the 1/2 off drink specials.  I ordered the Birds of a Feather, whoooooo! That drink was waaay too strong and i wasn't trying to get that crazy! 

They do have a pool table so if you're into that, do it to it.
author: Daniela R.

description:
I know quite a few people who love Rye. I don't. It's not like you have to drag me there kicking and screaming, but it's a bit antiseptic for my taste. Coziness is my litmus test for a bar, and that's not the vibe here. Sure, there's a pool table, but I also wouldn't feel uncomfortable wearing (trendy) business casual. I never, ever want to feel comfortable in business casual.

The drinks are well-made, with an obvious bent toward whiskey. I've had a couple memorable Manhattans in particular. However, you can order memorable whiskey drinks a couple of blocks away at Bourbon and Branch and get atmosphere too. It just doesn't compute.

So yeah, Rye does what it does well. If that's your scene, cool. If you're my friend and that's your scene, I'll tag along without complaining. If you leave it up to me, though, it won't make the cut.
author: Janna M.

description: BASIL GIMLET! Pool table, relaxing lounging area, and cool atmosphere. Definitely cannot get better than that!
author: Mia L.

description: Came here on a Sunday. the Bartender from San Diego (forgot his name) absolutely rocked! Great Ambiance and best Old Fashioned I've had yet! My new favorite
author: Mitra K.

description:
I absolutely ADORE this place!  This is my favorite watering hole in San Francisco!!!  I live in NYC and this is my 2nd favorite bar, (it would be my 1st if it where in New York).  The bartenders are awesome and friendly.  The setting is cool and kinda sexy in a SF quirky/hip way.  On busy nights, the bar itself can be a ferocious place due to everybody crowding the scene but the bartenders will get to ya (Just be patient.)  

By the way, like everyone says, YOU MUST TRY THE "BASIL GIMLET!"  It really is as good as it gets!  Awesome, awesome place!
author: CrazyLady T.

description: This is the first place i ended up when I landed in San Francisco. I love these drinks! I actually ended up coming back 2 other times while staying in San Francisco. I have to say the area around it is pretty crappy but the inside is cute and the good drinks make up for it!
author: Alessandra A.

description:
RYE
SF: Civic Center?
Sunday/Monday January 2ish 2011
Four Stars

Another Bar.  More Ginger.  More Pimms.  The Old Cuban was amazing.  The pool table was open but there was no cue ball and two 7 balls which were slightly different colored.  This bar started off pretty lounging at first but it began to get pretty packed.  My favorite were these two bigger guys dressed in skirts and when someone asked them why they were wearing them, they gave the most pathetic answer of "Why Not?"  Anyways, I like this bar a lot and I wish I remembered a little bit more of it.  No Table Service.
author: Leonard L.

description: Small typical "craft cocktail" bar with a typical craft cocktail SF bar crowd and typical high prices.  Small space, literally a very small bar.  Bathroom was closed when we went which was lame.  Not necessarily a friendly vibe or crowd.  Not terrible, not a dive bar, but don't see a need to return.
author: Czarina B.

description: Loved this place. Bartenders were great. Came here at 8:30 and got a seat at the bar. Drinks were great, was close to our hotel and restaurant, and vibe was exactly what I wanted. Would definitely recommend.
author: Kate G.

description:
Went to Rye for cocktails with co-workers and when I first walked in I thought in my head "Really? This is it? What's so great about this place?" It seemed like a pretty basic, run of the mill San Francisco bar. Pool table in the back, man and woman getting frisky at the bar, so what's the big deal? 

Then I ordered "The Flash." Ah spank me silly and call me grandma because this cocktail blew me out of the water! Gin, kiwi, cucumber, cane sugar syrup and lime = COCKTAIL BLISS. It's like drinking a cloud from heaven and I gulped mine down in 3 minutes. Mmmm!!!

To "The Flash" - I will see you in a few weeks when I come back and will think of you everyday until then...
author: Emi H.

description:
"Just one drink and then let's get some sleep."

If you say this sentence to your friends and mean it, don't go to Rye. You'll walk in expecting a quickly gulped drink and an early night in bed. What you'll get is a mind-blowingly delicious cocktail and a friendly bartender, the combination of which will keep you on your barstool much longer than you expected. 

The best cocktail my group tried tonight was "The Flash" by far. With gin,muddled kiwi, lemon, cucumber and sugar, it's dangerous. Dudes will be scared to order it because it comes in a pretty little delicate glass, but just suck it up and try it. It's amazing. I ordered the daily special, which included tequila, strawberry, lime and jalepeno and the bartender made sure to check to see that I liked it. 

Rye has a regular mixing contest as well, so if you think you can beat this place at its own game head down and show them what you've got. 

On Wednesday night, the place was buzzing but not bumping, just the way I like it. I was able to hear the excellent soundtrack playing over the ambient noise (Spoon, Wilco, Modest Mouse, oh yes). 

One star docked for the sketchy neighborhood (maybe not a factor to some people but scary for me as a girl who has to walk back to her car/hotel alone), pretty high prices and limited sitting space.
author: Christina P.

description: Cocktails are great! Service and scenery is fantastic! On a nice night feel free to sit in the lovely outdoor area- otherwise grab a couch and relax!
author: Jessica B.

description: delicious drinks and great energy.  Been here a couple times and it's always a fun crowd.  Pim's Cup was delicious and refreshing as was everything else on the menu!
author: Christina K.

description: You gotta keep your eye out for this place as it looks like its boarded up.  That plywood looking stuff is actually the door.  It's dark, reasonably quiet and they made fantastic cocktails here.  We didn't try the food, why would we, it's was cocktails that our spirits needed.
author: Nosmo K.

description: Slowest service... Had to wait around the bar for 10 mins not for an elaborate cocktail... But for a beer. And there wasn't even a lot of people either. Other than that, I like the ambience, the pool table, the RYE sign inside the place is really cool. Plus there's a small patio for smokers! And it sucks to leave your drink behind to have a smoke... So this solves that issue :) one of the last few places we smokers don't feel frowned upon.
author: Alexandra V.

description:
One star for cool atmosphere and another for good ratio of men to women.  Definitely not a sausage fest.  Having said this, bartenders here seemed nice but they passed me over two separate occasions for more than what felt like 30 minutes to try and get a drink.  Seemed like everyone who was whiter and "cuter" than me got served first, even if they came after me.  It really pissed me off.  

I felt like they treated me poorly and didn't even apologize or say thank you.  I came up from LA for a good time and feel like this place really pushed my buttons.  

The atmosphere was cool, the music was crap (they played a country song about saving a horse and riding a cowboy) and drinks were pretentious and weak.  

Maybe I just got rubbed the wrong way and this is a cooler place in non-prime time hours, but I doubt I would come back.  Two stars may be a bit generous.  

The location is not in the best or safest neighborhood, so ladies walking home alone from here please be careful.  I saw some dudes smoking rocks in the middle of the street half a block away.  I'm certain the city has much cooler places to offer.  In Los Angeles we have a number of places like this and I never have trouble getting a drink at the bar.  

The manager seems to be running things well but perhaps she could facilitate expediting service rather than chopping it up with regulars and standing around.  Also, they should get rid of their billiards table and add a second bar or use the space to make room for customers.
author: ShakaZulu S.

description:
I would give this place a 4.5. I've always had great drinks and conversation here so I don't really have anything bad to say. I wish it was a little bigger but otherwise that's all I can say. 

I live right across the street so I think it's a great little place to grab a drink. Some may say I'm spoiled, I say I deserve it :)

Moscow mule is amazing! They will serve it to you in the cool copper cup if you give them your id in exchange.
author: Kelly B.

description:
packed on a friday night-- it took forever to get a drink, i even gave up waiting at the bar, but luckily, i was able to get service at my table.

very cute place, i love the look of horizontal wood!

and like everyone else recommended, get the basil gimlet! sweet, but refreshing!
author: Rosalee C.

description: Bartender dude gave my friends credit card to someone else, he was clearly not sober. Pretty lame considering it was her first time there because I convinced her to go.
author: Dayne A.

description:
I like the look of this place. I also like the fact that it is within sight of the front door of my apartment building--hello drinks that I can imbibe after working absurdly late and still be able to get home at a reasonable hour!

I've liked the aesthetic for a while--from the fact that they have a smoking patio so you don't have to stop the cocktail action while dosing yourself with cancer to the impressive, enormous wooden slab door that's pulled aside every night to kick off the evening. It's one hell of a fine-looking door.

Finally, after much walking past it and thinking to myself that I really needed to give it a try, I went in for some mid evening cocktails with a friend on a Tuesday night (about 8PM or so). They are, apparently, part of this whole cocktail haute couture that consists of "mixologists" making "slow cocktails."

Look, darlin', I don't care how tasty of a cocktail it is, if I'm paying $12 I want my cocktail in something less than 20 minutes, especially when the bar is nearly completely empty!

We had two rounds of drinks, which took us until about 10:30 to manage, despite the fact that we weren't really nursing said drinks. Around 10, the bar started to fill up, and I can only imagine the cocktail service got even slower.

I enjoyed my drinks. I enjoyed my sips of my friend's drinks. It was just slow.

If slow is your thing, or at least you don't really much care, then give Rye a shot. I'd like to say it would be a good date location, due to the dark lighting and leg-touching conducive seating arrangements, but it can get loud. So, how much do you want to talk to your date? Decide accordingly.

I'd definitely steer clear on the weekend. I've never actually gone in, but again, living nearly right next door, I pass it on the regular, and it gets really crowded. Unless they exponentially increase the number of bartenders, service must get crazy slow.

A good place, I'm glad to have it in my neighborhood, but nothing to write home about.
author: Vivienne P.

description: Nice venue. I liked that there was plenty of seating. A good place to catch up and drink.
author: Margaret R.

description:
Hello to my new favorite drink, the wonderfully crafted basil gimlet at Rye.  It was so dangerously delicious that I would trek back into the TL just for it!

The down and dirty: Moody dark decor, free non-standard size pool table, outside smoking area, and a limited seating area (good luck getting a table).

The bartenders take a lot of time and care to make their drinks aka it can take awhile so be patient!  I definitely want to come back on a non-weekend night and ask the bartenders to make me something "special". 

Drinks on the pricier side, $14 for the gimlet.
author: Kim-van T.

description: So I sort of stumbled yet was invited to Rue. I had a nice time in the place, it was cozy (at least where I was). It was more of a whiskey bar so I wasn't in my element. They don't have a good beer selection. I can't say I hated the drink that I had but I'm definitely not ordering it again.
author: Paola S.

description:
OK, after many years coming here, I really need to update this review.  Jen set me on the path of the cocktail connoisseur (snob?) and I have to give props.  The crowds aren't nearly as douchey as they used to be (or they've matured, or I've gotten more douchey?) but it can still get pretty crowded here on a fri/sat night.

But the cocktails are still the bomb.  Not usually as intricate as the ones at 15 Romolo, but still finely crafted and delicious.

Over many years, Rye has become my default bar on Friday nights after work.  And between the bartenders' friendly demeanors and artful craft, I just can't stop coming back.  The cocktails are easily accessible, yet can be complicated or simple enough to satisfy my cocktail snobbery.  What do you expect?  I "grew up" on the drinks here.
author: Fong L.

description: Always a fan of new, original cocktails.... and they have a bunch. There's always a danger in getting too cutesy with naming original cocktails and I'm glad they keep it pretty straight-forward. Good stuff, I'll be back.
author: Mike J.

description: Nice overall ambiance, quite classier than average. Great cocktails.
author: Leo L.

description:
2 words.

Basil Gimlet.

Enough said!

I love this place, its vibe and its cozy atmosphere. Worth checking out!
author: Purnima S.

description:
Stopped in after a giant dinner for a drink and some games of pool.

The basil gimlet is AMAZING.  The bartender definitely has mixing skills.

Free games of pool!  Granted, the pool sticks are half broken, and the eight ball is the red stripe ball colored in.  And, I got schooled with trick shots.  Not fair!

Ladies, the sink was totally there to trick me!  I didn't know how to turn it on for a good 20 seconds.  The key is to push the gadget on the right up.  Got it?  Good.  Wish I knew that beforehand.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Rye never disappoints. They should have a drink here named "Catcher in the Rye" or "Holden", I loved that book. It would be a quintessential recipe: Shake and strain 2oz rye whiskey, 3/4oz sweet vermouth, and 2 dashes of bitters. Add a cherry or orange peel. A reliable concoction for teenage angst or just plain new to SF rebellion. 

I am really happy to see they have added more upbeat music these days. The ambiance is chill, dark, high ceilings, cool artwork, lounge tables, an outdoor patio for smokers, pool table, and two bathrooms. I seem to enjoy more Thursdays and Fridays here, but its always a pretty chill vibe. 
 
The drinks are always top-notch and beautifully crafted. I recommend ordering sazerac, birds of a feather, pimms cup, mojito, old fashioned, campari,  and their usual specials. The best part about Rye is that you can start off here and then when you are ready to dance, go across the street to Ambassador and see where the night takes you.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
Once upon a time when I was acting like I lived in the city, Rye was a perfect stop if you were feeling fancy. It's located in the prestigious Tenderloin and just a few blocks away from many many other amazing bars in the TL.

Come on a breezy summer afternoon and enjoy some of their specialty drinks, they use some awesome ingredients that are extremely fresh. The result ends up being a super refreshing drink to help you get through the evening. Or chug down some damn Whiskey! It'll give you courage to walk around at all hours of the night in that neighborhood. Trust me.
author: Debbie P.

description: Another trendy and chill, but lively SF lounge big on mixology.  I always enjoy the cocktail concoctions they have going on here and they create new ones all the time.  Space is relatively small, even though there are three areas to hang out.  The main bar area -- though a substantial part near the bar is occupied by a pool table -- a subsided area with seating which at times has an obscure movie projected on the brick wall, and a caged outdoor area with limited seating (that you can also bring your pets out to).  Crowd is usually a good mix of folk.
author: Erich D.

description:
I came here on Saturday night since it was part of Yelp Drink Week 2012.  There's no sign on the door (supposedly, it's trying to be speakeasy-like) but not hard to find since there's a decent line of people waiting to get their IDs checked by the bouncer.

Got in and immediately ordered the Yelp Drink Week specials.  Birds of a Feather was like a whiskey with a slice of orange in it.... similar to an old fashion - so I'm told as I've never had one before.  Also got the Pimm's Cup which is similar to a mojito but made with Pimm's rather than rum.

The venue is small and there's a pool table in the back.  What's awesome is that there's a guy/girl bathroom stall and a women's only bathroom in the back.  Finally, someone recognizes our needs!  Maybe there's a men's only bathroom somewhere too...
author: Joyce C.

description: Came here on a Monday night and there was still a decent crowd. Basil Gimlet, you are so good and got me SO drunk. I love the venue. Very modern without feeling pretentious. Great place to come grab some delicious cocktails and just relax and enjoy good company.
author: Cindy A.

description: Good mules or rather their variation of it. The bartender made this clear. "It's not a mule. It's a variation of it." I just asked him why he was correcting me. See. I could get feisty. The bartender is really trying to make a good drink for you. He even tries each drink he makes. Albeit I am not sure if he is pretending at this point.. I highly recommend this place. Everyone's favorite for the night seemed to be their Pimms cup. It is sweet and mask the alcohol. A creeper, is that what they call it?  Place is dark and quiet and perfect for catching up with a friend. Plus the bartender put up with my antics, which is always good.
author: Hazel F.

description:
Pool table, 2-stall lady restrooms, outdoor smoking patio and being too hip to have a sign outside. I've never seen it really packed, but it's very laid back and hip. I like the style even if I've never wanted to end the night here.

If you're bored, try the Ambassador across the street.
author: Betty C.

description:
Pub Crawl Stop #8~

Final stop. Errr...I don't remember much. We were all standing...I hope. There was a pool table. And the bathroom was small. 

I do remember I was supposed to come here for HH, but didn't.
author: Marti L.

description: Cool ambiance but not really a serious cocktail place. Feels like they're another place trying to ride the current trends. Fresh fruit and house made simply syrups are great but booze should come first.
author: Joshua G.

description:
Popular, minimalist, and not too hoity-toity, Rye's a crowdpleaser of a place. As a friend of mine put it: there's no suspenders and waxed mustaches here. Not much in the way of atmosphere, either: some colorful abstract paintings and a cool street-facing smoking den are the space's main distinguishing features. Though I'm told it gets packed in nicer weather, we visited on an uncrowded weekday evening, and easily slipped into a booth big enough for six. 

For my drink, I went for the house whiskey, the heady Rock 'n' Rye, served over a giant ice cube. The Talking Heads played surreptitiously in the background. "This is not my beautiful life!" You said it, Byrne. 

Overall, Rye seems like a good place to take a group, especially one with members who'd like to talk to eachother, about things other than housemade bitters and favored Scotch-producing regions. Though SF boasts other weirder, wilder bars that I like better, I'd imagine if you're a local, it's nice to hit up someplace low-key like Rye once in a while.
author: Ryan W.

description: I've been asking information for birthday party and it will take years to send me an email. They don't take it serious ,
author: Ebru Ö.

description:
Oh Romero yummy in my tummy!  The female brunette bartender can tell you where ever liquor comes from, the owners history and make a drink to fit your needs for the night.  It was a fantastic experience.  

I have heard that it gets very "douchey" after 10 p.m. so if you are looking for good drinks and a chill hangout go early!
author: Sarah B.

description:
Two nights ago JB and JM did some good philosophizing before rolling to Rye to check out the scene.  I've been to this bar several times before and have always had a great time.  The lounge on Geary has an unpretentious urban hipster feel and attracts a cool SF crowd this is looking for a good chill spot, but also a place where you can people watch.

For some reason I always order a French Connection here and am generally not disappointed.  For those who like their Hennessy or Grand Marnier this is a great spot to enjoy it.  

JB pointed out that Rye was showing various pics of nudes in a slideshow on the exposed brick wall.  This subtle visual stimulus ads an artsy flair to the place.  The smokers lounge outside also allows patrons to add some nicotine to their night without feeling the need to leave or be isolated from the action.  

I like the versatility of Rye and plan on coming back soon.
author: John M.

description: Fantastic cocktails (worth the wait) + nice selection of single malts - what more would a girl want?  Nice to hang on the low couches in the lounge area.  Music was fun & not too loud (on a Thurs) so you can chat with your companions.
author: Kim S.

description:
I'm putting this place on the rotation for sure.

Class it up without pretension. Spend a little more on some well-crafted drinks but not too expensive. Look like a cool kid. 

I will return.
author: Kiristen R.

description:
How many hot girls do you have to bring up to the bar before the bartender will take your order at Rye? I'll never know because I'm never going back.

Granted, it was a packed Saturday night but I did my due diligence and waited until I could physically get an elbow on the bar, money in hand. 10 minutes went by. Then 20. At this point, not one of the three bartenders, though busy, had said a single word to neither my friend nor me (not even made eye contact). We had a few cute girls around so we brought them up, hoping to get an edge. I'm not sure what one has to do other than simply wave money and be loud to get a damn drink at Rye, but apparently my classy and patient approach wasn't enough.

Maybe I went at the wrong time or just simply didn't understand the culture but I don't really care. It's not for me.
author: Mark L.

description:
Paul Rudd on 40 year old virgin "Yea it's 15 dollar beer night"

Swanky.
author: Daisy M.

description:
I started this review @ 3 weeks ago the morning after my girl friends and I wandered into Rye for a cool specialty basil cocktail my friend Kate adores. We had a good time and spent a ton of money. Their specialty drinks were delish. Only negative was that I left my gym bag with my brand new running shoes in with my work out clothes and a sweater that was my Mom's before she passed away (which made it important to me). I called multiple times in hopes someone would answer the phone and also left 2 or 3 messages with my number asking them to call me either way and let me know if they had found it.

No response. Still waiting as a matter of fact. We spent @ $200 that night between us. Guess that's not enough to get a call back. This should of been a 4+ star review. Oh well.
author: Lisa H.

description:
This is my kind of bar! I like being able to say to a bartender "I like gin, herbal and bitter flavours, nothing too sweet and preferably served short" and leaving it to them to create something for me. It pushes me to try things I may not ordinarily, gives the bartender the opportunity to experiment with new ideas or use an old classic that they don't get to bring out very often. 

The few drinks I had at Rye recently all hit the mark.  I especially enjoyed the Southside - a reminder of how much I like this cocktail and that I ought to order it more often.
author: Tresna L.

description:
Rye has the best Basil Gimlets...so refreshing and easy to drink!  I like the overall set up of the place...one room that is nice for hanging out in groups, cool bar area where you can watch the bartenders work their magic, and a POOL table!

Oh yeah, there's a patio area too!
author: Sandy L.

description:
Rye is another entry in the ever-more-crowded field of craft cocktail bars.

Drinks are delicious, often feature obscure ingredients, are about $10, and strong. I had a Blood and Sand and my usual Manhattan (I love me some whiskey). Both excellent.

Decor is modern and trendy, the lights are dim, and it's a big place with plenty of seating.

Kind of like if someone took Churchill or Blackbird, made it twice as big and half as loud (this in particular is really awesome), and dropped it on the edge of the Tenderloin. A bit of an odd location but I guess the rent is cheaper, and hey, it's walking distance from work! With any luck I'll be back.
author: Sam K.

description:
Low lighting, very tasty drinks, and an atmosphere that's cool but welcoming.

I do love me some cocktails, and Rye serves up some very creative concoctions. If I could sustain on cocktails alone, I think Rye would be my nutrient source.

I dig the design and the tables on the lower half, plus the steel cage that surrounds the "patio" out front, even if there wasn't quite enough seating for all of us out there.

Hopefully I get another chance to sip a Rye signature next time I'm in SF!
author: Brittany K.

description: Very nice place, but the staff was slow and more about talking to friends than bar tending.
author: Ruben B.

description:
Came here after trying to get into the library at  Boubon and Branch.

This place had some of the best cocktails at a reasonable price!


Such a huge drink menu, I recommend the Pimm's cup, and some type of drink with blood orange, and fizzies.  Both were delicious and it was hard not to try every single thing on the menu.  Too bad after two I'm done.

The bartenders were very friendly, quick and helpful.  The prices were average for SF, on the lower side for the quality.  The space was bit packed, but the people were friendly.  Around the bar they have a bunch of seats, and standing area, then they have a lower level with some seats and an open air patio.

I enjoyed my time here, I would come back.
author: Courtney R.

description:
Basil Gimlet. 
Hanger vodka on the rocks.
Done and done.

It's a cool space but it's pretty small.  It's also really really loud in there!  Cute place to visit as a bar hopping stop!
author: Helen V.

description:
The basil gimlet is brilliant (See my photo).  It's like a really good mojito, with just a subtle note of basil to it.

The bar has a very nondescript facade; it's easy to miss (see photo)
author: Scott F.

description:
3.5 STARS:  I really like this venue.  Its sleek, urban, and un-pretentious.  Its in the Center-loin:  is that what it would be since it borders Civic Center and Tenderloin? Whatever.  Anyways, its a good looking spot with ample interior space for a neighborhood bar.   I had a hard time locating the Rye sign, but if you see Osha Thai, Rye is next door.

Here's where points were docked:
-Pool Table:  Shiiiiieeeee.  Man, thing needs to be retired.  I mean, I love playing pool while tossing a few back with coworkers but not under these conditions.   Felt is hurting.  Balls get stuck.  2 sticks, 1 chalk.   .5 point deduction.
-NO BEERS ON TAP.  That's a full point deduction in my book.

Happy Hours specials:
Nothing huge (I think its because they don't have beer on tap)
I believe it was $1 off beers and $2 off speciality drinks. 
CHICKS:  Basil gimlet and Pim's cup
I of course (queue: pant shift) was jamieson & ginger backs plus beers.  (beelch.... a true dainty lady I know.) ahahha :)
author: Deanna A.

description:
My coworker and I decided to extend our thirsty Thursday into Friday. Would that make it fun, freaky or maybe even fabolous? Well, it was too early to tell. We ventured to Rye on my own selfish reason to possibly join in on the Yelp DYL gathering. I figured hey... why not. Kill two birds with one stone sort of thing.

We got there pretty early (the place still smelled like fresh cut limes and lemons) so we were able to grab two seats at the bar. They have a great selectiong of whiskey and even their own infusion. We decided to try some of their cocktails. Pretty darn tasty! We soon realized that having an open tab might become dangerous. But again... why not. We were even gutsy enought to try out their rock and rye whiskey- neat. 

As the night and happy hour progressed, another coworker joined us. I was also able to spot the Yelp crew - yay!Met a couple of cool people and enjoyed the lounge area behind the bar. This place is pretty chill and even has a little patio/smoking area. It does get crowded quickly though. But everyone looks to be having a great time, except for the homeless person who strolled in for a moment. Maybe she knew that the bartenders make a tasty and mean cocktail too! As the night progressed there was a bouncer outside and you have to start defending seats. But all in all, a great place for cocktails and fun with some pals and strangers.
author: Dee D.

description:
This is one of my favorite bars to go to in SF. The drinks are amazing, especially the one with a cucumber in it. The bartenders are super helpful, they can basically make recommendations based on what kinds of liqueur and flavors you like. Vince and Phil (the bartenders) are definitely good at their job! 

The atmosphere is fairly easygoing. Yet, this bar has a pretty luxurious look to it. I really like the fact that they have a second room with tables and couches. They even have a server for that area so you don't have to wait at the bar. 

Overall, Rye is the best spot in the neighborhood and I highly recommend it.
author: Kate G.

description:
#1 sure-fire mouth watering cocktail: Basil Gimlet.

Come here for the casual to trendy atmosphere, seating, and maybe even the free pool.

Watch out though, the pool table is free but totally cruddy. If you're wondering why a ball is missing, either someone stole it or more likely it's stuck inside the table. Drop some more balls into the pockets to try to knock it out, and hope they don't get stuck too.
author: Fawn B.

description:
Rye oh Rye you gotta be so cool? Brick walls, cozy couches, rad bartenders, strong drinks - you've got it all figured out. I don't even care what kind of music you play (you do play music, don't you?) because once I get your Basil Gimlet in my tired hand, I go to my magic place. 

And I'm not even a cocktail drinker.

Your Pimm's Cup is sharp and refreshing, your Blood and Sand kicks my ass, and Flash is my new best friend. I don't even care that your straws biodegrade in my cup - the drink will be long gone before that even begins to happen.

I'll be back, Rye. This is the beginning of something beautiful.
author: Robin M.

description:
Cocktails anyone? Why, I don't mind if I do.

An intriguingly low-lit lounge with a lower level of low tables and an enclosed little patio out front. I opted for The Flash, a tasty mixture of gin, cucumber, kiwi and lemon. It was so tasty, in fact, that I opted for two of them before my visit here was done.

Also not your typical looking wait staff on duty. The lovely folks working the bar made some mean drinks, and all with a kind of friendliness that didn't seem to quite match the bar, and yet at the same time added that much more to it.

Great to grab a couple of drinks with your friends and a conversation or two.
author: Wendy P.

description:
Living in the neighborhood, Rye is usually one of my favorite bars to hit up at any time of the week. Its usually never too crowded, the drinks are well made, and the ambiance is relaxing and cool. 
But the only downside thus far has been an unbelievably mean and rude bartender who is usually there on friday and saturday nights. Most bartenders here will wait until they have completed someone else's order before asking for yours, this woman asks for multiple orders at a time. So after waiting about 20 mins to get her attention you will usually have to wait another 15-20 mins to your drink. On one occasion she yelled at a patron, who had not yet ordered from her but was standing in the vicinity, to not order from one of the other bartenders and to just wait for her. I found this pretty shocking and rude considering we were all still waiting to place an order. Since it didn't happen to me I simply ignored her sour puss attitude. 
On my most recent visit to Rye the same bartender had taken my boyfriends order, questioned if he was making the right decision "Are you sure? Its a white wine spritzer you know", then taking 20 mins to even start making the drinks without even saying a simple, "It will just be a minute". After too many false alarms with the drinks we simply decided to cancel our order and leave. She shot us a look, and walked away without saying anything.
Long story short. This is a great place, but I think I will try to order from somebody who doesn't let their indifference ruin people's night out.
author: Jessica G.

description:
I would have loved to love Rye. 

The place is great, very nice design, intimate lights, very nice smoking area, I really loved the way everything was organized in this bar. The drinks list was also very nice and tempting. Basil cocktails, original names... From the list, I wanted to drink them all!

The only tiny problem is... I really didn't like my drink... I had the Fraised and Confused (greaaat name), which sounded really nice, but which I found really too strong for my own taste. I tried out a few drinks from my friends but didn't find the perfect match there either... Sad...! Add to this the fact that the drinks were really looong to make (the waitress took lots of care to prepare them, but since she was all alone at the bar, it took some time), I was a bit disappointed with the place.

But I think I should go back there one day and try again, because the place really is nice and comfy! Until then... 3 stars!
author: Camille L.

description: One of many spots brightening up the Tenderloin. Good music, plenty of space to hang out, mix of tourists and locals. Pimms #5 was really special, though my Y. Presbyterian was kind of one note. Friendly laid back bartenders, and plenty of staff so you don't have to wait an hour for a drink.
author: Nick C.

description:
Dark, industrial and minimalist, Rye keeps the focus on what's important: making cocktails that mean business, and drinking cocktails that mean business - both of which are concepts I can really get behind.

Still, I can't help but wonder why it isn't just called Gin since those are their cocktails (Aviation, Hey Day) that really blow the others out of the ballpark.

The fact that there isn't much on the inside actually makes for a really great drinking atmosphere. No one wants a cocktail bar where people just sit down and stay down all night.

When you're sloppy, you might as well be mingling by the bar, dancing in between the few tables, or pretending to be a caged lion on the smoking patio. Otherwise you're just not going to be getting your money's worth outta those $10 cocktails.

Cool art, spectacular drinks, and just the right kind of crowd!
author: Ben B.

description: Best on a tuesday or weds before 9pm. Hot toddie is best. Winter bar. Dark, stylish, great lounge tunes. Chill and clean.
author: Angela G.

description:
Unlike other craft cocktail bars I've visited, Rye isn't promoting the whole super dim/ dark wood aesthetic. It's comfortably lit in there for a bar, there are concrete floors, and generally a funkier vibe. Yet make no mistake, Rye's tenders mix a mean cocktail, and there's something for all palates. Well as long as your palate craves liquor. Let's face it, if you're there with me, why wouldn't it? You're just a weirdy, and I don't think we can be friendsy.

Speaking of weirdies, there was a drunken dude that was all up in everyone's bizness around the bar. He said he was a friend or relative of one of the bartenders, but it didn't excuse his too-friendly, no-regard-for-personal-space antics. He would just plop himself down at our table, reach over people for drinks... just really inappropriate, unwelcome behavior. At one point, he claimed he was a werewolf and was feeling crazy because the full moon was coming, and then he plucked the basil out of my friends' drink, took a bite, made a sneer, and spit out the rest... BACK INTO MY FRIEND'S DRINK. Not cool at all dude. If that had been my drink, I don't think I could've been as forgiving, but my friend just laughed it off.

Aside from that guy invading our space and making some of us uncomfortable, we had a great time at Rye. Our party kept growing as friends and friends of friends kept popping in, and the drinks kept flowing. Like I said, they have something for everyone, from a long list of specialty cocktails, to custom-ordered ones, to a decent beer selection (Hitachino Nest White Ale was the popular choice that night). I'm pretty sure this will be a staple of my visits to the city.
author: Mike Q.

description:
Basil gimlet was damn strong but I will definitely make sure to order another next time I'm at Rye.

Very cool space in a very un-cool neighborhood....sorry I just don't really feel safe down there.  :-/
author: Sofia H.

description: Rye is extremely good at what they do. I went to bourbon and branch because I heard they were known for their mixed drinks, but they let me down. So I went to Rye and I was completely blown away. I had some sort of pisco drink with rosemary and it was SO GOOD. The bartenders were super nice and very attentive to what I wanted. There is also a small pool table with a lounge area. I would definitely go here again!
author: Grace C.

description:
Came by with some friends and all I have to say is BASIL GIMLET.  So delicious that we seriously contemplated on buying a bottle of it for $100... 

Crowded as it's a small spot.  Pool table.  Restroom isn't convenient (one per) and parking is not pleasant.
author: Patricia G.

description:
Friend of mine did his birthday here a couple of months back. We got there early so we were able to grab a table and sit down. The drinks were okay, nothing special. This place tries to create a feeling of a speakeasy, but the drinks are not as good as you would expect.

The night we were there, the AC wasn't working, so you could barely breathe in this place.

However, if you are looking to have a quick beer here, then it's a pretty good place. Drinks are slightly overpriced.
author: Karina A.

description:
Rye was one of my highlights of my evening in S.F 

After mentioning I was a big fan of the Manhattan, my gf's buddy recommended that we go here. It was spot on. 

When we got there I ordered the Dogpatch - Pikesville Supreme Rye, Averna, Noilly Prat Rougue, Regan's Bitters. Spot on again. 

Throughout the evening I ordered many more drinks that were recommended by the bartender. The fifth star is for her knowing Murrary and the famous Zig Zag Cafe in my hometown of Seattle!
author: Cameron B.

description: Got the Merchant Mule and then the Hebrew IPA and I was a fan of both. Went here with my husband and there was plenty of room and it had a nice romantic feel. Will be back!
author: Brittini S.

description:
I don't live in San Francisco so I don't know what this neighbourhood is like but I'm pretty sure I hate it. 

This is a good bar. It's unfortunately full of dick heads and all transportation that leads here is dominated by vagrants.

The good:
- again, this bar is pretty great - lots of seats, good layout, generally pleasing aesthetics 
- my drink was excellent
- clean, good restrooms
- pool table (unfortunately overtaken by people who were... not playing pool)
- great details - the concrete block in the floor of the doorway is poured around the namesake and the wood in the ceiling above the bar looks great
- staff was cool, welcoming and friendly
- good music

The bad:
- i didn't really like the other people patrons (see: douche factory, here: http://goo.gl/BCfIc)
- I hate their artwork. I get that they need a bunch of huge pieces but I hate the ones they have. They're just huge and meaningless. This is actually my number one complaint about this establishment. Bad, huge art.
- our party was accosted by a drunk, who started out trying to buy Kat drinks at the bar. She unwittingly brought him back to our table (hey, isn't that my move??) where he immediately fell in lust with Mike's beard, regaled us with stories of the complex customs forms he has to complete legibly at UPS (he's employed?) when mailing things to Canada, then bought Mike a drink under the guise of it being for a "fellow Canadian" (he was definitely from south america) and... it was just very confusing, but I have a lot of great photos of the situation.  Harmless/funny/confusing.

I would come here again if someone else picked it, but I would never choose this venue for anything. The other patrons were kind of obnoxious for my taste and the drinks were exorbitantly priced (average $13).  

I wish I could teleport this venue to a different location and fill it with people that I actually like, then I would never leave.
author: sarah l.

description:
Lofty drinks.

Exposed concrete. Spacious. Subtle lighting. Chill vibe. And on a rather warm night, a beer that hit the spot.

If I can't live here, at least I can drink here.
author: Jason B.

description:
Chill spot to relax with the friends!

I loved the dim lighting and the soft, low benches. We sat around a small table and just enjoyed each other's companies. We came on a Sunday night so it was quiet but it was perfect. The drinks were made to perfection. My friends loved the flash. I ordered a chartreuse swizzle for my friend and she said it tasted like chex mix. The cocktails are special, unlike many that I've tried. I'd definitely come back!

I've only said good things about this place but why not 5 stars? They don't have every drink you'd imagine. Seems like they only have the drinks that they use in the cocktails. I wouldn't come here for shots, but cocktails, yes.
author: Connie Y.

description: You had me at copper mug! Well balanced Moscow mule served in a proper vessel. Fun little bar. Would certainly go here often if I didn't live thousands of miles away...
author: Griffith G.

description: Great cocktail bar. Approved by Italians. Good cocktails and nice people!
author: Sean F.

description:
I discovered Rye as the night cap drink to Bourbon and Branch and it's quite nice.  And sometimes it's even the replacement to Bourbon and Branch when they're being a pain.

They make great classic drinks (sazerac, blood and sand etc) as well as great interesting drinks (Sicilian mojito is one of my favorites, although it's no longer on the menu.  You can still ask for it and they will make it for you--it's on the sweet side made with Averna liquor).

There are a few seats at the bar and a few smaller tables with couches in the "downstairs" (down 2-3 stairs) area. But there's some decent standing room along the bar and near the pool table.

All in all, great place to get great tasting drinks!
author: Traci H.

description:
Not sure what it's like on the weekend, but during the week there's no bouncer, no line and no crowds.  It's a totally chill neighborhood bar with a cool atmosphere and killer drinks list.

I've been on an old fashioned cocktails kick so I didn't get that many fruity drinks here.  Started with the basil gimlet and though it was good I didn't think it was mind blowing.  What was really good was the blood & sand (with blood oranges).  I was really impressed and even more so because I'd never heard of it before, but then I found it out it was a standard recipe so I was sad that it took me so long to discover this tasty drink but was still super impressed with the execution at Rye.  After that I had a sazerac (which for some reason I remember as being cloudy - is that true for sazerac's? I found it odd).  Then finished it up with an Old Cuban.

Happy hour turned into many happy hours and I finally made it home at midnight.

I thought the female bartenders there were nice and knew their stuff.  I wasn't so impressed with the guys.
author: Jean K.

description:
S L O W .

I came with three other friends on a quiet Monday night. There was at most about 15 people in the bar that night, but it took them about 20 minutes to get 4 cocktails done. 

The friends I was with were visiting from another city and one who owns a bar there. Ouch, thanks! It was quite embarrassing for me to take them there thinking that Rye was a better choice in the neighborhood.

So you can actually make pretty good drinks, but I wish you could've done them quicker.
author: Rika P.

description: Their moscow mule is made the way it should be made. delicious!
author: Jade Y.

description: My old stopping ground. Great specialty cocktails. The bar itself is a great place to start on a weekend, or cool place to grab a drink after work on a weekday. They have a pool table and plenty of seating Inside. Best big ice cubes around (: my favorite drink is the gin gimlet with basil, tastes like a liquid dessert:
author: Rosie N.

description:
My boyfriend and I stopped in after a long day of walking and sight seeing! The ambiance was perfect! Dim lighting, great music, & perfect way to end our day (& begin our night)! Drinks were great, service impeccable and super friendly! Nothing bad to say! Will definitely recommend
 and return!
author: Tania S.

description:
This place is pretty sweet. I had my first-ever sazerac here and enjoyed it immensely. I normally don't drink bourbon or whiskey - it burns. But this went down so smooth. While I was sitting at the bar the bartender was very accomadating and refilled my water glass without prompting. 

Go here if you are serious about cocktails and willing to spend a bit of extra time and money to have one that is properly made. Order off their drink menu and try something new (or old, if you're going with a vintage cocktail such as the sazerac). Just live a little and trust your bartender.

The crowd is good: more age 30s than 20s. I actually went here alone while traveling solo and found some friendly, nonsketchy locals to converse with and hang out with the rest of the night. A success all around.
author: Emily R.

description:
Fab.U.Lo.So!!!
I've been here on many occasions and thoroughly enjoy the scrumptious and innovative cocktails. Last thursday I had the pleasure of meeting the man, the myth, Mr Greg L. in the flesh. He was actually behind the bar, muddling, mixing and getting his hands dirty with the rest of the Rye crew. He also turned one of my drinking companions(usually a jim beam chick) on to Pikesville , so we'll see if she switches it up.
A lovely place to lounge and chat up a hot date. . . .
author: Kia B.

description:
Date & Time:  Friday May 16, 2008 @ 12pm
Company:  Christina & Peter, Lydia & Anthony, Michael
Crowd:  Trendy Diverse Crowd 
Vibe:  Energetic & Chill  
Decor:  Two Very Cool Rooms and Outdoor Patio for Smokes - one area with tables and the other with the bar and brick wall and mirrors and a pool table in the back.
Service:  Very Cool Door Guys & Manager - bald guy rocks! & Nice Bartenders
Imbibe:  Specialty Cocktails like Blueberry
author: Genevieve Y.

description:
When Ambassador gets a little too... street (sometimes they'll let in some silly people) I'll go here and pay a little more for a cocktail. The bartenders here are super knowledgeable and don't mind talking with you for a bit. It's hard to have a conversation at Ambassador. 

The interior is nice, cozy, a little bit modern with low intimate lighting. 

I'd be impressed if I was to be taken here on a first date. Hints!
author: Amanda S.

description: What a great place to visit. Amazing and friendly bar staff who really know how to mix their drinks. Mixed crowd, all very chilled and friendly. In the tenderloin but worth the visit and the grittiness of the area only adds to the bars appeal. They do the best whisky sour with egg white but challenge the bar staff to create something for you...tell them a couple of flavours you like and they get very creative. Worth the visit and really good prices.
author: John B.

description: I love the interior design of this place. Contemporary, pristine and edgy is how I would describe it. Great place for yummy drinks and to hang out with friends.
author: Debra T.

description:
After the Giants won Game 1 of the World Series, my friends and I ended up at Rye to celebrate the victory and enjoy a night cap before we went our separate ways. 

This place is mellow and if it wasn't for some of the chairs in need of upholstery repair, I would say it was classy. It's very close to being classy and sophisticated but you can still feel comfortable there even if you aren't wearing a dress and heels. The lighting is pretty cool around the bar an there is a huge mirror to make you think this place is larger than it actually is and there are millions of bartenders waiting to take your order. 

I got the "Flash" because I'm usually partial to gin cocktails upon my first visit to a new bar. This drink has kiwi, cucumber, gin, lemon juice, cane syrup and maybe a couple of other things you would find on the menu at Juice It Up!.

The Flash is very refreshing. It's sweet but not to sweet and it goes down smooth. 

The facade to this place is easy to miss so pay attention while walking in the area. 

I look forward to coming back and trying more of the drinks.
author: Daisy S.

description:
I think it's safe to say the word is out on this hot little thang. The space is sexy and the owners put some coin into making the bar look good. The wood panel up above is a nice touch and the chalk art in the back is sweet. The furniture in the lounge area could be better. Though likely expensive, the chairs look like they belong in a pizza parlor.

Last Saturday night the bar was busy, but not painfully packed. The scene could really benefit from a live DJ. The current music set up doesn't do the space justice.

Overall it's a cool spot, definitely worth dropping in...
author: Jeremy S.

description:
The seating is comfy, the bathroom smells lovely (and has great fixtures) and the drinks are well-made.

What more do you need?

Also, I met my new favorite cocktail here: the Hemingway Daiquiri

10 Cane Rum shaken with
Maraschino Liqueur, Fresh
Grapefruit & Lime Juice served
straight up

UPDATE 7/19/1006:
Brought a group here to celebrate a birthday. Had an awesome time with the bartender, John, who even brought us out a round of tasty shots he'd concocted. This guy makes a mean cocktail!
author: Miriam W.

description:
After dancing for a couple of hours at Swig, my friends and I decided to take a break and went to Ambassador, which was absolutely dead and creepy. So we crossed the street and went to Rye. That's my kind of place!  :-)

Love the exposed brick walls (always a sucker for them), the cozy lounge area, the high ceilings, the music videos, the pool table.....it's such a fresh refuge from the coldness and sadness of the tenderloin. 

We got our drinks (which by the way were fabulous) and spent some time at the pool table, having some fun playing while we talked about our week. Great place to either start or finish a mellow and fun night in the city.
author: Simone W.

description: This was a nice modern, hip bar in an almost sketch area. We walked here from the Hilton, but made sure to stay on Geary. A block over either way is all bad, especially if you're a bit inebriated. I loved the hardwood ceilings, pool table in the back, lounge area, brick walls, and smokers cage. A cool chic spot. The bar tenders and waitress were cool and made good drinks. This is the kind of bar you start off at while sober and can appreciate the ambiance.
author: Jenn E.

description:
Basil gimlet - amazing and fresh tasting.

I came here for Happy Hour just to taste this drink. I love the look and feel - so industrial! It would have been nice to get table service instead of having to walk a whole of 10 steps to the bar. What can I say - I love being served. 

The only thing missing is a bar menu - a girl has GOT to eat!
author: Monica Y.

description:
I liked Rye, the drinks were awesome. When did the TL get soooo hip? The bartendress made some "off the menu" special cocktails that were simply lovely. So good in fact, I had quite a few. My night favorite - the red and blue, a vodka drink made with muddled strawberries and blueberries.  She also made this special champagne cocktail with Orange Blossom that tasted like a spiked Orange Julius (for those of you who know what that is) or a flower. Oh and the basil martini was great too. 

YUMMM-tastic.
author: Rebekah T.

description:
Came here last night for Yelp Drinks -- it was around midnight when we arrived, and by then they had run out of the 5 Island Rum Punch. SAD! Mainly because that was the one that I really wanted to try. We ended up ordering the other two options, and the Pimm's Cup was far superior than the Birds of a Feather. They did honor the prices, and charged us $10 for the two.

We also ended up trying the gimlet which seems to be the go-to drink here, and it definitely lived up to the hype. It was a very smooth combination of flavors, and for someone who's not well-versed in her alcoholic concoctions - this was good!

The crowd/line outside can seem a little intimidating, but it actually moves fast, and the bartenders are great. They are really well-staffed and we didn't have to wait long to order drinks at all.

It's a little more upscale than what my bf would call an "everyday bar", but it's nice for nights where you want to feel a little classier.

And for the SF newbies like me: as for being in the TenderNob, I don't think the trek is all that bad. Geary has pretty heavy foot traffic on Friday and Saturday nights so even if there are some not so fun stretches, it doesn't feel awful.
author: Alison C.

description:
Modern architectural cool.

This is what emanates from this little gem stuck so close to the stumbling drunks and crack addicts twitching away.  I had to make sure to step around certain things, my heels clicking on the hard pavement.

Okay, I must confess.  Most of my dates are coffee based.  Why?  So I don't end up biased due to being under the influence.  Everyone starts to look better.  Motions get diluted.  Words start to slur and so do actions.  A possible relationship ideal will suddenly become a one night stand. Trust me, I know.  

After my Campton experience, the man pulled through again and through persistence, we ended up at Rye.
