I've always heard of this place but have never been (just got out of a 8 month long relationship with a liar) and keeping a low profile from the social scene.  It was nice to dress up and go out on the arm of a very cute BR man (swoon, my type ;) Rye invokes memories of my several visits to the Pacific Northwest where the interiors are made of rich wood with muted steel accents.  My kind of place.

It was pretty busy and crammed with a good looking thirty-something crowd.  Most of the men dressed well (after work crowd) and the ladies well put together (no hoochie mamas, thank the lord).  I ended up with a Whiskey Sour which was more whiskey than I could handle and my date had Glenlivet.  Apparently, we were doing whiskey tonight.

The bartenders were slightly busy this night, so I recommend persistence and just being cool.  A smile doesn't hurt either :) For people who truly want a pull at their cancer sticks, Rye comes clean with a little area just for smokers (like the Hemlock Tavern).  

We'll be back, I can vote on that!
author: Miika M.

description: The taste of the drinks here are pungent.  The seating is dark so you can do anything you want with your hands inconspicuously.  However when the bathroom door opens, the bar turns into day time.  The seating arrangements is sufficient for the most part.  People tend to need to stand up after 10PM.
author: Byron L.

description: Love their drinks, well worth the price. It was easy for my gf and I to get a seat by the bar on a Friday night. The bartenders definitely are good mixologists. Almost as good as the bartenders in Beretta. Don't know if I love the crowd that much as I left around 10:30 pm but will definitely come back and try the other cocktails! Parking sucks too but there's one parking lot close which costs like 10 bucks.
author: Claudine V.

description:
Came here with a few friends to relax after a day in the city. What immediately struck us about this place was the great industrial feel with good mood lighting, excellent seating, and a clientele that was well dressed and casual at the same time. They do a good job of playing background music at a level such that people who want to dance can dance and people who want to chat can chat.

As the name implies, expect to have drinks that are mainly based whiskey based, but trust me; they're creative. I had a drink that infused lime, maple syrup, and whiskey in a way that allowed me to savor the flavor inherent in the whiskey, aided by a few notes of sweet and sour. My friends and I were able to find a seat quickly and lounge for a good two hours, never feeling pressured to fight our way to the bar or back to our booth on the side.

Yes, the Tenderloin may not be one of SF's best neighborhoods, but you should still make the seedy trek to try this great gem!
author: Mark T.

description:
This place always goes straight to my head. As in, I end up drinking a bunch of amazing drinks that all create an amazing ache in my head the next day. 

The drinks are just fabulous - even the peach julep that I'm sure is to blame for my current state of heinous unhappiness. The space is pretty sweet -- people playing pool, a great outside area (if small) and m ms on the bar. Life isnt terrible when you're drinking some super boozy drink and eating chocolate in SF

Bottom line: if you love good drinks, and you love not having to deal with people in jerk shirts... and you might want some decent thai (at osha thai) then this is a sweet destination.
author: Kelly S.

description:
There are two words that instantly come to mind when entering Rye. Effortlessly cool. Rye's like that kid in school who was the first one to wear Windsor knots in their tie when everyone else's was skinny, the person in the office who knew all about True Blood before it crossed over to UK shores, the fashion-forward types who wear Buddy Holly glasses and quiff their hair, the student at uni who doesn't listen to a band unless fewer than four people have heard of them.

You want to acquaint yourself with their Pimm's Cup, especially if you're a British visitor. It's a fantastically interesting take on the usual lemonade, strawberries, orange, cucumber and mint combo we get over in Blighty and is very, very tasty. And if you're a fan of sharp, tangy cocktails like myself, the Basil Gimlet will be a treat for the senses. And at Rye, you get entertainment too. Those mixologists are darn good at their jobs, and watching the way they smash the fresh herbs before throwing them in the glasses is a joy.

They take their work very seriously too. A particularly good-looking female bartender was muddling lemons and said irritatedly to her colleague, "These lemons suck!" alluding to their freshness and the difficulty they had in yielding. A lesser worker wouldn't have mentioned it or even realised. As for the decor of the place, think bare brick, think industrial seating, think minimalism - think a blank canvas for a group of flamboyant, creative young individuals to descend upon and call their own. Marvellous! Also the free Chex Mix lining the bar in bowls is tops, and there are M&Ms and sweets to munch on too. All just there. Free to take. That's SF, baby.
author: Emma Louise M.

description:
I checked out Rye about 5 months ago but never got a chance to write my two cents...

Totally unassuming from the outside, equally understated inside.

I remember having the Basil Gimlet, and some fruity drink (like a blackberry something perhaps?), and then after a while a couple more drinks, but I can't remember exactly what because I had been drinking at an event with an open bar prior to that...good thing I already had a buzz going in since drinks are so tasty at Rye that you inevitably end up drinking quite a bit, all the while depleting your wallet.

The drinks took forever to make.  The bartenders/"mixologists" spent what felt like at least 10 minutes per drink, and trying to get their attention was almost equally as frustrating.

The ambiance (if there was one) felt like I was in a very crowded, black room.  Very dim, very dark, very stuffy.

I'd like to go back and imbibe on more of Rye's delicious elixirs but I'm pretty impatient, and waiting 20-30 minutes to order and get each drink is a bit frustrating...
author: Laura S.

description: Pay attention to the name, people. Not a vodka bar. A bit smaller than I thought it would be, but a cool spot. Think, dark wood, dim lighting. I'm liking it. There is a sectioned smoking area, so that's a plus for u smokers. There was no live music or DJ the night we went, but I believe they do have it on the weekends. Thanks T & L for a wonderful night!
author: Nicole M.

description:
Forgive me if there are any typos in my review, but my ears are still ringing and making me a little dizzy.  Not a bad place, if you don't care in the least what your friends have to say, because it's SO DAMN LOUD.  Did they really have to turn the volume all the way up to eleven?  Couldn't it have rested happily at 9 or something similar conducive to conversation?  

Other than that, I kind of liked it.  The bartenders are SUPER nice, but they maybe need one more for a couple of hours during their busy times.  Their drinks are so time consuming that you have to wait a little longer than is customary for a locale that size.  Dig the basil gimlet, not a fan of the black & blue.  Like how they have PBR on the beer list.  I could have cared less about the monkey/smoking cage, but after reading yelp reviews, it made it easier to find the place.  

I like the ambiance, and if it wasn't for the noise, I'd probably go back.  Doubtful that I will anytime soon, since I also managed to run into an ex that was the break up from hell.  Seven years ago.  In an entirely different state.  Don't want a repeat of that, but I digress.

Go if you're young, have a plethora of money to spend on the drinks, and don't value your hearing.  Otherwise, if you're old and deaf like me, might want to search somewhere else for a good time.
author: Pam S.

description: I really like the artisan cocktails at this place. Rye is similar to other high end drink places such as Rickhouse and Burritt Room where the bartenders take their time with the yummy libations. The music here isn't too loud so one can actually conduct a conversation on one of their comfy chaises. Me likey :)
author: Alice W.

description:
Very nearly missed this place. It was dark out and the front of the bar blends right in to its surroundings. 

Best gimlet I've ever had (Basil Gimlet) and their version of Pimm's Cup is phenomenal. If you are a brown liquor drinker, then try the Buffalo Nickel. Root Beer Liquer, ginger syrup, and buffalo trace bourbon with some grate nutmeg and I believe a pinch of cloves. Knocked my socks off. 

Bar staff was extremely helpful and very friendly. The best part is watching them make the drinks. Real skill on display and I swear it makes the drink taste better. 

If you are in the Union Square neighborhood, this is a must.
author: Joshua S.

description:
Here is why Rye bar is awesome:

1. Some of the most innovative and freshly-made drinks in the city.
2. The nicest, flirtiest bouncer around.
3. An outdoor cage for the smokers.
4. A cool brick wall.
5. The smoothest sazerack I've ever had.

The only reason I withheld a star is because they get a bit crowded and the music is hit or miss. This does not however, stop me from heading there pretty darn often.
author: Shyla B.

description: The walk here is always interesting because of the location, but once you make it through the mean streets of the loin, you are in for a pleasant surprise. chill crowd and good drinks. The bartenders are always friendly and cocktail staff very knowledgable and fast. There's also a pool table if you are up for a game of billiard.
author: Azin D.

description:
Medium sized bar.

Huge selection of whiskey.

Very nice ambiance and decor (Not a dive).

They are known for their mixed drinks, but i'm just happy to find a place that looks nice and has a large selection whiskey.

Only think is that when the bar gets crowded service is super slow because everyone is ordering fancy drinks so the bar tenders take a lot of time with each order.
author: Steven F.

description:
Came here for a friend's birthday, i really like the venue really cool interior.

We ordered our drinks from a waitress and we waited for a long time and never got our drinks, so we decided to just leave.
author: Darnell L.

description:
Only the front half of the bar is accessible; there's a full step down into the main area. But there are normal-height tables and it isn't totally too dark to see, and a pool table of sorts, and the music doesn't suck and yet is not so loud that one can't hear a conversation.

While there is a criminal lack of beers on tap (What is it with these swanky cocktail bars and their lack of beer? Ever heard of a beer cocktail?) they do at least have some in bottles (which is better than some of these snotty bars). The bar goes low enough at one end that I can see over it and order. The bathroom is accessible and in pretty darn good shape for a bar. 

Rumor (aka the doorman at Bourbon and Branch) has it that this place is related in some way to the famous B&B, and it shows in the cocktail craft, quality and ingredient selection. Cocktail Snob partner was very pleased to drink and nerd out with the bartender about orgeat or something, and I had a decent drink or two before switching to beer. 

In a saner world, that's be a three-star bar. But there's such a lack of wheelchair-friendly bars at all that I'm being generous.
author: Anne K.

description:
Ah Rye, it's been so long. I was here when you opened up and I'm here now as you're getting out of pre-school.

Rye to me is the grown up spot for cocktails afterwork. You come here for a cucumber-basil-gimlets. They also have a bonus pool table in the back. 

Rye is not on the top of my list for places to find ladies, but if you're looking for high brow cocktails this is definitely the spot I would turn to.
author: Michael S.

description: Some of the best bartenders in the city hands down. U can just tell them what you're in the mood for and they'll concoct something amazing. Spacious, great ambiance, nice little patio area, all around great place.
author: Sheena J.

description:
Can't believe I am just now getting to this book mark!

What an incredible bar. The bartenders are amazing. The owners have another establishment, 15 Romolo, that could be the more mellow kid brother to this bar. Everyone will talk about the basil gimlet, but you can order virtually anything with your preferred spirit and enjoy yourself. 

The first time I came in here I ordered a Dogpatch, -- to this day, I love it more than life itself. I'll try other drinks occasionally because my friends are always giving me a hard time, but I always come back to the dogpatch. 

Pool table in the back, and they always have good lounge music on. If you get bored, hope across the street to RJ's for a laugh and a knife fight... seriously.
author: David N.

description: It was my first time at Rye and it wasn't a pleasant experience, their staff is very slow behind the bar and aren't very knowledgeable. It takes them forever to get to you while they are chatting with each other. I was very impresses, They get 2 stars for the bouncers smile and friendliness and their interior design. Parking is a pain around Gary street but that expected in that neighborhood.
author: Shadi K.

description:
4-stars for the drinks: Strong, gets the job done, and they have a wide selection of whisky/rum. 
3-stars for the prices: ~$10 however, I came for the Yelp Drinks Week so I was able to get them for $5-6 a glass (too legit). 

It's easy to miss the place on Geary because of it's tiny door. The inside looks cute with its SoHo-feel (brick walls, dimness, funky art). It's a lot smaller inside than I thought. The bar is split into two sections: one where there's a pool table and bar stools and the other half with more lounge-seats. If you're planning on coming with a huge group, I'd go someplace else. 

Not sure if the crowd is typically sparse here but both times I've stopped by, it was super empty... But seeing as the reviews below me talk about how "cracking" it is later on in the night, maybe next time I'll stay a little longer instead of bouncing out early.
author: D S.

description:
Ambiance: Four stars - I love the exposed brick and the ivy on the outside patio area.. everything about this place screams cozy and would be a great place to hang out on a cold rainy day. I went on a Monday and it wasn't busy at all, but there are these stools that are between tables and on a busy day, I could how it would be annoying to have to share with a different party. 

Drinks: I had the following- basically everything that was on the Yelp Drinks Menu 
Cold Whiskey Punch- For someone who doesn't like Whiskey this was a surprisingly good drink 
Rock & Rye- There was no description for this on the Menu, but it was something that was already pre-made and had cinnamon in it. It was pretty damn awful in my opinion. 
Blood & Sand- tasty, but not worth the $11 it would originally be without the Yelp discount. 

Overall the drinks are good, but way too pricey.. and therefore it gets three stars. 

Service: Three stars. It was a Monday so they probably weren't expecting to be as busy as they were, but everything was kind of a mess. It didn't look like they had any good way of keeping track of credit cards. They were all just sprawled out on the counter. I also know this because they didn't charge me for two drinks and took 10 minutes to find my card... I can't even imagine what it would look like on a Friday night. 

Neither bartenders were very social. One of them, when I asked her what was in a drink, she just handed me another menu and told me to look it up. They did their jobs, they gave me drinks, but if they are trying to be an upscale place, which I think they are, it's the little personal touches that are going to make a person come back.
author: Rona Y.

description:
Rye is a funny one. 

You know how sometimes you sense something is off but can't quite put your finger on it? I've been here a few times, like the bartenders, have enjoyed the carefully made cocktails, played pool, lounged in the best seat in the house, gotten tipsy off their toddy, el bano is not horrendous... but the vibe is a bit off. 

It may be feng shui. There aren't many seats at the bar, not much space when crowded to walk to the bathroom which is right off the pool table so beware being jabbed by cue sticks or errant balls from aggressive players... again, the inventive drinks are truly well executed, there's some smoky drink that comes with a can of Tecate for awesomeness sake, and I've had good times with friends but I don't know. My spidey senses tingle there. With the feeling that this place turns into a vampire lair or something when it get really late. I'm sure it doesn't but if you find out let me know.
author: Kim K.

description: Great bar with excellent drinks. The place is trendy and slammed when I have been there. Good option for staying near union square.
author: Jonah K.

description: One of my favorite cocktail bars/lounges in SF. Really great drinks and atmosphere. The music is usually pretty good as well.
author: Galen F.

description:
The bartenders are really great here. This was our only drinking stop on Cinco de Mayo when we happened to be in town. There was plenty of seating that night and I was happy to see that. I had the Casarello (sp?) and it was really good. It tasted like a orange creamsicle without tasting like it was made of crazy, nasty chemicals. The ambience is quite chill and I really enjoy that about Rye.

I'll definitely visit Rye again when I'm in town.
author: Alyssa A.

description:
SERVICE:
Bartenders are nice. Offered a lime with my tecate, because she likes it better with one


ATMOSPHERE:
Not bad, chill place, has a pool table, nice loungey area, a small bar. Place is limited for seating, but atmosphere is over nice yet casual.
author: Angela L.

description:
Why is the tenderloin considered 'ghetto'? Maybe I don't grasp the seriousness of it because I've only seen it at night. Maybe I'm too easily charmed by all the old architecture. But, whatever. Rye has a cool ass modern front door.

Obviously, I'm not from SF. I visit family here and they took me to this bar when I asked for a place that serves interesting cocktails. WOW. LOVED. You go now! Seriously, I still crave that sweetish cucumber peppery drink of mine. I forgot it's name, though, because I was so thoroughly buzzed from just one. I can say it wasn't whiskey based and I'm quite the light weight. It was clear liquid and came in a glass. Help much?
author: Jackie N.

description: Love the moscow mule, hate how long it takes to get a drink. I get it, they are mixologist and not bartenders, but still, it just sucks how long it takes,
author: Arlenne D.

description:
If I wish there was a bar in London, that is in San Francisco it would be Rye. This place is possibly my favourite drinking establishment in CA. From the Basil Gimlet that was pushed into my tired hand from the moment I walked in, to the relaxed vibe and couches, friendly and knowledgeable service the the amount of space that the bar has. Everything screams cool and wonderful to me.

Do they play music? I don't even know, I'm normally enjoying the cocktails to much to notice. Rye, pretty please can you come to my city? I promise to visit you every week, my friends will love you, I'm sure of it. This could be the start of a fabulous relationship!
author: Lizzie S.

description: One of my favorite bars/lounges! Everything from the interior to the carefully crafted cocktails. Absolutely love it! Great for a moscow mule during the summer or a hot toddy during the fall. Cozy and dark atmosphere. I like the outdoor cage like area, but unfortunately hate cigarette smoke so I usually have to hold my breath or suffocate anytime I have to be out there w/friends. All in all, love this place.
author: Natassia S.

description:
I was looking forward to celebrating a friends birthday party here. I'm not sure why, the service was horrible. The decor was nice looking but I couldn't believe the service. I sat at the bar for 15 minutes waiting, I had the older female bartender completely ignore me. I was pretty irritated with the whole situation and had my boyfriend try to attempt to order our drinks. He was also ignored. Trying to get her attention by asking her about the drinks she was preparing for others,  to spark a conversation and try to get her attention.. Still no service. I'm not sure what the problem was. We finally came to the conclusion that, we were the minority. 

I'm really disgusted.
author: L F.

description:
I love this little spot even though you can easily miss it.  Located on Geary right before it gets too sketchy.  Parking is a bitch but don't drink and drive anyway.  The drinks are good but definitely not strong.  I appreciate that my Greyhound always tastes like it's made with fresh squeezed grapefruit juice, even though I've only ever seen him pour it out of a bottle.  But hey, there's a bowl of fruit on the bar so I'm assuming they just bottled the stuff themselves. 

The folks who work here are nice and friendly.  I appreciate a bartendar who makes eye contact and tells you he'll be with you shortly when it's packed and says it with a smile.  The folks who come here aren't your douchey marina type (yes, stay on that side please) so it's always a good vibe in there.  I like the chairs/couches but one of the reasons why I dig this place is their enclosed-ish smoking patio thing.  I know smoking is terrible for you and that I really should quit, but I love how I don't have to go outside and stand on the sidewalk for a ciggy break, because that almost always invites unwanted attention.  Whoever thought of this idea, kudos to you!
author: Sally T.

description:
I heart your basil gimlets.

Twice so far and have never had my experience be short of good fun with the bartenders. This time, I had to hit on the bartender, John, for an SF Food Street Challenge:

"What's the difference between a hamburger and a blowjob?"
 
......"hmmm, the buns?"

(OMG, he was supposed to not guess!)

"Good point, but why don't we do lunch and figure it out?"

I won my drink, the classic The Last Word made with Chartreuse. 

Dear John,
I will be back again for more!
author: Alita M.

description:
Drinks are great here.  The Flash (gin, muddled kiwi, cucumber, sugar cane and lemon juice) is really refreshing, and the White Diamonds (rye, cocchi, maraschino) was also good.  Would be better if it was a bit bigger or had more seating, but I guess that's how it is.

Bartenders are also very friendly.
author: Ken L.

description:
I was in San Francisco for a mere 7 days. I went to some 30 different bars during that week, but somehow, managed to become a "regular" at Rye.

My first night in town, Rye was stop numero uno. I was smitten. Nothing really stands out as special enough here to write home about, yet somehow, I found myself coming back night after night. Whether pulling up a chair at the bar and sipping on some carefully concocted cocktails, lounging on the couches debating world politics, or going nuts on the patio pretending to only speak Spanish (which I don't), every night here was unique and special and chocked full of hazy memories which I will cherish.

The bartenders have this attitude that is fantastic and unlike any I would find in my hometown for sure. No southern hospitality, just this sort of "I'm-not-gonna-take-any-shit-from-you-get-your-hands-away-from-my-garnishes" air about them that I found amusing and simply, cool. But seriously, don't help yourself to their garnishes. A little birdie told me you can get kicked out for that...
author: Kay T.

description:
Oh Rye. What a cool place to get a tasty drink with fitting names and create an air of coolness. The dimly lit bar is a nice touch. It's enough to let you see the face of the person you're talking to. Like it matters after a few drinks anyway.... hah. 

I recently tried out their Pimm's Cup and what was named... I kind of forgot what the name of it was because my vision was cloudy from having such a good time. Hah, but I vaguely remember the drink being called something along the lines of "Scorned Wife" or "Scorned Lover", either way the bitch was wrongfully scorned. But the outcome was totally delicious. These bartenders or, excuse me, mixologists have got their shit down to an art. If you're even the least bit unsure, these guys will treat you well and whip you up something that would probably suit your tastes.

Even on a Saturday night the place still had enough space to walk around and chit chat with friends, hang around the pool table, and come back just in time for your specialty cocktail. The music isn't too loud and it's a great place to lounge, especially in the smoker's den. It's a great hangout and every time I hang out at Rye, I definitely have a good time. Just come in a bit earlier so you can have some prime seating at the bar. But even then they have a server ready to take drink orders to you, too. So no need to fiercely guard that prime corner booth you've been looking at and finally got. Just sit back, relax, and tell me what the correct name of the Scorned lady drink is.
author: Leslie K.

description:
Basil Gimlets are off the hook. I learned that here. I also learned that I drink them too fast. And don't have the patience to wait in line for another or the willingness to pay $10 for another. 

The drinks are all really great ,and the bartenders are knowledgeable and can make you something creative as well. Just ask! I really loved the ambiance, the people and bartenders were all really nice, and the drinks as mentioned before, were amazing. Definitely excited I went here after hearing so many good things, and definitely want to come back here on a weekday night.
author: Lauren S.

description:
Not the biggest fan of this place. 

I came here through the recommendation of a friend who said it was a great hang out, one of his favorites to be exact. But it felt like such a yawn worthy place.

It feels like they might have been trying to go for that cool bar you go to with your friends that would be "your hangout" but in the end it just has the same feel as another bar down the street. Nothing special.

I was told I came on a bad night. Whatever that means, the feel of the place was blah too, the waiter at the bar not too friendly and the people seemed quiet. I don't even remember the music. 

If you're a bar in SF, sorry I'm expecting something more than another sterile, cookie cutter bar. Too bad I was really looking forward to finding something good.

Wouldn't be a place that I'd rule out forever but don't get your hopes up high, all in all nothing special.
author: Sunny D.

description:
Excuse me, Hot Buttered Rye - we have never met until last night...twice, but you are the definition of pleasure in a short & stout clear glass mug. If I could stalk you on Foursquare, I would.

xoxo,

Krystha
author: Krystha B.

description: Nice cozy bar in the TL that's ideal for Happy Hour drinks.  Like everyone has said, the basil gimlet is delicious.  Great taste with a stiff after-bite that is not too powerful.  My friend had the cucumber gimlet which she said was fantastic too.  However, I don't like cucumbers so i thought it was meh.
author: Alex G.

description:
The basil gimlets here are perhaps the best mixed drink I've had in a bar EVER... 

The bartenders are also very nice and somehow manage to coordinate amongst themselves so that even when it's packed, I didn't have to wait longer than two minutes to place an order (And how do they manage to fit three people behind the relatively small bar without getting in each others' way?!).

I'll definitely be back.
author: Dani D.

description:
Another great cocktail bar. When you're there, you don't feel like you're in the Tenderloin because it's so classy and upscale (yet still casual) inside. We went on a Sunday night, so there were no crowds and we got to enjoy a quiet night of chatting and enjoying our drinks.

The Basil Gimlet and The Flash are two excellent drinks. The Basil Gimlet is a delicious mixture of gin, basil, lime juice, and agave nectar. Although it tastes sweet and can't taste much of the alcohol, it sure is there. I think I might like The Flash more, which had gin, kiwis, lemon juice, and cucumber. You can really taste the cucumber and the kiwi after you take a sip and it tastes very fresh. The Flash wasn't as strong as the Basil Gimlet. I loved both though because I really like gin.

A big plus here was that they serve free snacks! One cup full of m&m's and peanut m&m's and another one full with party mix. Yum yum :) They were awesome.

The inside was really nice as well. I really liked the lounge area, looked very nice and comfy.
author: Sachiko K.

description:
Oh my god.  I have to stop going here.  It has only resulted in having tastier & tastier cocktails & buying fancier & fancier ingredients to make them with.

Witness Birds of a Feather (don't get the name, but that's beside the point).  I'd put this one right up there with something from Bourbon & Branch - definitely one of the best cocktails I'd ever had.  We got the recipe from the cocktailist (bartender just doesn't do this man justice) and are ready to start attempting them at home.

After 4 fancy cocktails & multiple tastes of several different interesting bourbons & liqueurs, he charged us $32.  I mean that's pretty much like getting a free drink.  Plus all the tastes.  We tipped him generously.

Also, I won't actually stop going here.  Ever. :)
author: Angela B.

description: Rye was one of my favorite bars when I lived in the Tenderloin. Yes, the cocktails are very pricey. But you get what you pay for. The mixologists are very skilled and take time to create each drink. This is the first place I ordered a whiskey sour where they use frothy egg whites and mint leaves - delicious. They have unique techniques, garnishes, and even glasses and ice cubes.
author: Natalie R.

description: Great drinks! And I love the smoking patio! Try as many drinks on their menu as you can. They are really delicious!
author: Michelle L.

description:
I had been wanting to try Rye for awhile and was a bit disappointed by the experience. The place itself is really cozy and intimate, it seems more like a wine bar atmosphere. I was not impressed by the weird music or the drink selection. Thankfully I was in good company and Bourbon & Branch was right around the corner to rescue the evening.

Pros:
*Lots of seating
*Cool atmosphere

Cons:
*Bad music
*Bad drink selection

Tips:
*Don't order the prosecco - it tasted like the bottle had been open for months

Bottom line, don't make Rye a first stop or even a last stop in a night - the jury's still out on whether it's even worthy of a stop at all.
author: H T.

description:
Rye is a great little bar with a pool table ans some amazing drinks in the Tendernob area. Their best drinks are the Old Cuban and the Basil Gimlet in my opinion. The bar seems to specialize in old school classic cocktails. 

This is a great spot to go to with friends too, because it is not overly noisy to the point where you can't carry on a conversation. My only complaint is that the drinks are a little small and a little pricey, but it's quality over quantity I guess. I would highly recommend Rye and definitely will be back soon.
author: Michael C.

description:
Great place to chill, nice atmosphere, and serious drinks.  The bartender's are great to ask advice on some fancy drinks here. 

Oldschool 80's music, pool table in the back, and really nice doorman are pluses too.
author: Yingjue C.

description:
When it comes to cocktail culture in the city, few bars can boast the history and prowess of Rye. Their reputation is built on the skilled, cool-as-cucumber barkeeps who shake with a fury, and stock nothing but the most luscious of fruit and finest of spirits. Can you get anymore California in a glass than Hangar One with fresh pressed citrus and St Germain with a cardboard straw?!    

My reservation with Rye is that it fails to cultivate a real vibe. I mean, I'm not going to turn down my nose at at decent looking folks air kissing and playing wink eye, but I'd rather gaze upon the Brian Barneclo or take silly pictures of my friends behind bars in the smoking cage.
author: Ligaya T.

description:
I liked Rye.  We went on a Friday night and it was busy.  Ordering at the bar can take a bit if its packed, but they also have servers.  Bartenders and severs are nice and fast.

All their drinks are really handcrafted without attitude (even a mojito). Cool industrial style decor.  The smokers pen is really sorta funny, resembles a cage, but thats probably applicable.  Anyway, cool art, good music, good location, good crowd.  Worth checking out for sure.
author: Bryan L.

description:
i spent a full day in napa wine tasting and then had dinner at ad hoc...where more alchol was consumed...arrived at rye late evening...not that i needed any more etoh, but it was a special ocassion...i was meeting up with an old friend i hadn't seen since college...

it was a fun night catching up, people watching, and trying all the delicious cocktails...especially the basil gimlet...i love that they serve hangar one...a locally made vodka...
author: Amanda S.

description:
I live close to Rye and I absolutely love this place.  By far one of my favorite bars in the city. I feel pretty good naming this my neighborhood bar I frequent whenever I can. Oh, and  I'm bringing back bullet points for all the positive things for this review...get excited...

* They make delicious specialty cocktails
* The Old Fashioned, one of the best in the city, get's it's own bullet point.
* Sazerac, "..."
* Cool layout
* Friendly and cool bartenders that know how to make amazing drinks.
* Consistently awesome music
* A random pool table
* Oh and one time they had this whiskey with just a moustache on the bottle.  It was hilarious.

So all in all, I love Rye.  Writing this review has reminded me I haven't been in a while actually.  So now I'm going back this week.

:) :) :) :) :) :) :) :) :) :) :) :) :) :) :) :) :)

17 smiley faces above.  Read previous review.  Have a good one.
author: John R.

description:
Since this establishment and I share the same name I can vouch that we have another thing in common...we're both Awesome. 

If you're not looking for a club spot or a typical bar then Rye is a cool joint to chill. I had a going away party here and I couldn't have found a better and convenient spot to host.  The atmosphere, music, people, and drinks didn't disappoint. 

The Outdoor area is a good outlet for you smokers but then again I felt like a caged laboratory animal shouting out vulgar obscenities at people passing by.

The only problem is the parking, it can be problematic and you'll be doing more circles around the block than the Indy 500. 

The best thing is that Osha's is RIGHT next store! So if you have a craving for some Duck Fried Rice you can literally crawl next store and fill your stomach full of some Thai food minus the lady boys.

So if you're looking for good times, good drinks and good music come to Rye where the beer flows like wine...where beautiful women instinctively flock like the salmon of Capistrano.
author: Rye N.

description:
This is my favorite bar in San Fransisco.  I travel for work often, and it is really nice to find a bar where the staff and patrons are friendly.  Sitting alone at a bar where the people are rude or standoffish is not very much fun.  

The selection of whiskeys is really nice, and the bartenders are extremely knowledgeable and talented.  My Manhattan and Old Fashioned were both tasty, and when I requested a surprise I got the best Whiskey Sour I have ever tasted.  Not to mention that this bar was one of the more affordable bars I've patronized in the city.

All in all, I don't think you could go wrong by visiting on any night of the week.  Go early for a spot at the bar, however.  Also, you should ask for one of the more exclusive small-batch Ryes.  For a non-Californian, the options were a real treat.
author: Blaise C.

description:
Free pool, great quality Old Fashioned and a glass of peanut m&m's... what more could you ask?!

The quality of the drinks is pretty tremendous, and the mixologists are a pleasure to watch in action. They certainly take their time to make the drinks special, and you can pick at the M&Ms while you wait.

A great shout!
author: Ben C.

description: Great cocktails with fresh ingredients. I've been here for parties, so the crowds didn't bother me, but I can see the bar being a tad crowded if I was with a smaller group. There are a few open spaces, which helps. Fun place to go out and range of casual to out-on-the-towners
author: Aki N.

description:
Pretty awesome drinks! A bunch of gimlets that taste amazing. As everyone said the drinks are expensive but they are also delicately made and strong enough to lay down a horse.

Only complaint I have is that the bar is way too small for such a place. The wait for drinks can take 30 minutes, but the environment is so chill and relaxed. Even with a full house the bar never feels crowded or cramped!
author: Jason T.

description:
Anytime you get a friendly, professional doorman who genuinely smiles at you and doesn't hassle you, it's a good thing. And that was my experience at Rye on Friday night (at 10:45, no less).

Mostly a professional-looking crowd. Maybe late 20's-40. Not particularly good-looking, but at least put-together and amiable.

Love the look of the place, although the pool table at the end of the bar is awkwardly-placed and anyone playing a game typically has to worry about hitting patrons with their cue. 

Drinks were standard lounge prices. Tasty and potent. Seems like a nice place to start off an evening and then jump somewhere else.
author: Sebastian L.

description: Drinks are $10 and I like how they accept credit cards. Doesn't put a limit on how many drinks I can order depending on how much cash I bring. I tried the basil gimlet and it's on the sweeter side for me but I know other people who had it loved it. I wasn't sure what to order when I came here because the drink I wanted was out of stock. I told the server what I like: Bourbon base not too sweet and I tend to like any drinks with an egg white. She suggested their sour whisky. I was a little hesitant because usually my sour whisky is on the sweeter side but she said theirs isn't too sweet and there's an egg white. Some people thought this was on the stronger side but I thought it was good but the people who thought it was strong were the basil gimlet drinkers. Apparently my drink was too manly for them.
author: Victoria C.

description:
I went here after my Bourbon & Branch experience (felt kinda like a loser drinking my drink in the corner alone there)---I needed a pick-me-up, and Rye totally fit the bill.

This chic and chill lounge was definitely more my style.  The ambiance was more open and my style.  The bartenders were friendly, and the crowd seem more casual.

I saw lot of drink options here, but I decided to go for the special:  "Afar Cocktail (cachaca, lemon, yellow chartreuse, pineapple juice, & lime slice garnish).  I have an affinity for all things Brasil, so if cachaca's involved I'm in (besides, the bartender recommended it).

All in all a solid experience here [4.5-stars], and I'd definitely go here again, solo or otherwise!
author: Corey G.

description: High end cocktails, great daily specials, fun atmosphere, cool little smoking patio.  Only drawbacks: kinda expensive (not bad for SF), no comprehensive whiskey list!  It's hard to believe that with the killer whiskey selection they have, there's no list...you have to navigate to the seats behind the bar and look through the glass and see if you can decipher the backs of the bottles.  Great bar, I go here all the time despite its shitty tenderloin location
author: Ryan H.

description:
Owner John, a silver fox version of Ethan Hawke, mixed me a couple of slick blood orange caipirinhas earlier this week. There were no bowls of treats this time around (*tear*) but the music was in awesome homage to my hometown (Metric, Junior Boys, Kevin Drew) and the drinks were flowing! 

Note: please invest in better straws. The environmentally friendly/biodegradable straws are just that: they biodegrade when moistened, which as you can imagine is not pleasant considering their job is to be immersed in liquid. Since I don't have pica (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pica_%28disorder%29), I didn't appreciate a mouthful of paper in my mouth near the end of my beverage.
author: Kat F.

description:
Kick ass drinks! I came here last night on a Yelp drink crawl with a few friends. Of course we had to try each of the special Yelp drinks. I ordered the basil gimlet with vodka cuz I'm not a big gin fan (I had a few too many bad experiences ODing on gin & tonics in the past). The bartender was very nice & encouraged me to try it with gin, explaining how the flavors meld nicely with gin & not so much with vodka. Sold! Yep, she was right, that was one good drink. 

The Fireside was also a favorite of mine. I think I liked it even more than the gimlet. For the life of me I can't remember what was in it so you'll just have to take my word for it. Luckily my friend Holly B. wasn't too fond of the gimlet so we switched. 

I just tried a sip of the Dogpatch, it was strong & I'm pretty sure it kicked my friend Brian W.'s butt. 

This place is close to work so I will definitely be back!
author: Erin S.

description: Best drinks in the tenderloin in my opinion. Bartenders are also friendly and accommodating if you want to try something new.
author: Drew L.

description:
Have to agree with the other million reviews on the cocktails.  It's not a lot of drink.. but they get you.  They sort of remind me of "jungle juice" from college frat parties..basically taste delicious but have quite a bit of alcohol .. which was how they got the freshman girls drunk.. lol.

Stars:
1. cocktails - fresh fruit, taste good ..and gives u a nice buzz
2. the bouncer - HELLA nice and hooked it up for me last night! didnt get ur name, but ur fabulous
3. fast service at the bar, and the chick who served me was patient and whatever she made tasted good. a version of the strawberry gimlet i think...
4. pool table!

The only con was that the music wasnt very loud.. u could barely hear it so you couldnt realy dance..and there wasnt really anywhere to dance.  Overall had a good time there -- will be back for more cocktails!
author: Melody T.

description:
Like most reviews,  the basil gimlet is supposedly their signature drink, so of course I wanted to taste it to see what all the fuss was about.  The basil gimlet was refreshing and our bartender(I think his name is Kyle) mixed` it with the right amount of alcohol to give me a good buzz throughout the night.  
As far as the establishment itself, the place is ultra-sophisticated and surprisingly it's located in the Tenderloin.  We went on a Wed night during happy hour so the place was pretty much dead, but who cares when your with good company and gimlets are only $7.  Beware cuz parking can be a b*tch in that area.  
I actually cannot wait to come back here again, cause those darn basil gimlets definitely hit the spot.
author: Emmett B.

description:
Okay - I'm drunk. But this place has excellent ambience and drinks. Don't ask for a Red Bull vodka (they don't have Red Bull). Instead, order the basil gimlet.

This place is perfect, especially if you were as scared away by Ambassador as I was. A relaxed yet refined setting - just go find seating on the lower floor, to the right of the entrance.

Thumbs up and beyond! I want another basil gimlet.
author: Lola M.

description: Very nice cocktails & staff, just not my kind of place. We've dropped in a couple of times, and don't really feel like it's anyplace special. Crowd seems to be dolled up techsters. It's nice to have them in the neighborhood for diversity, and to make it feel safer, very trendy décor.
author: Chelse B.

description:
We went there to meet with our friends for happy hour on a Saturday night. Very nice and modern interior design. Though there aren't a lot of seatings, the place is spacious enough to host enough customers. 

I heard that their whiskey selection is decent, hence, a few good cocktails with whiskey in it. I tried their wine, it was pretty decent as well. 

It wasn't too noisy to talk in, so we could still have a pretty good chat during happy hour. 

It's a place to hang out and have some drinks and lounge, no food is served though, which can be a minus. 

The neighborhood has quite a lot of cafes and restaurant. So it might be good to have food in other places in the neighborhood, and then have drinks at Rye.
author: Kai Y.

description: Solid drinks and friendly bartenders. I took a $20 uber to this place based on Yelp reviews and wasn't disappointed.
author: Jason I.

description: A top notch cocktail lounge that doesn't get crowded on school nights.  Beautifully decorated inside and tons of space to chill with your friends while drinking such great libations as "A Woman Scorned".
author: Chad T.

description:
Talent.
In a glass. Shaken. Stirred. Sipped. Savored.

Bartenders know what's up whether it's on the menu or on a whim. They'll make it to your liking or take it down themselves.

"A Woman Scorned" - fruit-forward but not too sweet.
"Added Bonus" - the Y chromosome to the "Woman Scorned". amazing. round two. three. four. Worth repeating
Whim of the bartender - always recommended

A spacious industrial-chic interior but somewhat small-group seating areas. The crowd ranged from hipsters to professionals, mostly in the early 30-range.

Dig it. Sip it. Savor it. See you there.
author: Alissa A.

description:
The Rye knows how to serve up a mean cocktail. Too bad I wasn't in any shape to drink a stiff one last night. I had to go the beer route to ensure that I'd wake up somewhat coherent today. But, thankfully, my tablemates were in better condition and were able to order a couple of rounds of a mean-ass drink called The Flash. My better half who was left behind in the Minneapple to care for our little one would have thoroughly enjoyed the Flash, as he's quite the gin man.

What I especially like about this spot is that it's not all flashy and pretentious, screaming "we are a cocktail bar." Rather, it looks like a lovely dive-ish spot that then wows you with its fantastic goods.

Ah, MSP could learn alot from you.
author: sarah p.

description: Tasty, creative cocktails and friendly service. Strong points, for sure, but I can't say I'll make this a regular drinking spot due to awkward seating and loud music. There aren't many comfortable places to sit and the few that exist are in a loud area or the outdoor smokers "cage".
author: Brett B.

description:
This place gets crowded!  It has seating areas that are cozy and proper for maybe a party of no more than 8.  It has an outdoor smoking area like a cage, clean bathrooms and pool table too.  The waitress was really nice, but the service was slow.  Their credit card machine was defunct later that night so they made me sign a random piece of paper with the bartender's scribbles on it.   They also charged my bff twice for a round of drinks that was $60 (charged $120!).  

I am now a fan of wine cocktails.  I had the French 75 (*Plymouth gin, fresh lemon juice, organic sugar and Prosecco float - was a bit sour), but had three Yellow Bicycles later (*St. Germain Elderflower Liqueur, Yellow Chartreuse and Druisian Prosecco).  They were damn good!  Too bad (or good fortune) that they only offer two kinds.  Only $9 - strong but small glass.  Just the way I like it.  Mixing two Patron shots was not a good idea, but I still felt fine the next morning since the wine cocktails were good quality.  I had a sip of the bloody mary style cocktail and it was ok.  

I would come back for the drinks, but not in a large crowd.  I wasn't coordinated enough for Thai food (plus I just came back from Thailand then) so we walked down the street for some pizza.  It was good!

*Just in case you were wondering, I do not have exceptional memory, but took a picture of the drink menu.  ha!  =)
author: Chris L.

description:
I'll say this, it seems like kind of a nice upscale place, but I wasn't really feeling the vibe here.

Bartender did his job, but wouldn't really pay attention to me till after serving several people that had been there after me.

Shot of Yamazaki 12, $18 dollars. For an 18 dollars a pop, I expect a bit more attention. I cannot comment on the mixed drinks, although I'm sure they're good. I'm giving it a 3 star rating because I didn't give it the full benefit, although what I experienced I didn't like.
author: Steven C.

description: I guess I came on a bad night or maybe I didn't look like a person that would come into this place but the service sucked tonight. The lady bartender with the little shorts was standing right in front of me and just ignored me as she continued to make toothpick snacks with the bar garnishes. When she finally asked me what was I drinking I asked for a lemon drop cocktail. Easy drink to make took her ten minutes to do and I watched her shake hands and hug. A bunch of people before she even tended to my drink. Maybe the guy that started talking to me was he guy friend but please give me my drink. I like this place just not whoever she was.
author: Aja C.

description:
OK. So here is the break down:
- minus 2 Stars for Jon and the nasty brunette bar tender on 4/10 at 11:30pm.  I spoke to him TWO weeks before my Husbands birthday to arrange for a table reservation at which point he said it was on the books and the table would be waiting for us when we got there.  I then left him  a message two day before to confirm.  

We arrive on this last Saturday night and I ask the Brunette bartender if Jon is available she snaps back at me "its his night off" and walks away from me,  I get her attention again to ask if she knows about a table reservation and she bites my head off again and says "talk to the cocktail waitress" and walks off again. 

I head to the area with the tables and spot the waitress and she nicely tells me she knows nothing about our table but will figure something out for us. She did end up getting us a table, but come on Jon!! You totally flaked out on me.   And the super rude bartender alone will keep me from ever coming back.
author: Elizabeth K.

description:
Sunday night, raining, 7pm. About 8 people in the bar. 

I was happy to duck in here from the rain (and from the crazy guy hunkered in the doorway of Osha Thai who started following me, hollering threats of violence). The neighborhood is not the greatest to be walking around at night in the rain.

Once inside the well-lit calming safety of Rye, I ordered the Basil gimlet, the Flash, and the Carovello. Drinks were well made and tasted good. The basil gimlet was good although I'm not quite sure what the fuss is about...the Carovello is the drink I would go back for; it had much more complex flavor and texture (from frothed egg white) and was really well balanced.

Things that happened that I wish wouldn't have:

* I was asked to pay up after the first round. I like the offer to start a tab. Asking to pay up after the first round means "you're done after this. right?"

*The menu was whisked away after every order. I don't like to have to keep asking for it. Also tends to mean, "you're done. right?"

* The bartender chucking empty bottles REALLY hard into the bin (especially when there's no one in there). Very jarring and unpleasant.

These are not enough to keep me from coming back. Although next time I will keep one eye over my shoulder for angry hunkered osha thai violence guy.
author: Ted M.

description:
(Cue Britney Spears voice over)

Dimme Dimme More, Dimme More, Dimme Dimme More

Dimme Dimme More, Dimme More, Dimme Dimme More

I think that the specials board advertising for the "Dimme Moore" cocktail was really referencing Demi Moore but I read into it entirely different because all I could think was GIVE ME MORE. They won't have this drink on the menu but if they remember what it is when you mention it, you'll absolutely love this delightful concoction.
author: Julia N.

description: The basil gimlet ROCKs (just sweet enough with a kick), and the bartender was friendly, quick and helpful - 'nough said!  :)
author: Maile N.

description:
Area is a bit sketch but if you're willing to make the trek out there to Ambassadors, Rye is just right across the street.  Came here on a Saturday night and it was already pretty crowded around 11pm.

The wait for a drink is horrendous.  Each drink took about 30 minutes of waiting time.  Rye has super fancy concoctions and with 3 bartenders I can see why it takes them FOREVER to shake one up.

I had about 4 Basil Gimlets and I was done for the night.  The basil gimlet is really good.  Taste like a mojito and very refreshing.

I would come back to this place.  Friendly crowd, decent bathroom, place to sit (once the crowd died down around 1am).  Just wish there was some music.
author: Terry D.

description:
I have to admit, I don't consider myself a fan of rye cocktails. When my friend told me we'd be going somewhere that specializes in them I wasn't all that excited! However, this ended up being my favorite spot I hit up while in San Francisco. 

The atmosphere was great - quiet enough to hold a conversation. We got their early and sat at the large booth in front , a perfect vantage point for people watching and getting optimum service. 

The basil gimlet (made with gin) didn't sound all that special but it was flawless. Smooth as silk, well rounded, tasty. I could have sat at Rye for 3 hours, racked up a $100 bar tab , and drank these all night. Alas the others in my party saw this as more of a quick stop than a destination. I will definitely be back for more basil gimlets next time I'm in town!
author: Blair B.

description:
What a miserable place to spend a Saturday night.  

First, there was a wait to get in.  Inside a jukebox blasted painful music so loud I had trouble hearing anything else.  A clever smoker cage meant smokers didn't have to wait in line to get a nicotine fix, but also that the whole place wound up reeking of cigarettes.  

The wait for drinks was interminable, and the drinks themselves varied in quality from not-very-good to undrinkable.  My last cocktail made everyone at my table make a face usually associated with five-year-olds and brussel sprouts.  

A friend who lives nearby says it's a different place during the week.  I hope so.  I couldn't wait to leave.
author: Dana S.

description:
The fabulous, vivacious and far-cooler-than-you Beth Spotswood celebrated her Soberversary party at Rye last night (one year drink-free; go Beth!). The party goers raised our liquor-filled glasses to her, and my, what scrumptious cocktails they were.

My Manhattan--followed by a Rock and Rye Manhattan--was exquisite. Hand-stirred by a man who knows what he is doing. They really know how to craft a cocktail in this joint.

The space is great! Pool table gets them bonus points, and there is plenty of room in there. It's dark, slick (but not too slick) and comfortable. There is a smoking cage for your cancer-getting friends, which is a nice thing to have. Keeps the doors free of groups and smoke, and your friends don't feel so ostracized. 

Oh, and the staff concocted a special drink just for our now-sober friend: The Beth 2.0. A spirit-less delight, to be sure.

I can't wait to return to Rye. I want that Rock and Rye in my mouth again, pronto.
author: Brittney G.

description:
I was with a group for a bachelor party and we stopped into Rye. It was great. The waitress was perky and fun and we all felt at home. The music was a bit loud for me, but then again I am over 40 so what do you expect?

Drinks (at least the ones I had) are insane. Yum yum. Very clean bathroom and their customers on this particular Saturday night were well behaved. Also, there is much more space compared to some of the more cramped bars in this part of town.

Give Rye a try.
author: Manu S.

description:
For mixology and atmosphere, Rye absolutely gets 5 stars.  $10 gets you a specialty cocktail like the "Added Bonus" - bourbon, maple syrup, basil, and whipped with egg whites.  My friends' cocktails were also all delicious - most notable was the kiwi and cucumber number with gin - amazing how those two green plants made such beautiful bedfellows.

It's a subdued atmosphere, good for a date, or a small group of people (lots of tables in the back).  I wouldn't promote it as a great place to meet people, though maybe it is.  The smokers have their own cage inset outside some glass doors - very interesting, especially set upon this part of Geary.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
I came here during Yelp Drinks Week to try the basil gimlet.  It was pretty good & the bartenders are nice.  My main complaint is that the space is really small, especially around the bar, so it feels too crowded.  There isn't a whole lot of seating either.

I think I would try this place on a weekday.  The crowd was just too overwhelming to really enjoy the drinks.
author: Amanda N.

description:
The cocktails are sooo good.  Totally worth the price.

The atmosphere is not me, but I can totally understand why this place is so popular... Let's just say, in my experience, it's a great place for singles.  Next time, I'll make sure I put on something that can pass for an engagement ring.
author: Lauren R.

description:
I met some friends here for happy hour.  Atmosphere was pretty cool but the music got kinda reggae at some point.  Bartenders were friendly, other clientele mainly looked like single IT guys?

The drinks were all really good and carefully made (my friend was handed a different beer than he ordered though) and the price was right for happy hour.

I guess if I ever find myself in that area for happy hour I'd go back.
author: Alison C.

description:
The basil gimlet did me in. 

Came here a few months back with a friend visiting from out of town. She's the one that actually recommend this place after scouring yelp. Chill atmosphere. Able to carry a conversation. 

Definitely coming back. 

Just have to pace myself better next time. :)
author: Janelle L.

description: Drinks at Rye are always good. My favorite is their strawberry basil gimlet with vodka instead of gin. It's dive bar fun without the smell and trendy without the stuck up bartenders. It's small and intimate for date night but not so good for big groups.
author: Jeanne C.

description: Went there last Saturday and all the bartenders were so nice! The ambiance of the bar is very cool and I had a really great time. I will definitely come back
author: Antoine F.

description: I like this trendy joint... we stopped in with a crew of 10 girls for a bachelorette party... not the best place to go for one but definitely a sweet spot nonetheless!  My friend ordered me their signature drink the one that is one the wall their signature beverage... something with Rye Whiskey obviously... it was killer and nice and strong.  The place was packed and the line for the bar was 4 people deep... I'm just glad my friend Dole is aggressive.  She is adoleable.
author: Shiho F.

description:
The crowd can be a bit hit or miss.  Sometimes young, hip, well-dressed, but sometimes...too Justin Timberlake (does that make sense?).  I've been here when it's crowded.  When you have to murder someone to get a drink.  I don't condone murder.  Been here when it's sparse as well.  Not the ideal, let's get drunk and party spot.  More of a chillendo spot.  Drink before drankin spot.

Atmosphere is classy, dimly lit, relatively small.  Bartenders are kind.  Sometimes slow.  There is an outdoor area where the smokers commiserate.  Sometimes seems like people picked this spot to have their heart-to-heart convo.

One time a well dressed 'mature'/'well-aged' lady popped by our table.  She was sotally tober.  Wanted to taste my friend's cocktail.  He obliged.  I told him not to drink from that glass again.  She downed it like a champ.  Engaged in some drunken/gilfy flirting with my friend.  Very awkward.  Like she skipped her golden anniversary dinner and popped into the bar instead.  Fun times.  Rye bar at its best.
author: Mitchell L.

description:
Went during our last vacation to San Francisco.  Nice little lounge with awesome lighting and a laid back ambiance.  Particulary enjoyed the basil gimlet... stronger than what I am used to.  Have to admit, I was very tired and not in the mood to be out and about.  It was a bit slow, but then again it was a weekday.  Kept looking around for a secret door or something...

I'd recommend it, probably wouldn't go back - only because I'm a grandma and rather stay home watching videos and drinking cocoa.  :)
author: Kristine M.

description: For being out of towner's, we found a great spot to hang out and do our thing.  Not only was everybody and the crew as cool as it gets, I heard about a spot in my home town.  Can't wait to check out the Zig Zag and find out about Captain Jack!!  Now I want to check out Rye on the Road, does it get any better?  Oh, and you got to try on of Jen's Beer Cocktails, quite tasty for sure.  Thanks again San Fran, love Seattle!!!
author: Diane A.

description:
This place is cool. It's got great atmosphere (low lighting, chill music), and the drinks are fantastic and creative. There's an outdoor area (for smoking?) where you can watch people wander by and strike up a conversation with the people around you. All in all a nice place. 
The only thing I didn't like about it was the neighborhood. It was a little weird walking from the BART to this place at night alone. A lot of people staggering (literally) around. Made me a little nervous. 
Otherwise the experience was great and I would recommend it.
author: Lynn B.

description:
I am not really big into the whole artisan drink craze that everyone seems to be on right now. I am most happy with a drink that has no more then 2-3 ingredients. 

Alas, since I was here I decided to try something out of the norm. So my buddy and I both got a mint julep. And I have to say it was very tasty. I felt like I should have been wearing one of those ridiculously big hats and watching the Kentucky Derby. The bar itself was actually very beautiful. We were here a bit early and were able to enjoy our surroundings before the masses came.

My only complaints were that one of the bar tenders was less than excited to be serving us drinks (to put it lightly) and it took forever to get one. But I guess that's to be expected from a place like this.
author: Jeff P.

description: Came here on a Thursday night to celebrate a friend's birthday. The staff are pretty friendly, but that's about as good as it gets. Their specialty drink that night cost $10...and I'm guessing the rest aren't too far along the cash scale. There's only one pool table, and seating is limited. What makes this place an absolute killjoy is that its main clientele is yuppies. That's right. You may not have known it exists, but there is a bar in the Tenderloin that caters to dirty, scruffy-dressed, pant-leg-raised, messenger-bag-toting, hygiene-ignoring yuppies. The place is small and friendly, but I don't want to spend a night with these people. Until the yups decide to find another watering hole, I'll stick to pubs.
author: Danny C.

description:
I'm so, so poor, and going to Rye is like rubbing salt and alcohol into a gaping wound. That said, it's totally worth it. Like, totally. I've been there twice and have been in ecstasy both times. The first time the bartender took a little while to pay attention to us, but once he did he was smooth and efficient and awesome about answering questions and letting us sample apertifs, etc. I ordered the Basil Gimlet (but with vodka) and the Dimmi More special (lemon bitters, simple, muddled strawberries and Dimmi). Both were AMAZING, high quality delectable cocktails. I wished I could have had 5 Dimmi Mores instead of just one. Boyfriend had the Nevada cocktail and the Vertigo (Earl Grey and Chai-infused gin--what?!) and they were also fucking superb, even though I hate whiskey and gin.

Each time they've had good tunes and just a few mellow people sprinkled around the bar. What a haven in the middle of the Tenderloin. I wish I was a millionaire so I could rot out my liver with style at Rye.
author: Laura M.

description: I went to this bar last night with a friend. We met with the owner who suggested a great cocktail.
author: Paul M.

description:
What a slick spot.

Before I get into any more details.. try the Flash!! (there's a photo of it in the pictures section.)

It's a cucumber/kiwi/gin drink. I'm sure there's magic or fairy dust in there too! It was so tasty! I can't do the description justice.

The bar itself is pretty cool. I went on a weeknight so it wasn't too packed but I imagine on a Friday or Saturday it must be quite crowded. The bartenders were friendly and quick, the drinks (as I mentioned) were amazing, and the atmosphere and fellow-patrons were cool too.

Next time I'm in town I'll be sure to get another Flash!
author: Katy H.

description:
If I ever lived in the TL, this would be my neighborhood bar.  I would have really cheap rent and bed bugs, but I could say that I spend all those savings at this bar.

I remember walking into 15 Romolo many years ago and thinking I had found an oasis in the often unappealing N. Beach area.  I feel the same way here.  As much as the TL has evolved, I still think the scene can be iffy.  The scene here is usually decent and the atmosphere and drinks are excellent.  If you find yourself in the area, Rye and to some degree, B&B, are always great places to end up.
author: E L.

description:
What better way to wait that long wait at Osha Thai than to grab a well crafted drink at Rye? 

I went in on a Friday night around 9, at it had the perfect crowd density. The bartender said it'd get super packed as the night went on, but my ideal bar is full of people but not needing to do the side-step to get from one area to the other. 

The atmosphere is divey with a mix of pre-prohibition type decor (unless I had too much to drink). 

I only wish I lived closer.
author: Jason L.

description:
great place for gimlets and their specialty drinks are also very lovely. Some can be extremely sweet and strong and others, not so much. If you don't know what to get, try one of their specials, you can never go wrong with any of their choices.

dog friendly bar, but i'm not sure if you'd really want to bring your dog into a bar/lounge, but if you really wanted to, you could.

great bartenders, super friendly and great service.
author: Jessica L.

description: nice chill bar.  Had to try the basil gimlet ($10) and I liked it.  Friends got whiskey on the rocks ($9) - one time the pour was generous, the other time it was a bit stingy.  Went there on a  Saturday night around midnight.  Not too crowded.  They have a small pool table and it wasn't too crowded where we couldn't play.  Love that they were playing old skool songs (Warren G, Notorious B.I.G, Tupac, etc).
author: Minah L.

description:
Really relaxed bar with a lot of custom cocktails made with freshly squeezed/muddled fruit.  I don't know why I thought it looked small on the inside, but it's actually pretty spacious -- there's a room separate from the bar that's pretty big, an outdoor cage patio for smokers, and the room with the bar, which also has a pool table.  

Our bartender was super friendly & gave us recommendations on what to drink, all while squeezing fresh lemon juice for the drinks!  I had a cucumber gimlet, which I honestly didn't like all that much, but that probably has more to do with my tastes than the quality of the cocktail.  

Definitely go here for a quiet place to chill and drink with friends.
author: Joyce H.

description:
Small place, which makes it cozy

Played cool music none of which was hip hop, which makes it alternative

Cool drinks like the Basil goblet, which makes it unique 

I'm in to cozy alternative unique places
author: Kristina S.

description:
Tried a basil gimlet, a Dead Ringer (reposado, grapefruit juice, st. germain), a sample of something apple cidery that the bartender made, and a sip of something else that I can't remember right now (EtOH fail!)

Really good drinks!  Minus one star because the girl bartender wasn't quite as skilled as the guy bartender.

This reminds me a bit of Library Bar in LA.  Super chill vibe, darkly lit atmosphere, good place to kick back and just relax.
author: Cynthia G.

description:
Super cute place with a fun, chill vibe.  It's hard to toe the line between scene-y and relaxed, but Rye does a great job.  It's not pretentious at all, and the waitstaff is really nice.  The cucumber drink (The Flash, I think it's called) is by far my favorite - tart and refreshing.  But all the drinks are fabulous and use real (!) fruit!  

I never or rarely head to the back of the bar; there tends to be open space in the back near the bathrooms...but then you'll constantly be getting bumped as people make their way to and from the bar and bathrooms.  The seating in the recessed area are the best; especially on nights when it's not so busy, it's a great place to chill with some friends.

Over the past few months, it has become busier and busier which is a bit of a bummer because I like having it as my favorite local spot.  But I'm glad people love it.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Looks like most everything here has been said and done, so I'll keep it short.  This spot has a nice dark cool vibe and creative drink list.  Across from the Ambassador, it's a nice refuge when you don't want to wait in line.  The bar is a bit on the small side, but the bartenders are pretty attentive and make some interesting drinks with pretty fresh ingredients.

For a spot in the Nob Hill / TL it's worth a mid day stop in for a Dark and Stormy or the Basil Vodka Gimlet.
author: Aaron W.

description:
UPDATE: Wow what a difference a few months makes. Some friends of mine hadnt been here before and since we were eating at Osha next door, we stopped by. They've got a pretentious asshole of a bartender who makes fun of their clients singing along to Oasis' Supernova. Lucky for me, I didnt feel like drinking so it was my paying friend who overheard him. If you can deal w/ the TTude, then enjoy it bitch! 

Atmosphere- friendly crowd, friendly bar hostess (Asian girl w/ the awesome tattoo, you rock!), very modern and a bit trendy

Music- mix of hip hop, house and top 40 just the way I like it

Drinks- satisfied myself w/ a Stella and gin and tonic. pretty standard so no big raves from me

Smoke room- faces the front and plenty of space.
author: Thomas L.

description:
One of my favorite places to hit up on geary.  Some people think its too small or always empty but I've always found it to be the right density, both in people and drinks.  

Let's start with the drinks.  The drinks range from the very light to very strong which is great when you're traveling with people with different levels of drinking in mind.  The basil gimlet is ridiculously good and is the reason why I came here in the first place (was doing the 100 things to eat and drink in sf).  If you're looking for a strong drink, try the Rock n Rye.  That thing knocked my socks off, great flavor and stiff enough to make you think you definitely got your money's worth.

Now the people.  So the typical crowd looks to be around early 30's, which is younger or older depending on where you usually go.  The pool table and the smoking area make it have a more relaxed vibe then most places but the soft lit seating room gives it an upper class feel.  No dress code (or at least I don't believe so).  Go in suit or shorts, you're going to have a good time (but wouldn't recommend shorts).

Overall I love the feeling of this place and they make their strong drinks strong, unlike most water-downed whiskey places.  Come here for a relaxed night in the company of a couple of friends looking for a great time.
author: Paran Y.

description: The bartenders are friendly, but more importantly know how to mix a drink. Basil Gimlet (fresh basil, lime juice, raw sugar, gin), Sawtiao San (classico rum, fresh kumquat, falernum, orange bitters),  and Rye Manhattan (rye whiskey, sweet vermouth, arugula butters) were all stand out cocktails.
author: Clarke W.

description:
First two words that come to mind: dark and swanky. 

I am regretting not having the Flash as you fine yelpers have raved about, as I had the Basil Gimlet and it was a little too sour for me. I should have known better. Other than that, the joint was fine. I dig the digital design against the brick wall. 

Other than this ... it didn't grab me one way or the other. Maybe because it was dead and the bartender seemed to take a while to notice we wanted a drink. Or maybe because it just didn't seem to have a lot of chemistry one way or the other.
author: Olivia L.

description:
A nice cocktail bar that brings some classiness to your evening when strolling around the Tenderloin. A group of friends and I came here to catch up on life and what not. The set up is kind of cool with the pool table in back with a fire place and a slightly lower floor with seating as well as an outdoor area that makes it look like you're caged in (for people who would like to keep sipping their drinks while satisfying that nicotine craving). I ordered THE FLASH, even though many other yelp reviewers really recommend the basil gimlet.

The flash is a lovely concoction of gin, fresh ground kiwi, lemon, cucumber and some agave nectar. The sweetness of the agave nectar masked most of the taste of the alcohol, which I really liked because I'm not too big of a fan with gin. But, be careful! However sweet it is, I still get that slight Asian glow. 

The party I came here with were a mix of people, some working and some who were still in school. I wouldn't recommend coming to Rye for cocktails if you're tight on cash and not willing to spend ~$10 per cocktail.
author: Julia K.

description:
Rye was one of the few bars I was first introduced to upon experiencing SF nightlife and was a loyal follower thereafter.

Pro: Great times and the best memories.
Con: Set the bar too high and now am left a bit unsatisfied with other places in the city.
 
Rye is the place to go for a chill start to your night out on the town. If you don't pay attention you may just miss it! Their smoking patio is 'like being in a prison cage' as I like to describe it- but oh the more reason to love it! Great for people watching and a bit incognito ;)  

Love the brick walls and casual yet modern interior, good music that isn't too loud and you can actually hear what your date/friends are actually saying. The drinks are well made and strong, unlike other places that pack on the ice and call it a drink. The crowd here is contemporary, hip, and chic- every time I go I see beautiful people ;) But without all the pretentious snobbery you see in other blazer adorned lounges. 

Not the place to go if you're looking to go crazy dancing, but definitely a place to get your drink on with friends and start the night. Everytime I have friends from out of town to visit I bring them here for starters and they are always impressed. Good drinks, nice vibes, beautiful people. love Rye.
author: A J.

description: Got an expensive drink that wasn't great here. Can't remember the name, but it was about $16 after tax and tip. The space was ok.
author: Khalid N.

description:
This place makes some bomb ass drinks!! Basil Gimlet and The Flash are two drinks you can count on, but you can ask the bartenders to make any drink to you liking, and they usually succeed. I'd recommend sticking to the male bartenders...they must have more arm strength or something to muddle those basil leaves b/c their drinks went down more smoothly than the drinks I ordered from the lady bartender....

Pretty laid back spot to start off your night.  They often have some creative drinks the bartenders mix up just for fun that aren't on the menu.  They once had this apple cider concoction that was served warm, which  i thought was a bit strange.  Not only was it tasty, it had a nice kick to it, and was free!!

def. worth a try if you're in the area!
author: Ngoc N.

description:
This was such a cool place!  The bartender obviously took great pride in the drinks he made for us; the Flash was delicious (like a spa treatment in a glass, as one of my friends put it), and another drink recommended by our bartender (wish I could remember what it was called) was also very good.

The only thing I really didn't like about this place was the "smoker's cage," which swamped the entire lower area of the bar with smoke every time someone decided they needed or were finished with a smoke.
author: Em S.

description:
came here for a friend's bday. the place is hard to spot and pretty small. it basically is a bar lounge with really strong drinks.

we stood around the bar area the whole time. i tried the basil gimlet and it was veryy refreshing and good. whiskey sour was strong, your typical jack and coke was strong. definitely get ur moneys worth.

wish they played the music a bit louder or had a small dance floor, but its more of a chill drink place. parking can be hard but snagged one a block away. 
nice bartenders but its true it can take awhile to get ur drinks since they get fancy with it.

extra star just for good drinks
author: Christine M.

description:
Rye's grown and waned on me over the years. It's really hard being here on a Friday or Saturday evening when the crowd around the bar is over 3 people thick and everyone's packed like sardines against each other. But on the more lax evenings it's a great place to park myself on a stool and ask their friendly and expert bartenders to whip me up something on the fly. 

They also have great community events. Recently, thanks to a tequila sponsor, they had invited many well known bartenders from across the city to compete on making the best mixed drink. Everyone was of good cheer as competitors egged each other on, stole equipment from each other, chatted up their neighbors and snuck sips from their rivals. Their creativity was amazing, as their concoctions held everything from hand-mashed watermelon, cinnamon, chili, fizzy baby tomatoes, mint, and the like. As a customer who happened to pick the right night to stop by, we got to sample all these amazing drinks and vote on our favorite. 

In fact, I had SUCH a good time sampling oh so many drinks, I wobbled home and promptly passed out for the night, completely forgetting to close out my card from the beer I had pre-event.  

They still have my card (it's probably assumed reported lost and cut up by now). This was maybe 3 weeks ago. 

Yes, beware the good times to be had at this place.
author: ChiYan T.

description: This is a good place to pick up a basil gimlet and also to lose your fatty balls.  Chicks don't want to talk to dudes carrying around a drink with a leaf of basil in it.  Its a good drink but expect it to be a game killer.
author: Fatty A.
