description: Really nice hip place. Stylish crowd. Seem very popular as well since it was quite busy for Tuesday evening. My friend tells me that this really popular with models. How he knows that, I have no idea and did not ask. One of those "sure, ok, whatever" moments. They have a smoking area as well. I don't smoke but was glad to see that it was well insulated and the smoke did not come back into the bar unlike some other places. A vodka soda was $9 which was reasonable given the type of bar this is
author: Sunil R.

description: I love the fresh fruit drinks but am not a huge fan of the Tendernob location and the somewhat steep prices. I tried a sip of my friend's basil gimlet though and it was great! If I'm in the neighborhood, Rye is definitely an essential stop but I usually won't go too far out of my way to come here...
author: Meghan P.

description:
Drinks: Above average. The perfect Manhattan I ordered was perfect as were the old fashioneds according to my friends.

Service: The bar service was slow, but in a good way. It allowed for the bartenders to craft drinks well. The bouncer is a very cool dude. He is also a ninja so don't mess with him. I'm serious, I saw him bust out some serious Wu-Tang Shaolin stuff. Not really, because everyone was calm and having a great time, but he could if he had to. Also, did I mention he is really cool? He has a secret door with no handle. The table server (waitress is politically incorrect these days right?) was heavenly. She was attentive, patient and somehow got the bartenders to play 2 Chainz "The Birthday Song" in the midst of a flurry of Phoenix and MGMT. For this I love her. Too far you say? I say you haven't met her or else you would say the same.

Ambiance: Clean, High Ceilings, Well-designed

Twitter Review: #ArnoldSchwarzenegger... I'll be back
author: John D.

description: A hip cocktail bar! We tried Basil Gimlet and Merchant mule! Basil Gimlet is fresh and sweet (a little too sweet, maybe). Merchant mule is spicy, strong ginger flavor. Both are excellent mixture and left a lasting impression on me.
author: Emmy P.

description:
My friends and I discovered Rye during Yelp Drinks Week when they had a few of their poplar drinks for a discounted price. Rye has a bar as well as an area where there are couches and tables for you to lounge. It's a very cozy environment, but the bar area does get crowded sometimes. 

I don't remember the other drinks that we tried, but the Basil Gimlet was a hit with everyone. If you watch the bartenders make the drinks, you will see that they use a lot of really FRESH ingredients in their drinks which is great, but just keep in mind that it takes them longer to make the drinks, so the service is a little bit slow at the bar. 

Since Yelp Drink's Week, we have gone back to Rye, but only for their Basil Gimlet. It's not a place that we start our night with, but it is a place that we end up at towards the end of the night when we are craving a Basil Gimlet.
author: Jessica S.

description: Cool space.  Creative cocktails--went here last night and got a cocktail that had pumpkin butter in it.... called the Jive Turkey ... so fun and interesting!
author: Lindsay L.

description:
can't control the sometimes doucheness of the people that get jam packed in here....that's why i go on the weekdays. but, you sure can get some yummy drinks. GINGER BUCK GINGER BUCK GINGER BUCK. 

go on a weekday, get few cocktails, sit with your buds and proceed to have amazing conversations dripping with deliciousness of your drink at hand.
author: Hanna K.

description: I've been here a few times and this is a great casual, chill bar with great cocktails. Smoking area attached, comfy seats, dark decor, love the brick walls, cool bartenders, close to other bars and osha thai is right next door if you get hungry!
author: Linda C.

description:
Nice vibe, with a slightly older crowd during the week.  

Stopped at Rye after breaking the bank at Bourbon and Branch around the way, and was pleasantly surprised by the bar staff.  They were helpful, and willing to but a house twist on my Pimm's cup, which was a nice surprise.

The space is definitely worth talking about.  Really open, and stopping by on a weekday means plenty of open tables to enjoy the sweet libations from the bar.  They even have a small patio area for smoking if that's what you're in to.  

Overall, if Im in the neighborhood again, I will definitely stop by Rye and grab a drink from the friendly bar staff
author: David M.

description: Nice cocktail lounge that makes a great place for a classy drink. It's cool that they have a patio area for smokers that is basically still inside the bar, but fenced off from the street. The location is a bit sketchy so I appreciate this boundary. They mixed up a great Old Fashioned, skipping the muddled fruit recipe for the classic made with just sugar, bitters, and orange peel.
author: Johnny W.

description:
I really love this place.  Although I find that the bartenders can be a tad of the nose-in-the-air type because of their mixing prowess, it's still a great place to get a fantastically-made drink.  Not only that, but you can bring in food from OSHA Thai, or the pizza joint down the street, or maybe the Chinese food joint directly across...whatever you feel will go well with your dashing spirit of choice.

We were here for 3 hours last night, and I consumed a glass of very nice Prosecco and 2 of their "Flash"es.  MAN, those suckers are good.  Although I did it without the sugar, the muddled kiwi and cucumber make for such a refreshing drink.  

I was supposed to get the Basil Gimlet.  The year's half over and I've let the 100 Things to Eat Before I Die in San Francisco list go to the birds.  Dammit, I should have had that gimlet!
author: Tamar D.

description:
I finally went to Rye after years of hearing other peoples' raves about it. When it comes to cocktails, sometimes I'm not the most well-rounded or sophisticated in my preferences so I didn't know if I was going to be able to find something I could handle on their menu . 

I asked the bartender what she recommended in terms of a not-too-strong-tasting drink...she goes, oh that's the whole point of a cocktail... UM okay yes. I know what the POINT of a cocktail is, believe it or not. But some cocktails still TASTE like booze and others don't :) 

I decided to go with the hemingway something or another. It had rum and lime and grapefruit flavors. It was intense but not in a way I couldn't tolerate. It definitely made me feel great in about, oh, five minutes! my friend had a margarita which was good too. Other than that, nice decor and crowd...nice smoking patio (even though i don't smoke).
author: Shannon R.

description:
The waitress was very helpful and helped us decide between the drink options.  We each tried something different and no one was disappointed.  We got there around 8:30 on a Friday night and just barely beat the crowd.  It was nice having a table and couch/seat while we were there.


I had to laugh at the smokers cage until the smell of smoke wafted into the lower section, oh well.
author: franko b.

description: Ok, so this place is the best. Here's why: When our server had forgotten whether we ordered 1 or 2 of a drink (it was 2), and brought one too few, she immediately apologized and charged us for only one out of the three drinks we ordered.  There were no questions, no lengthy apologies, just a quick and extravagant gesture for a very small mistake. Now that is service :-).
author: Joshua R.

description: My first stop of the evening on my last night in SF and what a nice way to start the night. I actually passed the place a few times, having to call the friend I was meeting because the sign is teeny-tiny, in little letters, strategically placed for people who are closer to 7 feet tall and I'm pint-sized, so I just don't look up that high...or maybe I'm not very observant. Either way, nice atmosphere, uncrowded and a REALLY nice Pimms cup!
author: Renee E.

description:
Infamous basil gimlet!
I LOVED IT. I love mojitos and this tastes like one, but with basil instead of mint. Very refreshing and tasty. There are other innovative drinks and I definitely want to come back and try them!

This seems like a great place to go if you want a chill night to talk w/ friends & sip on some yummy drinks, but more than your average neighborhood bar.
author: Miss H.

description:
Yes, the Basil Gimlet is AMAZING, but I tried another drink once (the cucumber one?) and it was pretty awful.  

Not a great place to sit and chat - the music was way too loud.

No dance space...but the last time I was there, drunk ppl just started dancing in the middle of the table area. Awkward.

The bar also gets crowded though the bartenders and wait staff are very friendly and helpful.
author: Jessica S.

description:
HAND-CRAFTED COCKTAILS

We entered through the nondescript entrance not expecting such a modern open and airy interior.  An artist was drawing on a large mural in the back and the bar was completely full.  The comfortable black leather couches make the perfect conversation pit; if you are lucky enough to grab one.  We maneuvered our way to the bar and the friendly bartender suggested we try an old-fashioned with simple syrup that she created.  How could we resist?

Fall-Inspired Old Fashioned
The bartender muddled a slice of orange and brandied cherry with fall-flavored simple syrup.  The bartender told us the simple syrup was made with mulling spices, sliced apples, and cayenne pepper.  Basil Hayden bourbon and ice was added to make this festive drink.  All the flavors worked perfectly; I tasted oranges, apples, and cayenne pepper.

Sazerac
Rittenhouse rye, sugar, bitters, absinthe rinse, and a lemon peel were the ingredients for this classic cocktail.  It was not too sweet and disappeared quickly.

I will definitely be back to try more drinks from their inventive menu.
author: Rob L.

description: Good cocktails,  chill atmosphere, nice end to a long night
author: Tay H.

description: Really cool place, although it would be nice if they had a little more seating given that they have the space for it. Drinks were good, bartender was friendly and even though it was crowded we got served immediately. I will definitely go back.
author: Maxim L.

description:
It was almost impossible for me to get a drink.

 I stood at one end of the bar for over ten minutes and didn't even get eye contact from the bartenders. I was starting to lose my buzz and wanted to just leave but decided to use the restroom first.

I opened the door and have to see some guy peeing because the door doesn't lock.

On my way out of the bar I noticed that the crowd was a bit lighter at the bathroom end of the bar and decide to give it another try. After another five to ten minutes I had a beer in my hand.

There were three bartenders working like crazy but the specialty mixed drinks are so complicated that no matter how fast they work they'll never be able to serve a full bar in a timely manner. 

After I finished my beer I didn't want to put myself through the ordering process again and decided to leave.

I'd go back if they started a beer only line.
author: Manny F.

description:
Like borboun & branch or rickhouse, Rye sports some decent mixologists, freshly squeezed mixers & an impressive liquor selection... just not quite as good but about the same price... and in the Loin. 

Good if you're going out with a large group and are literally bringing the party with you, but otherwise this place attracts the most random collection of patrons ever (age groups, personal style, locals vs. tourists, etc.) a real mixed bag.
author: Nick T.

description:
We stopped in toward the end of a long night and ordered a couple specialty cocktails off the list. The bartender definitely took his drink making seriously, maybe too seriously because he didn't actually look me in the eye during my entire stint at the bar. The drinks were terrific, if a bit on the smallish side considering it was about $30 for two including a tip. 

The bar has a hip vibe, but may be a little too full of scenesters for my personal taste. If you are in fact a scenester or even a hipster with cash to burn, this is your spot.
author: Heather D.

description:
Dear Rye,

It's places like you that make me want to drink again. 

I have strong feelings of affection for you,

Ari
author: A. E.

description: It's a bar like any other.  Good use of space, not too snooty at the door, etc, etc...  Since everyone raved about the basil gimlet, I decided to try it out.  It was good, but a little too sour for my taste.  By the end I felt like I was drinking straight lemon juice.  Plus, $10 was a bit too steep.
author: Denis S.

description: Oh. Hey. So I've yet to update my pansy ass 4-star review of Rye? How's this old sucker me: Rye's now my favorite bar in the city. I get to play pool. I get to talk about long lost loves. I get to drink high potency cocktails. And just about no one turns me down when I say, "let's go to Rye." Suck it, 4-star previous review. Here's to a 5-star future.
author: Monica S.

description:
Rye bar is a great little hole in the wall. The drinks are amazing. They use fresh ingredients and bitters in their drinks which I love. The neighborhood isn't great and the drinks are pricey, but well worth it. 

I'd suggest ordering the flash to start off and get more adventurous from there.
author: Bryan K.

description: Awesome basil gimlet, that's why we're all here.  It's a good place to mingle with a group and chat.  I've never seen it that crowded on the weekends either; we've always had a place to sit or congregate.
author: Erika C.

description:
I remember the good ol' days when one could actually come here on a Friday or Saturday night to just chill and have a drink.  Everyone was at Osha next door.  Alas, I guess word caught on because it is now a "B&T"/Marina magnet on the weekends.  The picture is rather amusing from the outside:  a [smoking] cage filled with overgrown frat boys and their imbecilic dates who provide a running commentary on how they are in an alternatively "dangerous" ghetto universe.  Whatever.  Then again, there was that time, while in the smoking cage, I came face to face with a middle-aged woman walking around with a threadbare top and her sagging breasts fully exposed on a typically chilly night.  I gave her two cloves.  I would've given away the whole pack, but my smoker friend looked at me like I was about to give away a car.

Rye, however, gets 3 stars from me because Sunday-Wednesday, you can comfortably enjoy a drink while chatting with friends ('course this rings true for a lot of bars Sun-Wed).  And they have, in my experience, always played good music even if it is not live.  Decor is also pleasant with its polished, black walnut tones and wall of decorative wine bottles.
author: Dee C.

description:
This place has a great atmosphere and love the "warehouse/cellar" feel to it. My friend and I came to grab a drink, and unfortunately all the spots to sit were taken so we just hung out on the steps right outside the smoking area. There was a good crowd, but either it was a little too mellow, or this crowd was a little on the dull side. Anyway, had a good mojito to drink and plenty of eye-candy to keep me happy.
You could hear the music in the background just barely, which was great to have a decent conversation, didn't have to yell at anyone standing 2 feet across from me.
author: Alyssa G.

description: Rye is a great bar to just chill and grab a drink at with friends. There is music but it's low-key enough that you can come in with a bunch of friends and actually hear each other talk. Tried the Basil Gimlet on the SF 7x7 100 things with gin and it was a pretty strange experience, kind of hard to get down. Probably just not my cup of tea. Either way I enjoy coming into Rye as a stop along a great night out in San Francisco =)
author: Christina L.

description:
Rye. It's hard to find the first time because of the non-existent sign.  It's hard to find the second time because you blacked out the first time.  Usually by the third time you're good to go.

The bar is essentially divided into three sections. The first, where the bar is, includes a pool table and plenty of space to mingle.  After your friends have arrived (or you've made new friends), you can move down a step or two to the more loungy area complete with your typical knee-high style tables flanked by boxy black leather couches.  Oh, and if you smoke, there's a great outdoor section for you to enjoy.

The drinks are so good at rye it's obscene - to the point where I think there's a crime being committed.  They're strong but surprisingly good despite the wallop. A bit pricey (about $10/drink) but you'll only need 2 or 3.

It's not an every night bar, but it's definitely a thrice-a-month spot.  Check it out.
author: Nathan M.

description:
The drinks here are delicious! Great place to grab a yummy drink with your girlfriends, or catch a pre-dinner / pregame drink :)

Only reason I'm not giving it 5 stars is because it's tiny, and extremely loud....Wouldn't recommend coming here with more than 2 or 3 ppl max.
author: danielle r.

description: We really enjoyed Rye...It has the swanky feel of an uptown bar but the cool vibe of downtown. I found this place on yelp on a first visit to San Fran. We really enjoyed the service and the assortment of craft cocktails. I definitely recommend this place to anyone who is looking for a great spot to go without the "club scene" but still have a happening vibe. Definitely GO!!
author: Marcie D.

description:
Two words - basil gimlet. 

Even beter when you have (1) good company at the bar; (2) the friendly  bartender that we had, who's always up for a good chat and (3) lots and lots of space on a random weeknight.
author: Ange L.

description:
Rye is a gem in the middle of the Tenderloin - even though the loin is rapidly becoming a hot spot for nightlife of this style.

They have great cocktails and a relaxed, pleasant ambiance. The Basil Gimlet is good as well as some of the other cocktail creations they offer.

A good doorman is important in this neighborhood, which they have as well.
author: Lina L.

description: Meh, I've had better "craft" Manhattens elsewhere in San Francisco. Slow club and Outerlands are two places I'd recomemd over Rye. The bartender used angustora bitter (ble) and not an exceptional vermouth or bourbon to create our drinks which left less hair on my chest than a pack of monkeys.
author: Alina P.

description:
Two Words:  Basil Gimlet

Oh how do I love thee!   I celebrated my 31st birthday at Rye and it was so much fun!   I got to twirl around in my Rainbow striped dress and received and applause from other patrons.   Smoked in the cage-like outdoor/indoor smoking area.  Drank different types of gimlets and a Flash.  The drink wait time was long but I had friends to pre-occupy my time. 

Mix Crowd, Great Music (they had on Ratatat another time I was there) outweighed the stranger/stalker who kept staring at my friend and I even after she told him she was married and waved her left hand at him.  

This is a Great Escape from the oozing stinkyness more like skankiness of Ambassodor; Oh how do I loathe thee.....
author: Morgan L.

description:
Hm.  I was less impressed when we went back to Rye on Thursday evening.  Not so much because it was far less drama than Wednesday, but because it seemed like less effort was put into crafting the exact same cocktail that I ordered the previous evening.

No crazy drunk girl assaulted us.  In fact, it was a super mellow crowd, and there was even enough seating in the lounge area below for all of us to share some comfy couches.  I will admit that it was loud enough that I felt we had to holler to make ourselves heard in conversation.  On the whole, this was exactly the speed I needed after a long week of long days, short nights, and lots of excitement.

Back to my drink.  After the magic of watching my bartendress craft my delightful Ginger Spice, I was looking forward to the same experience this evening.  Expertly eyeballed volumes of liquors and mixers went into a glass.  Ice was added and smoothly stirred.  The freshly chilled martini glass was emptied of ice water and refilled with Ginger Spice.  The bartendress siphoned up a small straw full of the drink and sampled it to ensure quality... and it was passed to me.

What?  No lighted toothpick?  No flaming orange peel?  This must be what it feels like when the honeymoon ends, and your partner stops treating you like you're special.  I was just a little bit crushed... but I paid up, took my drink, held my chin up, and weaved my way back to my colleagues to drown my sorrows in rye whiskey.

And drown them I did.  Flaming orange peel or not, this drink was still expertly crafted, ridiculously strong, and by the time I found the bottom of my glass, I forgot all about my earlier disappointment.

Rye, I still adore you.  But you remind me once again that nobody's perfect all the time.  Sorry, I have to go.  Reality's calling for me.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Best Whiskey Sour ever.

I love to go here when it's not too busy and ask Doug to just make me something, one of few  bartenders in the city that I can trust with such a request and who delivers so consistently.  Just a nice easy-going guy, too, which is refreshing to find in someone who has enough skill to probably  get away with acting like a douchebag if he wanted to.

When it's busy it's tough to find a seat and the table service is understandably a little spotty.  They don't really run tabs, so you'll have to pay for each round.  Maybe that's easier for them, but it makes it a little confusing and inconvenient for the customer.  Our waitress, though, was a doll and I'm sorry to see that it looks like the staff doesn't always get treated well by the clientele.  Seriously, people -- one dollar on two drinks is not a good tip considering it took two people to make them and bring them to you.  When it's really busy, I'd avoid asking for anything labor intensive and that isn't on the menu.  And I'm sure they will love you if, when you really need to have a Pisco Sour or a Jimmy Roosevelt, one or two of your friends gets the same thing as well.

If you're hungry, grab a buffalo burger around the corner at Pearl's.  Mmmmmm.
author: Sven E.

description:
I walked into the bar feeling a little disheveled. I certainly hadn't prepared myself for a schmancy night on the town and I was dressed as such. Luckily when we walked in I noticed the about-to-be-a-real-bitch-to-us barfly comment to her friend about how much she liked my jacket. Hell yes. You know you love that feeling. Everyone does. 

So after that little boost of confidence, I was set. Until the barfly reappeared to inform us it was a private party. Ehhh... whatever, we were already at the bar and I needed a drink, so we just kind of ignored her. That ended up working out juuuust fine. 

I had the Aviation, which was great. The perfect amount of sweet without being overwhelming, I loved it. I also loved watching the bartendress carefully concoct the drink, sampling as she went along. 

I returned the next night and sampled a fantastic Belgian, if only I could remember the name. It was pricey at $9, but as that's what I often end up paying for a Chimay so I suppose I can't complain. Again, the bartender was incredibly friendly and knowledgeable and I really appreciated his candor. 

Rye isn't the kind of place I'd make a regular hangout for me. I like my nightlife a little more divey and a little less "private party."
author: Kathleen M.

description:
I absolutely loved this place.  I'm a gimlet drinker, and the basil gimlet was unbelievable!  Marco, the bartender, was amazing and a huge "cocktail geek."  They have all kinds of bitters and fancy cocktail ingredients you won't see everywhere. The bar is cute and modern looking.  The bathroom is small but nice enough.

The only time I've been (a Wednesday night) it wasn't crowded.  I'm totally bringing people here.
author: Jessica M.

description:
Came here on Friday night, and the Basil Gimlet is indeed good.  But the line outside and the cramped space and the slow bartenders really brought the rating down.  I'd definitely come back here for drinks, but maybe not on a weekend night.   

I did like the personality of one bartender there though.  When I asked for 6 gimlets, she responded with a look of incredulity and, "You serious?"  I smiled at her and when she finished making the drinks, I told her, "Actually, 10 more gimlets," and she flicked me off.  Haha... Funny girl.
author: James C.

description:
The basil gimlet is a little peice of heaven in a glass... and I know my gimlets!

Happy hour is a great time to come - when it gets later it gets a little backed up at the bar with so many speicalty drinks that do take a little bit longer than normal to prep and get out.

Only downside is sitting on the patio behind the bars does make for some interesting street-walking talkers...but can't hold that against them.
author: Chelsea D.

description: I don't see what all the fuss is about regarding this bar's drinks.  As a first timer there was nothing listed for me to choose from and try out.  One drink on the board was in honor of the football game-and I don't care for cinnamon. That said I just ordered a whiskey sour.  The bar tenders are not very engaging or helpful regarding what to try.  They also seem to think bitters goes in everything.  I'm not sure how this bar gets first timers to go back.
author: Kristen B.

description: Great cocktails, a good ambiance (you can hear the people across from you and they have a pool table).
author: Eddie H.

description:
Came here for a good friend's birthday party last weekend. I can't believe I've lived in the city now for well over 3 years and hadn't yet made it to this lovely loungey type bar in the Tenderloin (or tendernob, whatever).  

I love the atmosphere.  Its dark, has some great art, and was swimming with other gorgeous singles like myself.  My only issue is that is was too crowded, not many places to sit, and the wait at the bar was a bit too long. 

It was a great opportunity to try #98 on the SF Big Eat List, which is a basil gimlet. Ummm, YUM! Delicious. I had no idea what a gimlet is but it's basically like a martini (but sweeter) with basil.  I ordered the vodka because I absolutely despise gin (well basically any other liquor besides vodka).  The gimlet was super strong and well made.  I will definitely be ordering this again next time I venture on over to Rye.
author: Jenny W.

description:
Drinks are great here and I love the atmosphere!  Definitely worth checking out. 

My only complaint is that the service can be ridiculously slow. I understand taking your time to make a really good cocktail, but a lot of the slowness was due to the bartenders chatting with each other.
author: Julie M.

description:
This is one of my top 5 favorite bars in SF.

They have a great space with a pool table, bar (obviously), and then you can go half a level down and enjoy the tables inside or out on the patio.

My only issue here is that some of the cigarette smoke makes it inside, but if you drink enough you'll hardly notice. ;)

The bartenders are ALWAYS very attentive and friendly.
author: Joel S.

description: I'm lucky that Rye is my neighborhood bar. I'm always a few steps away from creative and delicious cocktails and the super friendly staff.
author: Teri G.

description: This is my favorite type of lounge - dark, with some low lights, casual seating, and really good drinks. My husband and I happened on this lounge walking down Geary and spent an hour just hanging out. Loved the ambiance and drinks. The basil gimlet isn't listed on the menu anymore, but they still make it! Great little bar to hang out in.
author: Courtney M.

description:
I love this place cause it's like 2 blocks from my place! I decided to come in for a quick drink with a friend and ended up staying for some time! love the decor. the walls are dominated with red brick walls and some of the ceiling are covered in hardwood floor. very chic. 
the drinks are amazingly made but there are not that many choices. I still love it though cause I tend to go for the classic drinks. 
please try the whiskey sour! AMAZING!!! after u finish it, they have a lil surprise at the end. =D
author: Miss C.

description:
This place is very different from what I expected...

Super Crowded filled with city hipsters
Men in sports coats
The only seating was at the bar or on a pool table
There was a smoking cage??

But lets really recall the biggest thing...This bar is known for having a variety of specialty house drinks. My friend decides to tell the bartender to suprise him because he wants to try something good from the bar...

The bartender turns around, pulls a Tecate out of the fridge and says, "SUPRISE!" and walks away. HAHAHA awesome. Obviously the bartender came back and made another awesome whiskey shaken drink, but the prank was truly original and for that I will always remember Rye. Tecate on the house, and a bar memory that I will cherish forever.
author: Samantha R.

description:
I don't know what happened to me, but I am just not the young whipper snapper that I was 2 years ago. I used to love the loud, trendy, over priced lounges that have always infected NYC, but after moving to SF, I have seemed to have lost my love for everything that is the "lounge" or even worse, the "ultra lounge". But when I came to Rye, it was a special evening. 

Seong, Omar and the gang were here having drinks and Eugy and I wanted to meet them to celebrate our engagement. After driving from Cupertino to SF with a drunk Eugy, I definitely needed a drink! hah... So we said yes, we will venture into the FiDi on Friday night. Parking was a bitch and once at Rye, squeezing our little short frames into the bar was even a challenge. 

10 minutes in there and I felt as if I were in a sauna. Cramped to the core, sucky music and extremely rude bartenders? Why the hell would anyone want to come here?? 

After 20 minutes, I was sweaty, my ears hurt and I kept saying "it's past my bedtime".. It was time to go. And I'll never come back.
author: Jen D.

description:
We ordered the whiskey sour, which was unique that in it had egg whites topped with some kind of hot sauce. While I was a bit hesitant to drink this weird concoction, it was ended up being very tasty! Definitely coming back here to see what kind of other surprises their menu holds. 

The only complaint I have is that there was very little seating, but other than that this place was awesome.
author: C P.

description: Great atmosphere and good crowd.  The staff was very friendly.  And if the people I been with hadn't been a little strange.  Then would have been a great night.  I just never had out 5 stars unless I LOVE the place.  Cool spot.  Would recommend for happy hour or just evening drinks.
author: Matt B.

description: Delicious artisanal drinks and a nice mellow atmosphere make this place a consistent winner.   I think it's especially good when you want a drink in this neighborhood but aren't in a Bourbon & Branch mood.  (In fact, this is a regular hang-out for the B&B staff, so you know it's good.)
author: Lynn S.

description: This place is cool and trendy. Dim lighting, a no pay pool table (I enjoyed this the most out of this place), table seatings for the more private groups and good drinks makes this a wonderful spot for after work get togethers. The drinks can be pricey (usually around 10 bucks a piece) and it isn't the fastest bar, but the bartenders are really nice and helpful. This place sort of reminds me of 111 Minna, but smaller and more personal. You can spot  some of the SV all-stars here sometimes too.
author: Greg G.

description:
Nice, small-ish bar.  Nothing to write home about unless you're a smoker.  They had the outdoor vented metal cage just for those that wanted to be at/near a bar and get to smoke at the same time.  
Drinks were good, about $10 a cocktail.  The main reason I docked a star was the really long wait.  I think there were one or two bar tenders and about 50 thirsty patrons.  I'd go back on occasion, but definitely not my favorite place.  Try the new bar - Eve - in SOMA if you're looking for similar cocktails without the wait.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
My experience here had some wind at its back that may not replicate on every visit, but it deserves yelpin' all the same:

#1 It was the 1st Monday of the Month Mixologist contest (try to catch one of those if you can). This translates into free appetizers, and the first drink being on the house. Plus of course fostering a fun, festive party atmosphere.
#2 I knew one of the judges, so got hand-fed the drinks that were being rated in the contest for a few hours. These were *amazing* btw (but don't ask me to recount what they were). I DO remember that the complementary margarita I got to start was also very good. Not mojito...margarita...
#3 As a result of #2, I got to meet the owner who was just WAY cool. Super nice, explained the different drinks and why they worked with different ingredients. Oh, and I also got to feel really important hanging with the judges, and really happy and festive due to the hand-feeding.

I'd be curious to know what the music is like on nights when the competitions aren't happening. But I have a feeling it'd still be a great experience: the alcohol is good, the service is friendly, and the decor is hip. On this last point: a nice touch is the fact that the "smoking room" is in the front with open windows, which makes the addicts feel less marginalized as they subsequently are perched just adjacent to the Tenderloin sidewalk. It just makes everyone happier. That, plus the spirits, of course.
author: Diane B.

description: One of my favorite bars to hit up in the city. The bar is small, but bartenders are friendly and you may have to wait a bit for your drinks. My favorite is the basil gimlet, but their other drinks are well made. I've come back here multiple times and more recently noticed they took the pool table out for extra seating.
author: Beverly D.

description:
Whiskey/mixology bar in SF.  Cool, laid back vibe.  A good jumping off place for something wilder or a nice place to kick back and relax.  Everytime I've been here, things have been busy, but not packed.

Good drinks, though a bit on the pricey side.  As with any mixology place, be prepared to wait as each drink takes time to prepare, especially if there's an order for five different drinks in front of you.

Service is friendly and low hassle.

There's a front smoking area for those who love cancer.
author: Marcin M.

description:
maybe it's just me but if i go to a bar called RYE I expect to see some whiskey and some bourbon on the shelf.  At the very least some rye whiskey?  call me crazy.  but consider yourself informed. 

I think "Rye" is maybe for their wry sense of humor.  

What you get is your standard tendernob/loinhill bar - slash - lounge. with your usual vodkas, gins, and a couple whiskeys only. stark chic with no substance.  dark sleek walls, concrete floors, sticky tables, you know the drill.  The 'signature' cocktails list seemed a bit confused, not only were they seriously missing the firewater but no booze list. well i guess they don't really need one since there's nothing notable on the shelves to refer to.   My gimlet tasted strange.  and so did the other two even less memorable cocktails i had.  their bottled stella tasted like bottled stella. 

The iron cage out front makes this place stand out from swig and the others down the street.  nice touch.  except that it adds to their whole creating the false illusion that you will find caged barrels overflowing with bourbon inside.  sigh.  and sitting in the patio inside the cage does make one feel like an animal, and not in a good way, but more like a creature held captive at a zoo exhibit.  also, if you can suffer the smoke long enough to sit out there, expect to get panhandled on, which is another mind-jarring experience.  me behind bars and the downtrodden strolling free back and forth and hitting me up for cash. 

and on this particular night, someone had their giant cream colored lab crossed with a st. bernard looking dog with them.  it was certainly grand to look at. and i wanted to pet it too like everybody else.  but i am allergic and so i tried to stay away.  but those were some tight quarters in there.  and the hives that that furry creature caused me all over my face and neck, arms and legs really helped keep that good feeling all night.  (think what's his face in that last scene in there's something about mary.) if it wasn't the hives, it was moving across the street to swig that really did the night in.  did YOU know that the tendernob turns into a suburbia-in-the-city-gala event on the weekends?? seriously, prom dresses and all.
author: Nikki F.

description: I popped in lastnight for a friend's going away party and immediately liked the ambiance of this spot. I asked the bartender for a mint julep, the first I've had in San Francisco. Being from the South, I know what a good mint julep should taste like, and the small details that make it exquisite (shaved/crushed ice and muddled mint leaves). I've been a little nervous about ordering one from just anywhere- I was waiting for the place that looked like it could handle it expertly. Rye did. The bartender was quick and efficient, and the drink was amazing. He definitely made it right, and it even came in the chilled pewter cup, the traditional way. It was sweet, the bourbon infused so well with the muddled mint, and dangerously tasty going down.
author: Leigh H.

description:
Nice, chill atmosphere.
Brings out the NOT ghetto crowd.
Small place.
Always busy on Fri/Sat nights.
A big cocktail menu.
Strong drinks (around $9)
Somewhat slow service since each drink takes a while to make.
Mildly pretentious.
No cover.

Take all that, mash it together and ta daaa!! You have RYE.
author: Heidi C.

description:
Finally tried the basil gimlet! And it was delectable!

The bartenders are rather funny/hospitable people as well. They kept us entertained and smiling all night long. Wonderful bar, wonderful drinks, wonderful people.
author: Felicity M.

description: I want to start off by saying I have been to a bunch of bars all over the globe but I have never seen bartenders turn out speciality cocktails with the speed these guys have. The cocktails are centered around orange zest so if you don't like a orange peel in you drink don't get any of the speciality cocktails. The scene was standard but the drinks and the selection of rye and bourbon make the place worthy of a 4.
author: Jeffrey H.

description:
This could possibly be the hardest five stars a bar has ever earned, because man-oh-man, was this just not my normal cup of tea.

After dinner at Canteen, we decided to head over to Rye because, well, it's named Rye. Let me explain. If you're from the East Coast, especially the New York/New England/Pennsylvania area, you probably have some ancestral memory lodged deep in your mind about the virtues of rye whiskey. For those of us from the Northeast, Rye is our historical tipple of choice. Unfortunately, as a result of many years of marketing from the bourbon and vodka vendors, this perfect grain distillate had faded out of vogue.

But there is hope - in the late 1990s, Anchor Distillery launched a single malt rye whiskey - and since then a number of great rye whiskeys have come back onto the scene. So with this in mind, when I heard about Rye, I decided to make a trip out there.

The bar is beautiful, more East Coast than West - Scandinavian designed with wood accents everywhere. Down to every detail, the place screams "The Bubble Is Back! Long Live The Internet Bubble!"

But just on the promise that they may have rye, we went in.

The crowd was, well, horrible. Yuppie trash that decided to go out slumming in the Tendernob. Screeching bleached blonds and boisterous jock assholes vying for attention and hoping to get laid.

But they had rye, and we could get two seats at the corner of the bar near the door in case we needed to make a quick getaway.

It was at that point that I recalled what I thought about Paris: a beautiful city, if you could just get rid of the damned Parisians. Same thing goes for Rye.

Our bartender, Jennifer, was the saving grace of the night. In between churning out 7&7s, Rum and (Diet) Cokes, 7 and Waters, Gin and Tonics, Stoli Vanillas and Ginger Ale and other drinks better suited for frat parties than a sophisticated bar like this, she served up some of the most amazing Manhattans (Jim Beam Rye, Noilly Prat Sweet (Red) Vermouth, Peychoud Bitters and a single sour cherry) - possibly the best I have ever had. She admitted that she had a soft spot for that cocktail, and she treated it with the respect that it deserved.

We went in planning on having one, or at the most two drinks total, as we didn't hit the ATM before heading in (yes, they are cash only for now). By the time we left, we had each had four - because I don't think either we or the bartenders wanted the night to end.

As we left, we mentioned to Jennifer that she was the saving grace for the bar because she made the crowd there "tolerable".

So, here is the breakdown:

The bar - The atmosphere, architecture and sense of style is great, and the inclusion of both an outside cage (where we saw a blond chickie climbing up and comically (to us) trying to sexily writhe for her man) for smokers and a pool table warrants a definite 5 out of 5. Hopefully next time we'll see someone smack into the wall-length mirror thinking there is another bar on the other side of the wall.

The bartenders - Everyone we had there was amazing, not only making great Manhattans, but muddling a pair of perfect Basil Gimlets (vodka) and a house drink called a Gold Rye Fizz - a rye drink with mandarin oranges, rye, bitters and a splash of cream as a substitute for the missing Advocaat/Eierlikor/Egg Liquor. Jennifer gets extra points for gracefully dropping a whole lemon in a martini glass full of Absolut Citron - the perfect "lemon drop" in my book. 5 out of 5

The selection - 5 out of 5 - this is a hard one. The beer was well selected, but I still winced when seeing someone order a can of Tecate (the crowd was mostly drinking Stella, but a good number of Chimays came out of the fridge). A number of good whiskeys were available with the well rye being Jim Beam Rye (yellow bottle). Some bimbettes wanted Crown Royal, which they were out of, or didn't carry... which thoroughly distressed them but amused us.

The crowd - 1 out of 5, and if I could give lower scores, I would. Loud, annoying, drunk and the sort of people that makes me reconsider ever going back there, even though I loved the place. Once this crowd finds the "next greatest thing" I am sure it will be a much more tolerable group of folks frequenting the bar.
author: Avery G.

description:
A swanky industrial setting, interesting cocktail menu, and most importantly, delicious drinks made with fresh ingredients.

The only thing that would make this place better would be if they offered their basil gimlets at half price...wait, what?  What's that you say?  Basil gimlets ARE half price?  2 drinks for the price of one!  Woohoo!

Thanks Yelp drinks for doubling my pleasure!
author: Cindy W.

description:
GUYS pay attention!


About six months ago I dragged my then BF to Rye Bar to meet Lulu P and an entourage of friends and friends of friends. 

You ever walk into a place with your BF and suddenly feel so overwhelmed with the SCENE?  The swanky lighting.  The white noise of happy laughing drunks.  The undercurrent of flirtation in which you are not allowed out of respect to your BF?? 

BUT you feel like letting go of his hand which is holding onto yours . . .  

** A RED FLAG **


Well lemme tell you . . .  You don't need a degree in Ultrasound Physics to know what your own self is telling you.  I MISS BEING SINGLE.  HE'S NOT THE ONE.  NEED TO BREAK UP.  Not now.  Maybe after a drink.  Maybe start a fight tonight and say 'It's me, not you!' 

Never mind the voices.  I was just having too much of a good time.  The space, like Redwood Bar was pretty Def to Fresh.  

"This isn't working.  Let's be friends cause we can be friends forever versus hating and resenting each other for the next 3 months and never talking again."

And Lulu P was in her element.  Girls will be girls will be girls cause we are girls.  

"This isn't working.  Maybe we should see other people.  I mean, um, it's not the end of the world if it doesn't work out for us."  (And yes, I thought about stealing a line from Sixteen Candles the movie).

So my BF goes to the bar and gets me a drink.  I'm sipping and along comes Lulu P and her gregarious self.  Wahahahahah!  Blotty blotty.  Blotty.  Blotty.  Wahahahahah!  

SO THIS IS WHERE IT GETS ALL SCREWED UP.  Read Below.

My then BF asks Lulu P if she wants a drink.  She says she'll have what I'm drinking.  BF proceeds to wait at the bar for about 3 minutes for a bartender.  Loses patience.  Turns to Lulu P and says something like "OH WELL.  YOU'LL HAVE TO TRY FOR YOURSELF LATER."

Wha?  WTF?  Is chivalry dead or is my boyfriend the biggest ill-behaved fool on the face of this rotating planet ???

Needless to say you know how the story ends.  Blotty blotty.  Blotty.  Blotty.  Wahahahahah!  


5 Stars for closing a door so another one can open.
author: NISHisHOT g.

description:
Don't worry, I typically don't write my reviews sloshed, but after a particularly rousing and long (5 hour long) happy hour at Rye, I'm inspired.

You see, it all started with Brian Barneclo. The artist. I met him at an event last night while he was doing some live painting. He was painting live. Oh, you know what I mean. Anyway, I walked into Rye tonight and saw his paintings hung all around the place. I was so excited... For me, his paintings capture very essence of San Francisco. So, I started to drink.

Those who know Rye know the specialty cocktail menu never disappoints, and lest you think you've tried them all, there's always a new special on the chalk board. I started with the absinthe drink with muddled strawberries and moved on to the gin basil gimlet. Well, absinthe makes me loopy and gimlets are just so damn drinkable. But who can resist with all of the ice crushing, fruit muddling and heavy pouring going on?

Brian Barneclo, I blame you.
author: Nicole G.

description: Basil gimlets here are tasty!  The bartenders are great...I should really call them mixologists.  If you want to try something new that suits your palette, the bartenders are very helpful and friendly.  When it gets busy though, it's hard to get that same help and friendliness out of them. Regardless, there are great drinks here and it's a cool space with a nice ambiance.  Not gonna lie though, it does get touristy on the weekend and you may want to avoid that by going early or on a weekday.
author: Tara K.

description:
It's hard to balance a sophisticated atmosphere with a casual vibe in San Francisco where you can wear jeans and t-shirt pretty much everywhere.  Most bars attempting to do it are a sad knock off of New York or LA.  But Rye does it well.

I love the exposed brick, thoughtful interiors, great selection of drinks, and overall look of this place.  The music isn't way too loud and its a great place to meet up with friends where you can actually talk and have a great drink.  Their cocktail choices are interesting and STRONG!  This bar is two blocks from my house and I often suggest it for meeting up and catching up with friends and people visiting from out of town.

The one very minor complaint I have is that their bar staff are SLOW.  There could be two of you and you'll wait 10 minutes for a drink.  If it's busy, grab some popcorn!  That said, they totally know what they're doing and many of their drinks are complicated.  Once I get the drink I usually forgive them, but my one suggestion would be that their bar staff step it up a bit.

The drinks are also expensive, but not ridiculous.  They are worth it, but I couldn't afford to come here frequently.

If you have friends coming in from out of town and want a cute, non-pretentious, but very sophisticated cocktail experience then I would definitely suggest Rye.
author: Daniel H.

description: It's not in a great neighborhood, but it's nice inside.  Nothing super special about it.  The bartenders were nice and attentive and made good drinks.  Drinks were normal price... like 5 drinks for $42.... good crowd but never got super crowded, which was nice...  they have a small pool table in the back and a little closed off outside area (for smokers?)  didn't have to go to the bathroom so couldn't tell you about that...... I think they were playing some 80's music... billy idol and belinda carlisle? she sings "I get weak" right?  music was at the right volume...
author: Easter E.

description:
It's ALL about the Old Cuban at Rye for me. My only complaint is that I don't have the option of ordering the drink in the 32oz size. The drinks are small so you have to sip and savor every moment because they are so effen delicious, but be careful, they creep up on you and pack a punch. 

I have been wanting to go to Rye for quite some time now, based on the recommendations of friends in SF. Last week, during one of my many trips to SF from LA, I finally got to experience Rye, and lemme tell you boys and girls, it did NOT disappoint. This, in fact, is the epitome of MY kind of bar; rad art on the walls, low key vibe, great bartenders who are experts in their craft (yes, muddling & mixing the perfect drink, is a craft to me), minimal amount of clutter so there is plenty of standing and sitting room. We were here on a Tuesday night, and it was late, so it wasn't packed but it certainly wasn't empty. I imagine this place does get packed, especially on the weekends and during happy hour. There is an outdoor smoking area (bonus) and clean bathrooms (double bonus). 

Funny enough, the day after I visited Rye, I attended a happy hour event put on at the Farmer's Market in SF, to celebrate Cocktail Week and the peeps from Rye just so happened to be there. I ran into one of the bartenders from the night before and she was super sweet. I had to give her props in person because that's just how I do. I will most def be back to visit Rye again and again.
author: Aunny B.

description:
If i'm in this area, a visit to Rye and B&B is almost guaranteed to be happening. I really like the vibe here!

This is a reeeaally chill spot to grab deliciously well-made drinks. They have a pool table in the back. I've never played pool here and have no idea who i have to kill to get in a game but i've never really bothered to try either.

The basil gimlet is indeed delicious. I've found that whatever the drink of the day is at the time is usually pretty good too! :)
author: Kevin H.

description: This bar is great I like to start here early evening on Saturday's.  I like to just grab some kind of simple whiskey cocktail and start relaxing.  The bartenders here have always been awesome to me.  They generally give good suggestions and make great drinks.  I've never been in here when it's super-packed, which I know is how it gets later in the evening, so I can't comment on how it is then.  Anyways...I dig it as a place to lounge and grab a good whiskey drink early in the evening.
author: Ted G.

description: This is a pretty nice place to check out on a friday night or saturday night. It's not too close from all the market area shops and other bars around there, but it's a decent distance away. Didn't like their beer selection though, but i'm pretty not as classy as some of their regular clientele I guess. My girlfriend had the basil gimlet and she thought it was pretty good.
author: Tom I.

description:
We live in a world of excess. 

Where once some small good would satisfy, we overindulge in pleasurable explosions.

Rye's basil-infused gimlet is slight on syrup and strong on flavor.

To turn a tired day into a pleasant afternoon.

To turn a lost credit card into seeing new places, comp drinks, and visiting new friends.

How very satisfying.
author: Keane L.

description:
You know how I know you're gay?

Cause you listen to Goldfrapp...

Ok, so ya, I love lesbian rock. Sue me. It's my thing. And it helps that my token gay friend has the best taste in music ever and is constantly introducing me to the hottest new repressed, emo chick-rock.

Most bars in this grand city must have tone def staff or just prefer to get funky to electronic remixes of bad pop songs that were crap even before the remix.

But Rye, oh my dear Rye, knows their shit. I'm telling you, if I can sip my frosty dirty martini while listening to "Number One" (I know, it sounds like she's referring to pee, but she's not, so just go with it) instead of the new R. Kelly song that makes me want to vurp my precious olives back up, I'll dry hump your leg in a nanosecond. Sound inviting? Cause it should. I'm that good. Well, not really. But I'll totally gossip with you and tell you totally inappropriate things I should never repeat. Deal?

In addition to the totally delectable dyke tunes this bar offers some amazing drinks that knock me on my ass, which to be quite honest, isn't that hard of a feat to accomplish. But the drinks are damn tasty. I haven't tried the fancy shit like raspberry, honey, mint gimlet with a dash of lavender body oil and a hint of vitamin E, but the dirty Ketel martinis treat me like a rock star.

The decor is modern, yet homey, although I will bitch a little about NEVER getting a seat here. Come on ladies, aren't those ass cheeks getting tired from sitting in the same spot for five hours straight? Why don't I help you get up and walk around a little? Well, soooorrrry! I just think your hooker ass has been taking up all the g-d damn seats for days! I mean my bad. You sit back down. I'll just stand here next to you and rub my blisters for a while.

The crowd varies from douche central (if The Ambassador is turning away crowds) to alright; I can hang with these folks as long as they stay the fuck off my toes and don't spill my delicious drink.

Another reason why I think this place is swank is because the few times I've come here the bouncer comments on how good I look in my driver's license photo. Dude, I'd stand in line at Dolce for three hours if the bouncers told me I looked hot in my ID. Err, ok, getting ahead of myself. But the bouncer at Rye can rub my blisters any day.
author: Sammy S.

description:
Despite my total disaappoinitment, I will actually review this place. Yelpers, you SHOULD WRITE BETTER!!!!!

The drinks WERE great. But then again I confused myself with Never Never Land. NEVERMIND!!! I think Peter Pan might be barely be satisfied!

I felt back like I was at my old tea party where we PRETENDED to DRINK! But, comparing the level of consumption, I will TAKE THAT BACK: Tinkerbell might barely be satisfied. Imagine a champagne glass that is literally half full. 

To add an insult, I DID go to Swig afterwords and had a BEYOND a fabulous time. RECONSIDER!!!!!!!!!!

BTW, no table service. It's like huntin for your own meat!

As good as the taste of the drinks was, the Prohibition was still pouring DIRTY CRAZY, and I KNOW I KNOW it's the quality, not the quantity, but when you leave a bar more parched than after crossing the SAHARA, one HAS TO RECONSIDER!
author: Yelena K.

description:
Swanky bar does not equate chode bar. 

Just because an establishment serves $9 drinks (award-winning at that) doesn't mean it attracts a Marina crowd. Rye stands in a category of its own: classy dive. Mellow, low-key vibe yet your man could wear cuff-links and not be beaten with a cue stick. 

The basil gimlet is orgasmic. So is the vodka with blackberries, which was comped to us because the bartenderess made too many. :) 

Rye, you are one class act.
author: Suzanne R.

description:
So it was Bobo's birthday, which means that even though it's a Monday night and we're all pretty pooped from getting back to the work week, we rally the troops, and somehow manage to get ourselves all dolled up to head to the TL for some drunken revelry. 'Cause that's where he wants to go. And whatever Bobo wants...well, you know where I'm going with that. And Bobo hangs with some pretty fierce Russians. So vodka shots were gonna be on hand, in some pretty serious amounts. And work on Tuesday be damned.

Rye is pretty great for a mid-sized birthday party on a Monday night. It's pretty easy to take over the bottom section of the bar and/or the smoking patio. The music is pretty all right. At times, we were happily bopping along with the selections, other times, we felt that they missed the mark entirely. But overall, mostly non-offensive.

Cans of PBR, generous vodka shots, frou frou cocktails, and smoking in the patio on Geary in the TL. Not a bad way to spend a Monday night. 

But if you stand too close to the wire fence keeping the sidewalk people on the sidewalk and the smokers on the patio, make sure that you don't stand wallet-out, or you may be pretty quickly pickpocketed. We found out (almost) the hard-way.
author: Rachel F.

description: I do like this place but it does have it's flaws. First of all the bar area is way too small for the amount of people in there so you will be bumping into tons of people trying to get drinks, careful not to spill. The drinks were average price for the city and the neighborhood was chill enough for us to find some parking but you may not always be so lucky so have a backup plan. There is a pool table in the back near the bar and that's nice and all but it takes up a bunch of room that could go to the bar but that's another story. They have an outdoor smoking area which is caged into the actual bar which I really liked. Instead of going outside and getting your hand stamped and getting hasseled to get back in, you can just go outside and still be in the bar to get some air or a smoke if that's what you're into. Chill atmosphere except for a few bitches trying to start drama but we shut it down and had a good rest of the night.
author: Jeromy G.

description:
Rye's kind of like an unassuming, slightly edgy female that nevertheless manages to effortlessly exude class and sophistication... well, at least if you catch her on a Tuesday night.

Went there on a weeknight so it was all wide open spaces and chillness. 
The cocktail list was solid, the bartenders were friendly, knowledgeable and pro, the atmosphere was legitimately loungey yet not snooty. I imagine this place to get crowded on the weekends, so I'd probably keep to a midweek drink, although it does start getting more buzzy around midnight.

$10 regular cocktails, $13 specialty.
author: Chieh T.

description:
Good goody goodness! Basil gimlet! X- cellental!!! 
Came here for happy hour didn't get to try all the recommended drinks, since this light weight drinker is drunk within matters of minutes!!! LoL 
But goodness, the bartender was great!! 
Not being too busy is a plus!!
author: Monika T.

description:
Several weeknight visits to Rye. What am I doing in the TL? 

I can't help staring up at the back wall. Brick and wine bottles. The bar is small, almost cute. I still order from the drink menu because I am indecisive. I want to try everything. The bartenders are attentive, ready to whip up the next order.

There is a guy with a horrific shirt. The handful of us can't keep our eyes off of it. He thinks we're checking him out. Quit walking past us, and we'll stop staring. I shouldn't laugh because I've walked in wearing sweatshirt and jeans. But no, nobody's checking me out.

$10 drinks - They're using real fruit; they must be healthy, right? I shouldn't be going there ALL the time, but I'm tempted. It's a favorite of new friends. 

Update - An extra star for dear friends' newfound happiness.
author: Tinna H.

description:
So, last night I took a little stroll up Jones to hit Rye for a drink - Ahhh, how I do love a stroll through the 'Loin...

The first thing I noticed about Rye was the giant rat cage, I mean smoking area, that they have out front...How reminiscent of an RJR test lab - quite the visual...I wonder if PETS (People for the Ethical Treatment of Smokers) will come and liberate all the poor well dressed hipsters locked in the cage?

Enough of that, upon entering I saddled up to the bar for a scotch and wouldn't you know it...No Talisker, after one reviewers scotchy, scotch, scotch comments ala Anchorman, I was expecting a bit of a wider selection but alas it was not to be. My disappointment was quickly handled via tried and true bar first aid...I applied Glenmoranghie to the wound liberally...

Now Rye seems to be noted for it's mixed drinks...I will say that I am not been much of a mixed cocktail guy of late - I'm settling into a more refined stage in my drinking evolution (the expensive, tasty, hard stuff on the rocks) - but, I was given a cocktail when my scotch glass runneth dry and while it did have peach something-or-the-other in it (which usually instantly provokes projectile vomiting) it was quite tasty and so doing what I do, I drank it...I never did quite catch the name of it but it was like a fine dessert after a meal of scotch and topped off the evening in a fine fashion.

The venue is interesting and I will have to go back to check the vibe on a weekend as a Wednesday night is generally not indicative of a bars true character but I will say that what I saw I liked.
author: Todd E.

description: Ultra-chic, minimalistic and modern, yet surprisingly comfortable, Rye forever ruined me on the whole Whiskey Sour experience.  Upon my first sip, I had a Ratatouille moment harkening back to my youth.  Orange Julius.  Future Whiskey Sours would never have a chance.
author: R Y.

description:
Simplicity is Bliss! 
Great place for cocktails with one of the sweetest Bartenders Ive met! Helpful, friendly and makes killer cocktails. The place is the best on a weekday. A little more intimate and not so showy showy. 

Worth entering into the loin...
author: Dee C.

description:
I'll definitely go back.

There is something about this bar that is captivating. Maybe it was because I went at an early hour (6ish) when you could still enjoy the empty stillness of a modern-esque bar with really warm overtones. 

The "cage" you ask? I love it! Genius. Even though I don't smoke I can only imagine how that cage has been a refuge for people who want a cig but don't want the hassel of the Tenderloin street peeps. 

Hmmm... maybe it was the peach fizz cocktail... or the kiwi infused cocktail... or the vodka martini. I'll never know what it was exactly. But who needs to "know". I'll be back for sure.
author: Stephanie I.

description:
OK...being review 247, I'm sure there isn't much else i can say about this place that hasn't already been said.  so i apologize for the non-useful, non-funny, non-cool review that i will write following this paragraph. 

Last night i went here for my second time ever with the same friend who accompanied me the first time.  Let me start off by saying that if the bartender didn't have a wedding band on, id be on that.  He not only was a total sweetheart, and a hottie, but is an expert mixologist.  Last time he was experimenting with the creation of a drink called the Pearl.  A champagne cocktail that we were delighted to see as a permanent resident on the menu.  But i digress, cuz neither of us had that this time.

I HATE GIN....seriously hate it.  But I had the Basil Gimlet, and knowing that it had no hint of gin taste, because i ordered it last time as well, it proved to be totally refreshing on my palette.  We then asked what we should get for our second drink.  The other hottie male bartender suggested The Flash.  Seeing as though it was another gin drink i was a little hesitant, but he insisted that it would change our lives.  A perfect mix of sweet and sour, cucumber, kiwi, gin and probably a bit of magic had me convinced at the first sip. Life changing.  Not that often one can say that about a drink, but it was true.  So true in fact that we both ordered another one, and got one for our third person who had just joined us.  

I know that i woke up today a new woman.  Thats saying something.  Life changing....fo realz.
author: Lauren F.

description:
Gorgeous bar. The atmosphere is simple and chic. 
Friendly and helpful staff. 
Delicious drinks. 

Favorite bar in San Francisco. You have to go here!
author: Alexandra D.

description:
Accessible classics. Wonderful touch of vermouth in most of the whiskey cocktails defeats the standard rye-bitters-orange doldrums.

Recommended: "birds of a feather"
author: Alex B.

description:
I have visited Rye twice, once when it first opened and again with the party-of-Yelp after seeing Love, Janis at the Marines Memorial Theater.

While I think that the space is tastefully decorated, my exasperation switch goes on almost immediately for the long time it takes to order a drink and the noise level.  

This is a hip and popular bar, and I can understand why a lot of people are drawn to it.   I would certainly drink here over going to the Clift.  If I can find a time to visit when it is less crowded, I may return, otherwise,  I will choose a more intimate setting for my imbibing adventures.

Update:  An analogy came to mind as I was thinking about my experience at Rye.  Rye is like the beautiful guy that you know who has to has amazing clothes and uses expensive hair products, but when you stop to consider it, you realize he's told the same story three times, and hasn't heard a word you've said.  Rye is definitely attractive, but it lacks soul, heart, and on the most basic level, personality.
author: Liz S.

description:
"Dreams : the royal road to our subconscious". .Freud

I dreamt of being held prisoner in cages, not once, not twice but many times. A beautiful goddess appears in my last dream and tells me

"Follow your dreams baby. I will be there for you"

and I wake up and start walking in a dream-like haze down Geary towards Union Square. Have you ever been on a 2 CB trip where one part of the mind is totally dreaming and the other part totally active, awake, observing the lucidity of your dreams? That was me.

I suddenly spot the black cages of my dreams and I step in to a magical kingdom called Rye and am warmly greeted by  the most gorgeous Cocktail waitress  on earth. She seats me on a cozy bench and goes to fetch the menu when I suddenly smell  a whiff of Chanel and I turn my head and  see a smiling goddess telling me

"You believed in your dream and now it is true. You can get anything you want as long as you keep having a dream"

I turn my attention to the cocktail menu and the moment I read " basil gimlet" the menu transforms into a cocktail glass and I am drinking out of it. 
 Mind-blowing  Mojitos, maddening margaritas, 
the more we keep  drinking, the   fuller our glasses  become. And then....

I wake up in the  morning to the smell of Chanel on my bed( and a missing condom). Sight, smell, touch...the reality of our senses are delusional and my mind wanders back to the higher reality of my "dream" last night and I savor in the fresh memories of Rye.
author: Kaustav C.

description:
If I remember only one thing from my life on earth, it will be the basil gimlet.  Once upon a time there was a place that made margaritas with cilantro - they'd shake it and serve it up in a martini glass.  This was my first love affair with herbs in my cocktails.  The bastards stopped.
Rye blows that place out of the water, although if they wanted to start making those margs, oh, for summer or something, I'd totally get behind it.  * hint hint *
The service was stellar and not snotty or annoyed at all when we asked for recommendations.
**UPDATE**
John, I saw the ring, I know you're married.  But, I'm totally in love with you a little for making me that yummy cilantro lemon gimlet.  It was perfection.  *mwah!*
author: Jennifer D.

description:
If you are a fan of mixed drinks, this is the place to go.  Rye squeezes all of their fruit right before they make your drink, and the bar tenders really know what they are doing.  My favorite is the Caipirinha- perfect mix of tart and booze!!! 

This is a great lounge to hang with friends and the music is always good and keeps moving.
author: Kyra W.

description:
Three things they've done right:

1. ATMOSPHERE.  They got this right, from the wood, steele, and brick interior replete with tasteful art, to the dark lighting and sense of calm chic.

2. CLIENTELE.  Not too many people, not too few...and they are diverse, have fun outfits, and seem talkative and not overly bourgie.  

3. PIONEERING DRINKS.  I made the mistake of ordering my usual Jim Beam and whiskey, only to have Nish point out their veritable library of rare and unique alcohol selection.  I corrected the situation by having several more above-par drinks accented by frothy egg-whites, exotic fruits, and hard-to-find liquor.  You really can't go wrong here if you ask for the bartender's recommendation or if you order off the drink menu.
author: Sid D.

description:
I generally don't do cocktails. In every other bar, I prefer beer. Wine at a restaurant or swank party. That all changed when I entered Rye.

The care and precision that goes into the cocktails at Rye raises mixing to an art form. That the bartender also designed this beautiful space stands to reason. It is tasteful, cool and comfortable.

The Rye Gold Fizz and his inventive take on a rye mint julep shifted my perception literally and figuratively. My non-alcoholic wife had the most delicious fresh limeade either of us ever tasted.
author: Andy R.

description: old fashioned cure all was terrible. too much clove, made my mouth go numb. but drinks weren't terribly priced, great atmosphere. was right across the street from where we were staying. not enough seating, but a great place.
author: Korene D.

description:
Stopped in last night for the monthly bartender contest, but never actually sampled any of the concoctions.  Really I was there to hang with my roommie and her PR crew while they schmoozed.   

Take the PR people with you to a new bar and they will fearlessly barge into a table of strangers and introduce themselves, and introduce me, the introvert.  Good people to have on your side.

The bar is well-laid out, but for some reason, people seem to congregate along the bar  five deep, when there is so much room to hang out, and I got drinks faster by going to the end of the bar and not waiting in the throng.

Their cocktails are superb, the champagne was cold and tasty, and they keep PBR in cans on hand, but tragically not the tall ones.  If you want a beer list or cocktail menu, you have to ask for it.  Strangely they don't keep them on the bar.

I really had no complaints, especially since roomie's boss bought the first round, her coworker bought the second (I at least kicked in the tip), and before I could order my third, a former student sauntered in and bought me a beer.  I guess that leaves me no room to comment on the prices.

The interior is nice, with lots of dark wood, tall ceilings and comfortable places to lounge, but too few places to sit.  It felt a little crowded, despite the small number of people in the place.  The wine cage around the bathroom door is an interesting piece, however I wish that the door to the smoking cage swung closed of it's own accord, but hey, they have a smoking cage!
author: Quinn S.

description:
I love the fact that they have a 'Outside' / side walk smoking area. Even though I am not a smoker but its cool. 
There drinking menu is very tasty and the bartenders are all great.
The decor reminds me of like a industrial/modern bar. Which is my style.
I will be back to chill out with my friends.
author: Der Maibaum L.

description:
Rye is pretty solid.  Not foo-foo like I expected, and their drinks rival those at Bourbon and Branch.  Quite a selection of different types of alcohol as well...they had Reyka vodka that my friend Samantha suggested- very smooth.  Better than Grey Goose I thought.  (for all those that are thinking: could there be such a thing??? yes.)

I like the space- a very rustic feel, spacious and open as well.  The outdoor patio is nice too...its also spacious and very aired out.  Essential for a smoking patio- unlike the one at Harlot that tends to become a hotbox of cigarette smoke.  One suggestion: more seating out there would be nice.

Out of the 3 drinks I had there, 2 were very good.  The basil gimlet was SO refreshing and crisp.  A nice alternative to mint or plain lime.  Next, I had the Prosecco which was reasonably priced and pretty high quality.  Also very refreshing and crisp.  The third drink sucked- a horrendous Chartreuse shot that my boyfriend insisted we all have...horrible.  However, that doesn't reflect Rye...just my bf's taste. ; )
author: Genevieve M.

description:
I always end up here. I know it's a cool place.  They have great drinks.  

Still....

HOLY MOTHER OF JEEBUS!!! 
It took 20 minutes to get a drink and I was seated at the bar! 

Out of the two bartenders, one was catering to only the side area of the bar by the booth while the other took whole rest of the bar.  It was ridiculous. There wasn't even any "What can I get you"..just a blank stare waiting for an order.

The saving grace being the table area where there was room to move and breathe. 

I'll still come back because quite frankly everyone and their mother loves this place.  I'll never suggest it though.
author: Jay H.

description:
LOVE this place!

The day I visited, I looked like yesterday's fermented garbage. My hair was up, glasses on, and I had on a t-shirt (not a cute one but a slightly baggy one LOL!) with jeans.... Needless to say I was QUITE apprehensive to venture in.

But from the bouncer (who gave me a warm welcome!!), the crowd, to even the bartenders, everyone was SO kind! The ambiance is great and they have really cool obscure beers =) I will DEFINITELY be back!!

Man I love SF!! ...or it could be I've lived in NYC too long where people wear their cocktail dresses just to go to the corner deli. If I had shown up at a bar like this, in the attire I was in over there, people would've automatically assumed I am homeless =/ I am really glad to be back.


added: uhhh how come it says Nob Hill? Isn't this still the TL??? just wondering
author: Mona N.

description:
The bartenders are always so sweet and friendly. I come here when I'm in the neighborhood before or after dinner. 

I tend to always stick with the two classic rye drinks, the Manhattan and the Sazerac.
author: Juliane N.

description:
I first discovered this quaint little venue in the tendernob about six months and said to myself... "this could possibly make it's way into my top two list of favorite bars in the bay area"

Six months later, i have frequented this location at least every other week and the feeling has not gone away. 

Subtle yet vibrant decor: red brick walls, wine rack, chalk art, hardwood ceiling, ambient lighting and minimally spaced seating, outdoor smoking cage, make this place a comfortable hang out spot after work hours during the week. 

The bartenders are true mixologists in the art of the cocktail and as a trade off you must be patient for your drinks. If possible avoid the busy nights which typically are thursday thru saturday if you'd like to truly experience this place. 

the ONE special is normally posted on the chalk board behind the bar but it's best to walk in with a list of drinks you'd like to try for the evening. 

I normally take advantage of their  fresh selection of fruits by ordering a few rounds of blackberry lemon drops. Huckleberry when they are in season. As a side note, most drinks are misleadingly strong.
author: Earlvin R.

description:
God they muddle with love here.  The bartender all but made love to my drink while passionately muddling my kumquat cocktail... A groovy industrial loft like atmosphere.  

Plus I just like to say, "I would like the Kumquat Cocktail."....

Kumquat cocktail.
Kumquat cocktail.
Kumquat cocktail.
author: Jenny M.

description:
Greg L. and Co. took great care of all the thristy yelpers the other night.

Rye is awesome -- sleek and gorgeous decor and fabulous cocktails. The talented bartenders have an impressive selection of fresh seasonal ingredients to create their specialty cocktails. For instance, I consumed several peach cobblers: vodka, peach liqueur, fresh peach, and mint all muddled together in glorious deliciousness!

I can't wait to return and try some of the specialty whiskey cocktails...
************
Rye continues to satisfy with the great drinks... I had a "black and blue" recently with fresh blackberries and blueberries from the farmer's market that very morning. The staff is a pleasure, the drinks are delicious, and the space is gorgeous.
author: Jill M.

description:
I liked pretty much everything about this place, as long as I'm not out and in the mood for a dance club like atmosphere.  This is definitely a lounge where drinks and conversations are to be had.  And boy were the drinks good!  My friend and I tried to order the basil gimlet, since so many other Yelpers raved about it, but they were out of basil!  Booo...!  The bartender was very nice about it all and apologized but said he's been making pretty much nothing else all night so that's why there was no more...which seems like a plausible explanation right? 

My friend had the cranberry cocktail (complete with real cranberries) and I had the blueberry cocktail and they were both too good.  Literally.  I watched him pour the vodka, but I couldn't taste any alcohol whatsoever.  Great drinks.  The apple cocktail was a nice cocktail as well, but the apple brandy takes a bit getting used to...

Previous Yelpers noted the elegant yet non-pretentious vibe of the place and I'd have to agree.  Bouncers/door men were friendly, bartenders were nice (and the one guy with black hair was kinda hot -- if you're reading this PM me for my number), the crowd was not annoying at all, and I actually felt comfortable taking my shoes off...

I'll be back...
author: LaSha G.

description:
After an amazing five course meal at Brick on new years eve, my friends and I stumbled over to Rye.  This was not our first visit to Rye but I adore Rye so much that we made it our new years venue.  I am soooo anti paying $150 to go somewhere on new years just to rub elbows with a bunch of douchebags and fight to get a drink at the open bar.  


Anyway, I can't drink $150 worth of mandarin and sevens.  I didn't care as much about the champagne (although I do love quoting Christopher Walken "fine champagna!").   It is all about the basil gimlets.  I don't even know what the other drinks are like because to me this is the only drink on the menu.  It's THAT good.
author: Rosie F.

description:
I've been to Rye a handful of times, and generally for some sort of after-work event where I'm there for about 30 minutes, have a cocktail, and then dash to the BART station to head on home.
