This place gets bonus pints for treating us all with respect and not avoiding us because most of us communicated only in sign language.  There was no condescending behavior from any of the staff here - thank you very much.

Not only was I impressed with the Manhattan, I was also impressed with the basil gimlet, and I was also very impressed that they use fresh ingredients (berries, fruit, herbs) in their cocktails.  They seem to be big on muddling there.

They easily accommodated our large group in a cozy corner that had long couches and chairs and a long table.  My only real complaint was that the table was too low and one had to reach far over to put their drink down.
author: Asteridae A.

description:
Went here for a celebration, and was treated like a queen...but so was everyone else!

Service was great, bartender (Aaron, I believe) was fabulous and really enjoys and understands mixology, and the drinks were all pretty darn good. Not five stars only because I felt the drinks were a little expensive, but maybe that's because I've been getting some amazing deals lately.

I can't wait to go back!
author: Monika M.

description: Fun location in the tenderloin.  Mixed drinks are pretty tasty.  Love the little outdoor part of the bar where you can smoke or just hang out. The place gets really crowded on the weekends.  The space is actually quite small and it's quite a popular spot.  You may have to wait a little to get into Rye on a busy weekend.
author: Ka C.

description:
Cool, comfortable, and close to my apartment.  That pretty much covers my requirements for a good bar.  It can a bit crowded on the weekends, but what bar doesn't.  The bartenders are cool and easy to talk to and they really seem to know there stuff.  In other words, Rye isn't sticking a bunch of no talent hacks behind the bar unlike some other watering holes in the city.  

Pool table and cool chalk art on the wall makes this place extra special.  kisses.
author: Alexis M.

description:
I'm not sure about this bar. The staff is nice enough and the drinks are strong enough but I don't think I like the decor. It feels too industrial for my taste and I'm even a concrete loft-dwelling type of girl. I feel cramped and cold/detached at the same time when I'm at Rye. I'm not sure if I "get" the scene here either. Explain to me how a bar can feel confused? 

A gf of mine makes a regular weeknight habit of this bar though so I may just have to give that a shot and see.
author: Cindy P.

description:
When: Saturday night, ~10:30pm

We went to Rye to celebrate a friend's birthday. It's a small, inconspicuous spot and easy to miss if you're not paying attention. First thing I noticed on the way in was a homeless man bugging the patrons hanging out on the smoking patio for money. Ah, the night scene in SF...

Inside: For a Saturday night, it wasn't too crowded. My group of seven people managed to snag a table after about 30 minutes of standing around. I hardly noticed the wait though, since it took me about that long to get the bartender's attention anyway.

Drinks: Specialty drinks run about $9-$10, but I have to admit they are quite good. Recommend the basil gimlet and the blood and sand cocktail.

The bartender: I was tended to by a guy bartender, who I have to call an elitist. He refused to make my friend a long island, and responded with some kind of comment about how he doesn't make "those kind of drinks." Ooookay. Sure he mixes up a mean-ass vodka tonic (glass of vodka with a splash of tonic), but seriously, don't be a prick. Given the cocktail menu, you wouldn't think a long island would be an issue.  It's not like we asked for a round of daquiris.

The venue: The bar gets quite crowded, so good luck getting in there to order your drinks. You're better off grabbing the cocktail waitress and having her bring them to you. The music is loud, but not to the point where you can't have a conversation with the people sitting next to you.

Final verdict: 3 stars for tasty drinks, but relatively bad service. I'd probably only go back if my friends insisted.
author: Amy C.

description: Finding a proper cocktail in San Francisco with the hundreds of bar/lounges scattered across the city, can be a tough task.  Specializing in Pre-prohibition style drinks, at a price of about $10 per cocktail, you will be getting more than your money's worth.  Just watch the bartender slave his or her way into making your drink.  Couple of favorites that depends on your mood is the Flash and the Dogpatch.  The set up is a dark minimalistic lounge feel with ample seating and an outdoor section for you smokers.
author: Jason A.

description:
This is a contender for my favorite bar in the city, and I'd have to say I've been to quite a few. Somehow the mood here always matches mine, whether it be more sociable or more private, I don't mind a little attitude thrown about here or there because, let's face it, all of SF can have that quality to it depending on how you look at it. 

This is also one of the few bars I've been to that's ventured to play with absinthe in their cocktails, always hitting it right. I have never, ever had a bad time here. Except for that one time when a gaggle of girls from LA/Orange County showed up and I wanted to stab my eardrums.
author: Paul W.

description:
I had such a great time here.  I had cucumber vodka and sodas, which were so refreshing.  Not many places have cucumber vodka, so I definitely have to come back just for that.  Thinking about it makes my mouth water, just a bit.  

The bartender we had was amazingly sweet, and unpretentious, which I've concluded, is a rarity in the city.  

For those of you that are on the sober-train (*high-five), they make a fine shirley temple, with house-made grenadine, and garnished with a decadent black cherry.  I know because my friend ordered one.  If you're off the wagon, get a dirty shirley...  mmm...

The ambiance was very cool, charming, and intimate.  There's heated outdoor seating, plenty of places to sit inside.  This is definitely a place you can bring a date, or a few friends.  It's finally nice to have a place to drink where you can hold a conversation without yelling.

I can't wait to go back.
author: Lilly T.

description:
Wonderful! First time at Rye... we got there early, like 10PM on a Sat nite and it wasn't crowded at all... my GF and I scored 2 seats at the bar for the next 2 hours and enjoyed ourselves. 

Our bartender was SO nice and very honest about the drinks... we enjoyed all our cocktails, particularly the vodka basil gimlet and caipirinha  ... not too crazy about the vodka cane (seemed like a breakfast drink)... They also use fresh ingredients (basil leaves, cucumbers, mint, egg whites, etc) .. very easy going crowd, laid back, good lighting... it's modern and loungy but at the same time very friendly, not an easy task to pull off. 

Will definitely go back, just wish it was walking distance to my home!
author: Nenette Y.

description:
It may have been that it was the day before new year's eve, but the place was not very busy when I went to Rye.   I like when the bar has a few more people - it's all about the atmosphere.  

I had one of their fancy cocktails - a basil gimlet.  It was interesting and pretty tasty, but started to wear on my taste buds towards the end.  

Overall, Rye is a decent place and I'd gladly return if suggested by others, but not my favorite bar in the city.
author: Angie C.

description:
Something bad happened.  I LOVE Rye, and the hot waitress Erika.  I love their vibe.  I love their drinks.  But now a new bar/club/place to stand in line has opened across the street from it and the vibe has totally changed.  Now it's packed full of 21 year old's pre loading before going into the club across the street, and the guys who love them. 

And all the people who are too uncool to get past the velvet rope of said club.   Mostly dudes.  In fact... I think it was all dudes.  And Hot Erika.  

I will still go here on school nights, but it's off my speed dial until The Ambassador loses their hype. Or relocates to Vegas.
author: Cosmolicious L.

description:
This is a really really cool bar, and I need to remind myself to come more often.  I've only been during the happy hours, and it's been a great place to hang out after work that's got great drinks, a great vibe, and it's not too crowded.  I really love the interior as well - minimal, sleek, but comfortable.  Oh yeah and the outdoor patio is a cage :) - how cool is that?  It can get pretty loud in there, that's my only complaint.

Update:  After writing this, I did return.  I'm an even bigger fan.  Not only do they have Chimay, but their cocktails rock.  I had the gin / kiwi / cucumber drink, and the tequila / pomegranate one.... both were super yummy.
author: Jenny S.

description:
In my opinion, the best bar in the TenderNob. It's got that trashy, divey feel but also a sophistication. And even though it's not exactly cheap, I've never felt that Rye tries to be exclusive or discriminating. Anyone can come here and live it up. 

The most interesting aspect of Rye is its interior: exposed brick, chalkboard artwork,  pool table, modern bar, films blasted on the wall, trendy seating, smoker's cage...

Rye is particularly known for its cocktails. As far as I'm concerned, they make a damn good mojito.
author: Andrew K.

description:
It was Thursday at 12AM. Roomie and I were still awake and thought...hmmm...let's go to the Tenderloin at this time of the night...

So, my partner in crime became all Ms. Interior Design on me when we got here. I don't blame her because the designs described sleek & upscale industrial interior architecture. Quite desirable. The lighting was somber...perfect for chillin' after work and the pool table w a group of players around made all the visit laid back and comfortable. The crowd was a mixture of businessmen, cocktail divas and probably 1 emo (kid sported the trademark skintight pants). 

Well, roomie approached the long wall stacked full of wine bottles and pointed out how perfect this wine holder would be in the living room of her dreams. 

We became chatty cathies towards the end of the night. The bartender sure knew how to mix up a storm with those candied like mojitos and he was great at preparing them with time and efficiency. The tables and chairs were inviting. Thus, releasing the blabber mouth in us...an ideal hangout for conversations and probably shouting them out over the electro music playing
author: Charmian D.

description:
I came on a Saturday night for a friend's birthday and the place was pretty poppin.  A good crowd and not overly so that you're constantly bumping shoulders with people, but it was getting close to that point.  I was unfortunate to be standing near a high traffic area with lots of congestion that I shoulder bumped more people than a defensive lineman does in a game.  If you were standing in a better area, then you'd be safe from danger.

Rye is very rustic with the brick walls and an almost dive bar-ish type of feel.  I didn't venture around the place, but it was quite quaint with it being a smaller venue for a lounge.  Oddly enough, I didn't buy any drinks that night, so I can't tell you how much the drinks were, but I think I heard from a friend that it was around $7 per drink (typical).  They also have an outdoor standing area right around the front, which is nice for those who want to get some fresh SF air for a change.  I wasn't paying attention to the music much, but it wasn't really a lot of music that I'm attuned to, but the good thing about it was that it wasn't so loud that I couldn't hear what people were saying to me when I'm standing next to them.

In terms of lounges go, this place is a cool place to chill at especially if you don't want to pay a cover to go drinking with the buddies.  I think Saturdays was a bit too busy, but I can imagine going here on random days and getting yourselves a booth and chat / drink your night away.  And I almost forgot, parking is not that good in this area, so if you're driving then expect about 20-30 minutes to find parking.
author: David Y.

description:
I like that there is a waitress walking around and taking your drink order.

This bar/lounge was pretty packed on a saturday night. we were overflow from those that got turned away from Slide (a-holes!) 

The music was very eclectic, from some really good hiphop to the violent femmes. They have a pool table. Bathrooms A-Ok and Clean. GREAT seating options. Smoking patio.

I wouldn't mind coming back! But next time I think I'll get a dark and stormy.
author: Maureen M.

description:
If you see me walking in to a bar, I expect one thing: liquor.  I don't think it's a lot to ask; after all, there's nothing else to be had while you're at a bar.  Right?

Well, the one problem I have with Rye is that it always takes me forever to get a drink.  The bar area is too small and often too crowded for me to push my way to the front and get a drink.  I don't think I've ever managed to get a drink in faster than 15 minutes there.

Other than that, though, Rye isn't a bad place.  I do wish the layout was slightly different as the bar is often a bottleneck for moving around the bar.  I love the fact that there's a patio.  Being able to hang out on the patio at midnight with a drink in my hand is something I love about Rye.  Granted, Geary Street isn't exactly the best view; but it's not about the view... it's about the people.
author: Kurt C.

description:
In town for a wedding, we went to Rye to meet up with friends the night before the wedding for a few drinks.

Location:

Fortunately our friends had selected a spot not far from our hotel, it was extremely convenient.  

Service:

Our waitress forgot our drink orders multiple times (and I was only there for 2-3)...and when she did remember...the drinks took forever to arrive.  

Though, during our final round of drinks, the staff did ask what we were celebrating and they gave us our last round in seemingly larger glasses.

Decor:

Cool wood paneling on the ceiling, wine bottles lined the back wall, very appropriate given its proximity to Napa.

Would I go again?  Probably not on my own...
author: Jackie Y.

description: When did this otherwise cool bar with great drinks turn into a dance club?
author: Owen T.

description: Great tasting drinks that are also strong - probably my favorite place in the city thus far for the quality of cocktails.
author: A I.

description:
This place is hot.  Both in terms of popularity and temperature.

I didn't get a chance to look at the menu because the bar was stacked 3-4 deep and, well, we got thirsty.  The drinks on the chalkboard caught our eyes so we had both of those!  First off was the Green Thumb, a mix of cuke vodka (love!!), muddled watermelon, fresh-squeezed lemon and basil.  This was pink in the glass, so maybe they should try another name... I was expecting green, obviously.  The watermelon-cuke-basil flavor was excellent.  Sweet and cool.  Next we tried the Widow's Walk - made with rye, du bonnet, strawberries, lemon and something else.  This was a very interesting drink and smelled like fermentation.  Very yeasty.  But I finished mine and half of my friend's.  She went back for another green thumb.  YUM.  Both of these were $10 each so it's not cheap, but each cocktail is so expertly made and tastes so wonderful that it's worth it.  I'll try the gimlets that everyone is talking about next time.

I like that you can reserve tables/benches too.  Nice vibe here.  I was looking forward to the bowls of M&Ms and Chex mix that someone else mentioned, but the fat kid in me was disappointed.
author: Laura B.

description: I'm a big drinker.  I've had almost every drink you can think of.   But when I went here I honestly had some drinks that I have never had in my life.  These guys aren't called Bartenders, they are called Mixologist.  I had a cucumber martini.  Freakin delish!  oh and they have a cool little patio facing downtown.  These two chicks packed and smoked a bowl right then and there!  I'm from So Cal and that would have gotten me thrown out so freakin fast!  so the ease that they did that was awesome.  Love Frisco and Rye!
author: Aaron C.

description: the basil gimlet were amazing, and they make really good old fashioned.
author: Javier R.

description: The Basil Gimlet was good, but I'd rather have a Buccaneer at Cantina.
author: Chris Y.

description: We wandered in after the other bar down the street refused to let us in since it was 1:30.  What a blessing that was!  From initial impression, there is nothing fantastic about this place.  The decor is... brick and bar.  Totally fine with me.  Let's keep the focus on the important stuff.  Drinking.  The bartenders are funny, hipster types, but they poor the drinks quick and strong.  I wish there was a twin bar in my hometown.  I'd be a regular.
author: Katy H.

description:
Very lovely lounge! The bartenders are cute (and friendly) and I saw bunches of cute young male patrons! Very cozy atmosphere and good music. It's close enough to other nightlife establishments to eliminate the need for constant driving. Their Sex on the Beach is very mellow but their Long Island Ice Teas somewhat...odd.

The vibe here was vivacious and cheerful. Will come again!
author: Joh W.

description:
"Drove my chevy to the levee,
 But the levee was dry.
 And them good old boys were drinkin' whiskey and"

Rye is full of contradictions, but thats a good thing.
As we first walk through the non-descript entrance, I notice 3 small, elegant metal letters as signage and the same embedded in the threshold. 

The interior is industrial but luxurious. Dark exposed industrial beams and hardware, and what looked like a wood slat ceiling. Tufted black leather and candle light makes it warm and cozy.

The detail that was put into this place is really a joy, because it is anything but precious.

The drinks are classics, but with a creative handmade twist. If you know and love the lower east side's Milk & Honey, you'd be pleased to find this place. Who takes the time to muttle blackberries?! Um, they do.

I never drink Gimlets, but the Basil Gimlet with Vodka is nice, twice. I hear its good with the trad Gin as well.
author: Helen J.

description:
I walked in and thought.. hmm, looks a lot like Rosewood. So, I shouldn't have been surprised to read Nish's writeup. I really like the stark interior, but it definitely feels cold if you get there early. 

It absolutely does not have the logistics for crowd flow working for it. DOES ANYONE KNOW A BAR THAT REALLY DOES? I thought it was pretty tough to get from the seating area past the bar to the rest rooms and then get a drink, etc. 

I will say that Jennifer is the crowning glory of the bar. She's the bomb. The Manhattan and the Basil Gimlets were my favorite. The apple bomb, blueberry lemon drop and the melon cooler were only soso. Definitely not a place to come for a heart-to-heart chat though. 

Oh, and they are still cash only... despite hearing that they were getting the credit card machine installed for quite some time.
author: Heidi L.

description:
I've only been here once but I really liked it. Simple design and approach. The bartender and owner was attentive to the drinks in the looks and taste. I will go back. Plus I love me some Whiskey...oooh weeyyy!!!

AB
author: Anthony B.

description:
The scene: A Wednesday night, after seeing "Love, Janis" at the Marine Memorial Theater.  

The people: Yelpers.

The drink:  A "Morrie" aka "The Drink that Jen Made with the Cucumber" 
Ability to stand after the Morrie (1 = able to drive, 10 = passed out): 6
Tastiness rating of the Morrie (back to the Yelp! scale, now): 5 stars

Coolness of Greg, owner and bartender: 5 stars
Coolness of Jen, bartender: 6 stars

The only thing I would change about Rye is to add some more stools in that back room.  I can see them causing problems when it's really busy, but when it's not, it would be nice to have more seating back there.  I also might consider one of those plastic curtain things for the smoking area, since the door obviously stays open, letting some smoke inside.  If you're not right by that door, though, it's not an issue.
author: Danielle F.

description:
Five stars for the drinks, no problem. But it's not the sort of place I'd want to hang out at -- it's a weird mix of open space, pool table, and booth seats. Just not that comfortable. Too loud for a chill bar, kind of a weird flow for a "stand around and yell at your friends" bar... not sure how to put it better. And the other yelp reviews are pretty accurate about the crowd.

The drinks are great. I was dumb and started off with a high-maintenance "this is how I like my drink" order, instead of testing the waters with one of their standards. It turns out that they have a Rye Manhattan already on the menu and I had unwittingly applied my own modifiers on top of it. Long story short, there was constructive interference and I got a drink that was way unbalanced on the sweet side. Props to the bartender for keeping it drinkable; in other circumstances I think it could have gone pretty badly.

The basil gimlet is amazing. Can I call it a revelation without sounding like a snooty choad? The basil is completely on target for this drink.

Well, you get the point. I'm repeating what everyone else is saying. I'm sure you already know whether or not you want to visit; you just need to get off your ass and do it.
author: Paul D.

description:
Rye is a favorite bar of mine whenever I am in the area.  The whole password and reservations thing with Bourbon & Branch is just too fussy and I am so not a fan of the Ambassador.

Rye's brick and brown hues are quite warm and inviting.  The place can surely get crowded but not claustrophobic.  There are little spots you and your friends can nestle in to catch up or people watch.

Most importantly, Rye is the reason I switched from mojitos to basil gimlets.  Yum!  I like them made with SF's No. 209 gin, but had the chance to try it with Damrak gin recently.  Rye hosted a mixology event for Damrak and Yelp's very own Nish was a judge.  Damrak gin drinks were on the house so I tried the basil gimlet as well as the cucumber gimlet.  My basil gimlet was a bit too limey this time but the cucumber gimlet hit the spot.

And to follow up on Joe B.'s comment about the top-notch bartendress, she actually placed in the top 3 out of 12 and gets to go to Amsterdam to compete!  Woo hoo!
author: Pelle Y.

description:
Jess!   Love this bar! 
Con la excepcion que no tiene corona.  Pero bueno, uno no puede tener todo.
author: N. C.

description:
Ok this place was cute and there were a few people of interest until we met some people who were just weird! 

Ummm if you're asking us at a bar if this is a good place to meet people occassionally we'll be nice but if it's a line pleasseeee just keep on walking, cuz these girls aren't interested. 

Enough said.
author: K T.

description:
First the good: Rye has the 2nd best Manhattans in the city.

Now the bad: I can't stand their variable drink pricing policy. Depending on how crowded it is, their Manhattan might cost $7 or it might cost $10. Suck!

Also, I've been dumped here. Twice! 

Despite all this, I keep coming back.
author: Brad L.

description:
I LOVE the drinks here...i always pick a fruit and ask the bartender to make me for a vodka based drink with it. I've never been dissapointed. My favourite drink off the menu is hte cucumber basil gimlet. 

I like the brick wall decor and the atmosphere. I also love that it is right next to  the original Osha Thai. Cant beat that.
author: Paawan K.

description:
The key to Rye is timing. after work on weekdays or weekends early in the night, it can definitely be enjoyable. The cocktail list is inventive and the atmosphere can be nice with the right size crowd. The seated area is nice and extra points for a smoking patio.

The problem is that once the clock strikes 10 or the people balance shifts over about 35, the place turns into the type of place I want to exit immediately. Suddenly there are girls in stringy tops booty shakin' and ex-frat guys in identical blue and white striped button up shirts slapping each other's backs... you get the picture. Time to go! 

Stick to happy hour at Rye and exit early, you'll be fine.
author: Nissa A.

description: I love this place. The drinks are  unique and tasty, the music is wonderful, and the ambiance  is great. The only downsides being how crowded it can get (having to weave through the crowd with a full glass in hand is no easy task!), and the slightly pricey drinks (average price being $9 not counting the tip; but then again most places cost about this much).
author: Samyuktha K.

description: You'd think a bar called Rye would have an awesome whiskey sour. Why was it bland? I had all my drinkin' cronies take a sip and we all agreed it sucked. That said, the basil gimlet lived up to its hype and the Dogpatch was a smoky delight. I can't remember the names of the other cocktails sampled. I'd say the place was a little understaffed the night we went. Very crowded and only one server and two bartenders. You'd think they'd be prepared for such crowds on a Saturday night, but the waitress was super friendly so all is forgiven.
author: Farah S.

description: One of my fave bars in SF. Medium sized sitting area to the right, pool table in the back, awesome bartenders and delicious drinks! Try the Flash & Fireside...soo good! Come early as it does get packed later in the evening.
author: Cheryl P.

description: I was on a tenderloin crawl hitting some pretty seedy spots with some friends until we happened across this place. It was like an oasis in the ghetto. Swanky joint with a lot of brown bottles on the wall. The Rye Manhattan I ordered was as good as they get. I was standing at the bar and watched the bartender make some a slew of really nice drinks for other customers so it is definitely a legit drinking establishment....and most importantly a safe haven while trowling around in the 'loin.
author: Nick M.

description: Walked in the door and got smacked in the face with the heat of the place.  Made a B-line for the smoking patio where we met some really groovy people and hung out people watching til they closed down. They didn't get much of my business but I got nuthin against them.
author: Whryne R.

description: Love the open, spare interior. Concrete floor and walls with exposed brick on one side. Not much seating, Rye is meant for mingling while sipping on lovingly crafted cocktails. The bartenders spare no expense in preparing each one. In my case, slicing fresh kiwis, shaking to perfection and even sliding the rind of a lime around the rim. Will throw in with the rest in saying the Basil Gimlet, though not on the menu, is not to be missed!
author: Justin M.

description:
happening lounge but weird looking smoking cage
$8 drinks, music not too loud
known for cocktails like basil gimlet
all these places looking the same, i.e. John Colins, etc.
good to start here with out of town guests
from here you could walk to a lot of other places: Swig, Ambassador, Redwood Room, Le Colonial, etc.
fills up regularly
author: Rob C.

description:
Lets see here...

Drinks are well made and contain fresh ingredients, but small.
Its kinda swank and relatively low on the d-bag quotient, but it gets crowded and hot.
Music. Was there music? I can't remember...not a good sign.
Basil gimlet (gin, fools) and sazerac were very good.

Wanted to give it a 3.5...they are not cash only, so I'll upgrade it. I'll be back, but on  weeknight, and early.
author: Rainer P.

description:
I gave this place four stars because I would come here again if I was in the area.  My wife and a friend visited this place on Saturday night.

The wood and brick decor give this place a sophisticated yet down to earth feel.  I thought the crowd was cool, people were well dressed (but not too dressed up) and having a good time.

I did not have to wait too long for a drink at the bar, the bartenders were fast and had a heavy hand when pouring drinks.

It was a bit loud with the music, but not too loud where we could not hold a conversation.  Overall, a good experience.
author: Jaime T.

description:
Laid back bar/lounge in the upper Tenderloin.  Can get a little crowded, but there's still enough room to move around and it's not so noisy you can't hear the person you're chatting with.  Like other reviewers, I really enjoyed the decor.

Plus, their drinks are delicious, which makes this place top notch if you're trying to get your date drunk.  Their basil gimlet is superb!
author: Chris C.

description: Great approachable cocktails, unpretentious and comfortable. I think the ease of the place really added to our experience after waiting in lines at other trendy cocktail bars. We just wanted to sit and have a drink, no thrills! We got to sit at the bar and talk to the sweet bartender Douglas. He made an effort to talk cocktails with us and really figure out what we wanted. Fresh ingredients, simple setting, a great way to end the Thursday night. It was quiet, yet a day after St. Patrick's Day, so we lucked out on the small crowd. Quite the selection of liquors and the gin drinks are a must.
author: An T.

description:
I enjoyed the space, enjoyed the music, enjoyed the bartenders. What I didn't enjoy was the well gin that went into my $10 basil gimlet. Really guys? Really? 
I recently ate at Betelnut and had three, count em, three of their basil lemongrass gimlets for $9 a piece and guess what- they were made with Hendricks! They were so tasty I wanted mooore! (I was celebrating my last day at work) I didn't even have to ask for non-well gin, it's the standard there! Point being... I didn't even want a second drink at Rye, it left such a distaste, both physically and figuratively.
Also, you like all those nice fresh fruits and accoutrements that end up in your pretty cocktail? After sitting at the bar and watching money, credit cards, clipboards, dirty bar patrons cigarette- holding hands and the like be passed over, dropped into or set on top of these little edibles that end up in YOUR mouth, eh no thank you. I prefer my cucumbers without whiskey spilled in them. 
I will probably be back to try some more of their concoctions, but this time I will ensure I know what liquor is going into my glass, and pass on the fruit salad.
author: Claudia F.

description: It's a place where you can play pool and actually talk to someone.  The space is airy and modern.  Probably one of the best places I've been in the city thus far with unique yummy drinks.  I was so impressed by this newest discovery on Geary.  Worth the trip over and especially if you want to catch up with someone.
author: Jessica G.

description:
F'n amazing Basil Gimlet!

Actually everything anyone ordered got passed around for others to taste.
author: kristin n.

description:
I'm torn. It wasn't a great experience this past Friday. A group of us went to do a little pre-partying and went in with the mindset that it's a poor-man's B&B (it is). For all of B&B's shortcomings there's no doubt their cocktails rock. Rye's drinks pretty much blew across the board. We had standards (Rum n coke, G n T) and they were flat. We had a few drinks off the specialty menu, all were underwhelming.

The crowd was eh (but like a lot of folks say, many nights lead to many vibes, can't really judge the atmosphere from a single trip)

The reason I'm conflicted is because I love having half-way stylish bars coming into (nearly) my hood. Anyone who wants to bring something more than a total dive into the TL is all right by my book. So I'll fork over some cash a few more nights. Also, the one real thing it has going for it is the design. Nice decor, great layout for a small space. If they can fix their drinks this place might be a keeper.
author: James F.

description:
Alas, I fear the b&t and tourist crowd will overrun this chill little spot. But until then I can enjoy stepping into what I think is going to be a dive then surprise! Its a little dark and mysterious and the wine wall exudes a certain sex appeal. And the bartenders are awesome.
I said awesome.
author: Jeremi M.

description:
I want to have the basil gimlet and flash throughout the day.  I'm not an alkie, it's just that good.  They're all that good.  I've had all the specials on the menu - they're something for everyone.  I like some more than others  - but they're all lovable.  If you find the perfect mixed drink, it's like finding your soul mate.  You might find yours at Rye.   

I visit Rye when I can.  The drinks are surprisingly consistent even with the different bartenders.

The waitress Erica is the shizzles.  I want her to be my cocktail waitress everywhere I drink.
author: Lily H.

description:
It is a decent bar. 

Why 4 stars?  

It can get pretty crowded after 10 pm. 
The words "rye" are really small, if you walk by the bar you would most likely miss it.
The bartender/waitress was pretty demanding (but it is understandable 'cuz there was lots of ppl).
* I like the decoration of the bar
* Section for smoking
* Lots of Beautiful people
* Loud music, could be relaxing, lots of fun.
author: Bai Z.

description:
I had a great time here during happy hour last Friday.  The bartenders know what they're doing and are honestly excited about making different and cool drinks.  I had quite a few different concoctions which the bartender just made up off the top of his head (before it got busy).  

The space is pretty cool and I like the outside patio.  Downside is the drinks are pretty expensive.  Almost any mixed drink is going to be $10 or $8 during happy hour (which goes until 7:30pm).
author: Amy W.

description: Went bar hopping the other night and wandered ino Rye to try out their Basil Gimlet everyone raved about. Honestly it tasted like a cold bowl of pho... and I like pho so I'm a fan. Bartenders are a little slow but you really do see a difference in quality of drink so it all evens out. Entranceway & bar can be super packed but the side room was more spacious. Didn't even notice a pool table past the bar until after an hour. Hit this place up while hopping around to local bars down Geary.
author: Gil A.

description: Style and class.  Our waitress and bartender were great.  The drinks and atmosphere were exceptional.  Good place to grab a drink and chat.
author: Justin B.

description:
Good chill spot.
Loved the vibe.

Cool bartenders who definitely knew what they were doing.

Drink to get here: I've heard the basil gimlet is good, haha.

Probably one of the spots I have got to hit up more often.

Good times.
author: Jimmy N.

description: Mad props to all those who raved about the Flash, it was muy delicioso! Coming from someone who rarely frequents the alcohol, the drink was really delicious and great way to unwind. It was very calm and chill, bartendress was super sweet, but music was a bit louder than I expected. Would definitely come back here for the start of a night out.
author: Christine Y.

description:
chill, chill, chill!!! 

had such a fun weds eve drinking micheladas here. 

good scene...friendly staff. appreciate that it's a block or two away from the hotels, meaning you're not interacting with DBs the whole eve. locals exist, too.
author: Elle N M.

description:
i pop in about once a month, Rye is always a crowd pleaser (unless the crowd you're traveling with doesn't like whiskey??) Love the ever changing drink menu and the random celebrity sighting (Real World Alumni frequent Rye on any given night!) 

Love the new mini drink glasses-very 1970's chic!
High Five!
author: Sue K.

description:
Pretty cool crowd.  My fave bartender is the blonde chick--i forget her name, but she is really spunky and everyone knows her.  You'll know who I'm talking about when you see her.  

Rye is famous for the basil gimlet, which is good if you like those limey type of drinks...however, I strongly suggest you try the strawberry gimlet--a drank they be keepin on the DL, but it is helllla gooood!!  =p  

And then they have the smoker's cage outside..you can usually tell if it's crackin by peepin the cage from outside..The back lounge with tables displays a projector on the wall and they play hecka old school 80's-early 90's videos like..Neneh Cherry..member her?  Lol

Cool place to hang, I'm usually sitting up at the bar.  And if you're hungry Osha Thai is just across the way..and you can always check out Vintage415's Ambassador directly across the street..

It's a win-win situation..
author: C Q.

description:
I'm going to get my complaints about Rye out of the way first:

1. The waitress should stop taking shots at the bar and actually do her job. When she finally came by to take our order (2 basil gimlets and a Stella), she went back to the bar only to never return with our drinks. She brought drinks to all of the other tables. We just went to the bar after that.

2. I could not for the life of me figure out how to turn on the sink in the bathroom and neither could any of my friends. I ended up using someone's Purell. Gross. 

However Rye still gets 4 stars for everything it does right. The basil gimlet was one of the best drinks I've ever had. Not too sweet, not too strong, just right. It was like a mojito with basil instead of mint. My friend's kumquat drink was equally delicious.

I also really liked the energy in the bar. I prefer places where there actually are places to sit and that don't pack people in like sardines. There were plenty of people there, but not so crowded that we couldn't move. The music was also great, and pretty eclectic. They played some typical bar music, but a lot of 80s and indie bands as well. Bonus points for any DJ that plays the New Pornographers.
author: Jessica B.

description:
I love whiskey (whisky if yer Scottish), bourbon, scotch and pretty much any variety of fermented grain mash alcohol, so one would think this place might have been a shoe-in for me. However, I generally take my Laphroaig straight from the bottle, alone in my room with the shades drawn and plenty of porn to keep me busy till my girlfriend returns from whereversheis - but I digress... 

The truth is, had I not been invited with a group of friends I would have passed Rye up based on my perception of the uppity, trendoid crowd I normally try to avoid. That said, we arrived before the "scene" poured in and found the bar staff to be delightfully pleasant, easy on the eyes, and the drink mixes worthy of the rye they're mixed with.

In the end, I didn't love the yipsters that flooded the place, but no doubt I will go back. 

Advice: If the "Seen Scene" is not your thing, go early with a shitload of your weirdo friends and treat yourselves to a truly fine cocktail... or four.
author: Prattle P.

description:
pretty decent cocktails.  I tried the blood and sand then a st. germain/white wine/soda, and my friend had a cucumber-y thing and the basil gimlet.  All were very good and in the $8-10 range.

I had a feeling the bartender didn't like me so much and kept ingoring me, but my very pretty (girl) friend always caught his attention to order right away ... hmmm, it seems i have discovered one of the few downsides (to the ego, but who cares about that?) to having friends who are much more attractive I am.

It's a little bit of a meet-market (i could do without the awkward and forced conversation from strange men), but the decor is very nice and I'm a sucker for all that dark wood.

There's also a smokers cage out front for those so inclined.
author: Shailaja B.

description:
I love this place, even though at times it is hard to get the attention of the bartenders because they are so busy. But what bar is not that way.

I have been comin here for a year and a half, and have never reviewed it. Not sure why.

The drinks are great, the atmosphere is nice and dimely lite, and it is a great place to meet people.

This is a must if you like uppity bars, but not Marina bars.
author: Adam B.

description: Rye has fabulous drinks and its a great week day bar.  I think that it is fun here but on the weekends I'd lay low to avoid the B&T crowd and club overflow.
author: Sarah C.

description:
August 6, 2010.  We've been cocktail hunting for a while now: we've done Bourbon and Branch, Richouse, Absinthe, swig etc. but I think this is, so far, our favorite.  We felt right at home the minute we walked in: no reservations, no secret code, no bouncer, no crowds of yuppies drinking beer and being hip, just casual people from the neighborhood (maybe?) having a good time (and smoking a bit of pot . . .).  Rye is a nice size with two rooms, the front bar room and a back room with several sofa like seating areas and tables and an outdoor patio which is kind of sort of indoors.  The bartenders know their drinks but they are not pretentious at all.  We tried four cocktails that evening: the special which had creme de violette, mint and gin (I think), the dogpatch, a rye drink with averna, prat rouge and bitters; Birds of a feather, a bourbon/tequila mix with antica and maraschino; and Joie de Loire with Cachaca, orange liqeur and absinthe. All four were well-balanced, flavorful and we'd have them again.
 It was a Friday night and apparantly there is a happy hour until 7:30 with $8 drinks. Right before we were ready to leave, table service started. The waitress was delightful. She seemed to really like working at the bar and was very friendly and talkative. We wanted to stay just to enjoy her prescence.  She explained that in the future we could bring our dinner in if we wanted to. And that's what we plan to do next.
A word on the atmosphere. It's not a super busy place (or at least not between 6-8 on a Friday), but it's steady and the crowd is an eclectic mix of people in jeans and sweaters and even some sweat pants and another guy in a suit.  It's very casual and welcoming.  We'll be back.
author: Vivek V.

description: Not a bad spot. Pretty expensive. Bartenders are alright, not particularly friendly though. I might have been drunk, but do I remember paying 4.00 for a can of Tecate? I had a Jameson shot for 7 I know that much. Oh, from the outside it looks like a holding cell.
author: Jay C.

description: Excellent cocktails. Basil Gimlet and The Flash are my favorites!! Hip and modern vibe. Relaxed crowd. Pool table near the bar.
author: Lauren H.

description:
Cools space, creative drinks, sexy crowd.

Good stuff!
author: Tony A.

description:
One of my favorite bars in the city since it opened. Now, it gets a little too crowded on weekends with lines out the door. I'm not much into standing in lines! 

I heart their basil gimlets...too much!
author: Allison H.

description:
Sometimes I have mixed feelings about this place. But more often than not, they are pretty good feelings...

It's a nice and tiny spot. They make great drinks, the bartenders are some of the friendliest I've encountered and the crowd is usually cool. The place gets excessively packed though (especially on Friday nights... happy hour crowd merges with the people coming out for drinks later at night) and it can take quite a long time to get a drink.

Boo to those people that decide to order mojitos at that time!

Anyway, I've always had a fun time myself and met some pretty cool people there.  They even have a pool table in back.
author: Dave S.

description:
I went to this bar.

It's a nice space.

The drinks are good.

That is all.

(Oh what, you were hoping for 500 words, you want to know what kind of toilet paper they have, does the bartender have a zit on his ass, did I see Sean Penn there ? It's a fucking bar OK, a little more, nothing less, when you've been in a thousand of them it doesn't matter anymore, you don't need paragraphs and if you do here's a hint for you: Spend less of your time on "groovy lifestyle websites" and more time in bars and after awhile you won't give a shit anymore either.)
author: red c.

description: Great Basil Gimlet, and lots of sitting areas.
author: Maryellen P.

description:
Not really my scene but went there anyway to celebrate a friends birthday.

Was expecting some great drinks seeing that the place is called Rye(and I happen to love corn whiskey).  But they never delivered, I think that I have been spoiled by Alembic, and Bourbon and Branch's superior libations.  

Liked the decor, but didn't like the fact that the restroom only had one stall(and the toilet didn't flush=smelled like a hobo's den)

I would be willing to give Rye a second chance on a weeknight when it was slower, and maybe a chance at a better drink.
author: frizzle-fry e.

description:
I had friends in town for the weekend and we decided to walk down Geary looking for a bar. After peaking inside several places that didn't look so good, we came upon Rye. We almost completely missed it and wouldn't have even thought it was a bar, if not for the guy outside checking IDs.

We walked in and I immediately liked the vibe. Good crowd, good music, laid back atmosphere, not too busy. Two of us had whatever special drink that was on the board.. I want to say it was called a Statesman. I seem to recall it containing Wild Turkey, but I can't remember what the hell else was in it, only that it was absolutely delicious. My friend's girlfriend had a rum & coke and was surprised at how strong it was (that's not a bad thing).

I'm not in the city much in the evening, especially for bar hopping, but this place is definitely worth another trip.
author: Michael M.

description: Personally not a big fan of bars and this place was definitely more bar scene than lounge scene.  It is quite small I must say, but the drinks are pretty darn cheap.  I suppose it's a good place to preparty and then slip over to Slide down a few blocks or or something.  Drinks are also very strong here so you get your bang for the buck.  But still, very small venue.  Oh, bouncers are pretty nice too.
author: Randy Y.

description:
This is truly a great place. Have not been to too many spots in The City (I'm living in Chicago), but this was the most Chi-like of the places I have been. Came here with college friends that I randomly came across in the Elephant & Castle/Club Quarters bar.

The cocktail menu looked great, the crowd was good (not so hip that it hurt) if not that diverse, and the price on the canned Tecate was phenomenal. Perfect for the low-budget evening we were having, seeing as it was the end of the month, and just after Christmas shopping. Great design in this place and excellent barkeeps. The loungy area is separated from the bar area... another nice touch.

Highly recommended.
author: Clay J.

description: I've always really liked the layout of this bar, and the bartenders are decent. There's an outdoor kind of "caged-in" area, which has tables where you can sit with your drink and enjoy the fresh air or smoke. There's a pool table in the back, and it's free! My only gripe is that their happy hour is kind of puny and it's a bit over priced. Overall, it's great for a kind of special evening out.
author: Anne A.

description: Drinks are an art form at Rye. Each drink made with precision. Attention to detail from the freshly squeezed ingredients to the finessing of the glass rim with a burnt orange peel. Experience the best of the Tendernob. It's the creme de la creme of drink lists.
author: Alex H.

description: My favorite bar in SF so far.  The place has style and its cocktails are excellently crafted (perhaps too much so?) .  If there comes a point in one's chronological and economic life at which the quality of what you drink and the ambience that you enjoy it in needs to progress beyond functional, Rye is absolutely a place to spend that time.  Unfortunately, the bar is aggravatingly inaccessible on Friday and Saturday nights, but now that I know to submit myself to this place only on weeknights, it has earned a place in my heart (and liver).
author: Dareyn S.

description: Yummmmmmmm jalapeno tequila delicious cocktail. You cured me of my sinus infection, I swear. Must...find...recipe...
author: Vandana M.

description:
Rye is alright. I think I'm getting to the point that it takes a lot to get me excited about a bar/club. We ended up here friday night after a badparty and we were meant to be there. 
parking spot -check! (just around the corner)
two empty stools at the bar -check!!
awesome drinks -check! (try the basil martini)

Then the drunk loudies were making it pretty challenging to even imagine hearing each other (just a foot from each other) hear ourselves. but we ended up meeting some random people next to us (not the loudies) who turned out to be really cool and seemed like we've been friends for years.

the smoking area is a little weird -like a cage, but for those who need their fix, I suppose it's a draw.

go here if you're in the neighborhood, and you may meet someone interesting -or not :-)
author: Howard C.

description: Cute little place across the way from my apartment.  Pretty good drinks, and PET friendly.  Yes, you can bring your cute little companion with you to the bar.  YAY!  I usually come here to chill, have a few drinks, and then go home.  The service is great and they're always making sure that if your glass is empty, to offer you some more.  Great neighborhood bar that's not pretentious, but not ghetto.
author: Jin B.

description:
Stopped off at Rye around 10:30 on a Saturday night and had a great time. The waitress was very friendly and was very attentive. It wasn't very crowded and we were able to get a few tables all together. The music was a bit loud. Conversations were possible but you had to shout a bit, as my strained voice the next day made evident.

The drink menu had a nice selection and were very good. Fantastic Blood and Sand!

I'll definitely be back.
author: Kirk T.

description: Again, the bar is pretty, it was incredibly hot and stuffy and the bartender was awful.  She didn't know how to make a lot of requested drinks, used Smirnoff whenever a friend asked for anything with Absolut and was generally unpleasant all around.  Lame.  I won't be back.
author: Seong P.

description:
I've been to rye three times, and I've decided it deserves two kinds of ratings: averages don't apply here.  

First review: the Douchebags of Rye.  the first time i came to rye, the dominant sentiment was that i couldn't get to the bar because it was surrounded in a mucus of doucebags and the girls that love them.  This Place Can Be Douchey.  and the bros asking super-qualified bartenders for lemondrops and jagerbombs are wasting their time and money. (seriously guys, if you're going to order drinks named after sex acts and invented by college students, go to The Bus Stop).  i'm a pretty big fan that a place with such great cocktails will also throw some gangster rap my way (not found at say, bourbon and branch or beretta), but sometimes it prevents conversation.  my sympathy for the bartenders, but maybe if they turned the music down and refused to make lemondrops, the crowed would chill out.  but this rye deserves no more than two stars.  there is a special circle in hell for people who waste good liquor, and this place is an abomination. 

but then i went to rye last night, the rainy sunday night before MLK's day.  the place was perfect.  the bartenders know what the hell they are doing and are really happy to talk about their cocktails and the creative stuff they want to do.  the cocktails here are every bit as good as beretta and more creative than bourbon and branch. some of the best drinks in a city of good drinks.  
and the crowd was great.  it's a lounge and people were acting like it was a lounge, and by that i do not mean they were wearing sunglasses and taking bottle service.  it's what is should be: a place where people talk to other people.  
one bartender, whose name i forget, joined me in spraying soda water across the bar, made a damn good seasonal blood-orange whisky sour etc.  they are infusing whiskeys and getting really creative with seasonal fruits and infusions.  this place is awesome.  i didn't tip the bartender enough, as i left in something of a hurry, but i really want to come back to this bar... not the doucemonkey lounge.  five stars for this one.

and as i believe we should evaluate these places at their best, and because the average doesn't mean anything, i'm going with the five.
author: Walter L.

description: Rye is A-OK! Good drink, but a little drab, hipster, and unexciting.
author: Luke M.

description:
the scene of the crime last night for a yelp sunday bar crawl.... and boy did we crawl! this bar exudes sexiness.... brick walls, cement floors, amber colored hue, sleek design and candles everywhere. i really enjoyed drinking here. it was freezing last night so no one was hanging out in that monkey cage thing but i can see it getting really packed when the weather warms a bit. there were so many cool yelpers that showed for the party, the poor bartender had no idea it would be that busy on a sunday night. after rye we trekked over to red room, then balboa, then i think maybe the matrix (but i was really drunk at this point) and lastly comet club for some drunk dancing. i'm hurting today but looking forward to the next one.... thanks yelpers, you were all a blast.

so here is the breakdown: 

as Avery G mentioned-- Rye is a fabulous bar for yuppie-trash-screeching-bleach-blondes such as myself (although i never screech and using the word 'yuppie' is sooooo 1989!) haha  : )
author: Michelle I.

description: Great lounge style bar. Came here with a friend a couple weeks ago and it was fantastic. The bartender really knew his stuff, allowed us to sample a few things and decide what we wanted to order. Extremely professional, very nice, great service, and the atmosphere was amazing. A wonderful place to bring a few friends if you want to have a few drinks and be able to talk. I don't think I can ever again set foot in San Francisco without visiting this place.
author: Brandon C.

description: Are you in search of a great cocktail made with quality ingredients by bartenders that take their craft seriously?  Head on over to Rye, stat. I went for the first time last Friday night (I know, shame on me for taking so long) and was impressed at how the bartenders kept the drinks flowing despite the crowded nature of the bar. I'm looking forward to coming back on a weeknight, pulling up a barstool and working my way through their fantastic drink menu.
author: phil h.

description:
I can't write anything about Rye that hasn't been said a 300 times already, so I'll just tell you a story. Pass over me if you require a useful review: 
This was the last stop on my impromptu Nob Hill Bar Crawl. 6 other spots already conquered. I was a mother fucking Genghis Khan of pretentious drinking establishments. Rawr. Entering Rye with a defiant (and very inebriated stare) I'm pleasantly surprised. This place does not completely suck. Then a dark haired man approaches me with a gimlet. The man behind him says "My friend thinks you can use a drink". 
Me: What is this? Cyrano de Bergerac? Can't your friend speak for himself?
Guy: I apologize, this is my friend Erastus, he is from Greece. I am James, his interpreter. 
Oh my fuck, that shit is hot. Drinks basil gimlet handed to me. 
Panties. Drop. 
So while speaking to this James/Erastus hybrid I find out one of them thinks he met me in Greece, went to school at Fordham (me too!), wants to take me out sailing tomorrow (cheesy, but whatever), spent their childhood being raised by nannies (twinsies!), has a name that means "Loving One", is a ordained MINISTER. At that point I can't keep them straight, everything blends into each other like limbs at an orgy. 
Ummm..... somewhere in the night, things started going down.....

And I think I'm married

The funny thing is that I don't know if I'm Mrs. James D_____
Or Mrs. Erastus Snufflafagus

Eh. Worse shit has happened.
author: Mary F.

description:
after attending an art opening at gallery three, my best friend in sf and i walked over to rye to meet up with some other friends who were holding a happy hour here. as soon as i stepped in, the flood gates opened, and i was reminded of why i avoid this place: it brings up bad memories and stirs up strange emotions.

this is the place where my last serious boyfriend and i had some of our best times (when it first opened), and also where i was purposely excluded for a large birthday bash in his honor hosted by our mutual friends after we decided to take a break so he could hook up with other women. being spurned like that while we were still technically "trying to figure things out" really hurt.

this is a bar in the middle of the tenderloin, a block away from where i used to reside, and also the place where most marina chodes choose to hang out on nights they want to feel cool and "slum it". (ambassador is another spot, directly across the street)

they serve incredibly tasty liquor. their selection of scotch and whiskey is better than most hot spots. however, the prices for mixed drinks are insane for a spot in the 'loin.

i think the thing that bothers me most about this place is that it is a constant reminder of how great things COULD have been, but also how, in the end, chance and circumstance can ruin a very good thing.
author: May T.

description:
I been going to Rye since the early '70's.  That's how f'in on it I am, hit a hot spot more than 30 years before all other Yelpers.

Um.  Right.  Rye has been open less than a year, Lainie, why you frontin'?  

'cause Rye is where my dad's bar used to be.  Way, way back in the day that space was called The Rebound (has there ever been a better name for a bar?) and my daddy ruled the roost there.  He was the man.  Mostly I just remember the long bar and my dad setting it up with me stowed behind the bar after being told emphatically to stay out of sight. . .I sat there for hours ganking marachino cherries out of the jar that was big enough to stick my whole head into (I know this 'cause I tried this).  Sometimes, after the beat cop had his daily shot and left, my dad would let me run around the bar and play pool or give me money for the juke box.  At home he was daddy or Bill or honey but here he was Willie and everyone knew him and everyone loved him.  My dad had a soft spot for folks that were down and out and there would be a line at the door at 6am when he came to open up because these guys knew dad was a softy and he'd hook them up with a shot on the house to steady their hands and nerves.   When my dad died, it was SRO and a lot of people there were the same ones I saw in front of The Rebound when we would drop him off in the morning.  I was young when my dad passed away and a lot of my memories are of him in that bar.   

So cut to present day.  I had seen the spectacle that was Rye and had no interest in joining the fray - not my scene but I wanted to check out the place so I went at an off hour when I knew it would be empty.  Wow.  Total deja vu. .. it's completely different but somehow the same.  I sat at the bar and ordered a Jack Daniels, neat, raised the glass, toasted my pop and took the shot.  A wee tear escaped my eye so I threw a twenty down and walked out into the sunshine of Geary Street.  My eyes took a while to adjust to the sudden light, just like it did when I was a little girl.
author: Lainie L.

description: I love going to Rosewood in North Beach, so I was really looking forward to going to Rye. Like Rosewood, the interior is modern and cozy and the crowd is unpretentious. It's a great spot to have a party because it's small enough to keep it intimate. I was here for a friend's birthday, so I'm not sure if it normally gets crowded, but I'd imagine if it was like Rosewood, it would be pretty chill spot to lounge.
author: Connie C.

description:
happy hour with the cast of yelp the musical? sign me up.

all the fruity drinks here are made with actual fresh fruit. thats their thing. it's pretty cheap and fast and stiff. ambiance is sorta like what i see in downtown la, industrial concrete. 

i also learned the nish dance which looks like the twist, but has more vogue-ish facials to it. they got signature drinks so check it out and do the nish while you are there!
author: Sam Y.

description: Love this place. the atmosphere. the conversation I was easily able to enjoy...even on a Friday night I could still hear my friends. Loved the basil gimlet, best drink I have had in a while. I will definitely return!
author: Sonya D.

description: Saturday night, crowded as hell, smoking cage, bathroom that looks like an airplane lavatory, a guy from Yonkers who wanted to look at my feet, a drunk TV producer who kept proclaiming that "I'm awesome", I can honestly say that I had a good time. I did notice another guy who I was certain was my old coworker at (insert some retail store in Union Square) from 6 years ago but I didn't go up to him because I wasn't sure it was him either because I didn't know he was the type to wear trendy screen t-shirts and true religions but then again, a lot can change in 6 years. Then again, he was smoking a cigarette and if it were actually him, I should feel bad because when we worked together he was a non-smoker (and I wasn't) and I playfully pressured him into having a smoke with me after work and soon after, he started smoking regularly after that. Woops!
author: kristin e.

description: Great drinks and a cozy little place for heading to after work or on the weekend evenings. The drink they made me didn't have a name and so I can't tell you what to get. Just ask the bartender for a good drink and tell them what you like/don't like.
author: J S.

description:
make sure you go here prior to 8pm. before dudes from walnut creek flock in and begin their lady feast! before this time you can actually sit at the bar and watch the skilled bartenders create amazing drinks with inventive flavor combos without being preyed upon. that's the only reason i'm docking a star. the space is great - industrialish but comfortable and the bartenders are all legit without snobbery. i know it's not their fault that the clientele isn't my scene, so i'll keep coming but always before the rush.

i've become a cocktail snob recently and rye is on the ball. the basil gimlet, dark & stormy (made with bundaberg ginger beer...the best!) and their nightly special drinks on the board are all perfect. modifying the gimlet by adding elderflower syrup (or maybe it's st. germain?) is a nice trick that's not on the menu, and the elderflower drinks that are on the menu are suuuper good. mmmmm boooooozzzzzze!
author: Elle C.

description:
I have NO idea why this place is as popular as it is.  Popped in for a quick drink sat night since I had heard good things and was in the neighborhood, and man did I ever regret that decision.  The place is PACKED with amateur drinkers, marina chodes, popped collars, and striped shirts.  People that try to push in front of other people to get a drink, wave their money around, and so on.  To top it off, I ordered my usual, a Don Julio Anejo neat, and was charged $12 for what I'm pretty sure was a light pour.  The Page charges $8 for the same thing, so as far as I can gather, you're paying that extra $4 to hang out with a bunch of drunken marina idiots who flock to this place to say they're slumming in the tenderloin.  I guess I should be thankful that Rye exists however, since it's keeping the people that hang out here out of the good bars in town.  Think of Rye as a roach motel for Marina chodes.
************************
EDIT: The owner of the bar has since contacted me about my review and has requested I give them a second chance during the week.  This kind of follow up is appreciated and since more than a few bars in this town can be different on the weekend, I'll give them a second chance and report back.  +1 star for a business owner that actually cares.
************************
UPDATE: So I went back a couple of nights ago to give them another chance.  See original review.
author: Joshua W.

description: Friday night around 10 pm, I show up with a group of friends to kick off my birthday celebrations after dinner. Upon entering, the bar is rigt in front - whiich makes it a little awkward to move around when there are a lot of people. First drinks I had a glass of champagne which was nice and bubbly and then I tried one of their spcialty drinks, the vodka basil gimlet. A delish drink choice, it was sour and flavorful and I kept going back for more! My issues with my experience here were bad bartending service - it took FOREVER to get a drink. Second, the music isn't quite loud enough. I've never been for happy hour but it might be worth checking out at a less hectic time.
author: Lindsay A.

description: I was highly anticipating a night of dancing and drinking but didn't end up getting my groove on since the slide nor ambassador didn't work out.  Across the street we noticed a bar/lounge called Rye.  I would totally come back here again.  Very cool vibe and very chill.  Only 2-3 bartenders at the max behind the bar so it kind of was a wait but not too bad.  Drinks were generous on the alcohol side.  Some of the glasses they used though were a little odd and not consistent. The decor was urban modern yet streamlined.  There's a pool table at the back and a bunch of lounge chairs on the other side of the room.  The place is a little small.  The huge mirror facing the bar can be a bit deceiving but it made the illusion that the place was bigger.  Basically a really nice spot to grab a drink before or after dinner.
author: Ro C.

description:
This bar makes wondrous fruit inspired drinks to make this dude feel all squishy inside!
The smokers cage makes me laugh and makes me cry.
author: Daisy S.

description:
Awesome interior, decent staff, shitty customers.

well, most of the time.

Went here when i was visiting SF before actually moving here and it was great...chill people at the bar, liquor being poured left and right and some girl dragged me in to the bathroom.

next time i went back it's a bunch of douchebags in stripped shirts and ho'd out women. 

third time probably won't be happening, but then again, i've said it before.

but the staff definately rocks, very cool, very knowledgeable and very generous with the alcohol.
author: John G.

description:
What the world needs now is another Rye review, of this I am certain. ;-)

Went here with Jessica P. for the Damrak Gin Mixology event where Nish was judging (seriously, I might add, at his table in the corner) and what a wonderful space.  Gorgeous bar, bi-level and with an "outdoor" space that is out front but separated by a bars from the public, kind of like an advertisement for the good times within.  Easy bar to get around in, even when crowded.  Someone did their homework when setting up this space.

On to the drinks - I knew it was gin drinks for the evening, but had no idea they would be FREE during the event - hot damn!  Me and Snoop sippin' on gin and juice, laaaid back!  Or, as Mojo Nixon would have put it, we were in a gin guzzlin' frenzy.  I ended up having a gin and tonic to really get a taste for Damrak before I moved on to more complicated drinks, and it's very good, very smooth gin.  Jessica had the gin martini, which was good, but I wasn't in a martini mode at that point.  Then I went for a gin and sin, but the wait at the bar was so long (very busy at that point) that I settled for another cucumber gimlet that she was making and Jess had the basil gimlet.  Both were outstanding.  Then we more or less gave up on getting to the bar until I started up a conversation Carol Ann, a promoter making her way around the place, when she mentioned Yelp and Nish.  She was smart, fun, and we had a great discussion about Yelp and the effects of its' reviews which were pretty positive.  Anyway, long story short, that sweet lady got us gin-gin mules like, pronto.  What a sweetheart, and what a tasty drink!  5 stars for the event, Damrak, Nish for inviting us, and Carol Ann!!

Last note: the female bartender (didn't get her name, no time) there is top notch and deserves whatever tips you can manage.  She's quick with her drinks, high energy, meticulous with her mixing, cute as all get out, and totally sweet.  Great energy behind the bar here.
author: Joe B.

description: It's easy to walk by the entrance of Rye, but keeping your eyes peeled is well worth it!  The bartenders are lovely to look at as they crush up fresh fruit and goodies for your handcrafted cocktail. At 7x7's mandate, I had the basil gimlet, and it was among the best crisp summery cocktails I've ever had. Looking at the cute hipster wannabe crowd, I don't think I could make an evening out of it, but I'll definitely pop in on my way to a night out again!
author: Kelly C.

description: Lots of good times here.  Drinks are unique and tasty-- been here with a friend, a date, and a bday party, and all were great fun!  I'm going to credit the drinks and the ambiance.
author: Kari L.

description: Yes it's true: their gimlets are, in fact, amazing. But what really sets Rye apart for me is the crowd which is always successfully diverse. Few other places can you find the city's Hipsters and Day Traders drinking together in blissful harmony. The decor, the size of the venue, the attentive bartenders, the location and the music (I gotta credit the music for alot of this btw) all create the right environment to appeal to a very mixed crowd. It's hip but comfy but sleek, but gritty, all at the sametime.
author: Robert M.

description: Oh man.  Disappointing experience here.  We went for a friend's birthday and I have to say, I was pretty pumped to check this spot out.  The first problem was the line outside....like going to a club, line line.  Awww hell no!!!  So we finally moved to the front because I guess we had to say we were there for so and so's birthday and he let us in, but not the guy that was with us.  Lame.  So then next problem.  Getting a drink.  The dude bartender was a complete douchebag while the chick was cool.  I guess they were short staffed but umm not my problem.  Figure something out.  So after a while we got fed up and left.  I don't know that I would be back.  Too bad because the space is cool too.
author: Kirsten M.

description: This place is cool: really good drinks for a fair price, a pool table and some ok art on the walls.  I have only been once and was on a date at the time, so I will have to go back with my crew to see how it fares as a hang out.
author: Sarah T.

description: Liked it... nice vibe, lovely bartender (jennifer), fabulous julep with a bevy of ingredients.
author: Tom M.

description: Part of a long-awaited and much-needed Nob Hill South Slope renaissance, Rye delivers on nearly all counts. Excellent bar staff, good at dealing with a heavy crowd. The room is spacious and intimate at the same time. Contrary to opinions of other reviewers, I don't find this place to be filled with wannabe hipsters, but with actual drinkin' folk - mostly polite and universally good-natured. The outdoor smoking area is a boon to smokers and non-smokers alike - it keeps the smokers off the sidewalks and in the bar-proper. Happy hour means a good game of pool in a place that remains "intimately lit," even as it takes in the last of the southern sun through the steel grating of the smokers' patio. Again - anyone willing to give it a go so close to the Tenderloin is a mensch in my opinion.
author: West R.

description: Best bartenders in the city. Period. Need a drink recommendation? Ask them. Still need a recommendation? Have the Zaya Rum Old Fashioned. God I love this place.
author: Phillip B.

description:
nice atmosphere inside, but grab a sofa if you can because the rest of the chairs/bartstools are not that comfortable. i've only been once, so i can't judge the drinks as a whole, but i can tell you one thing. i have never gotten smaller olives in a martini than the ones i got here. sure they could have compensated for the size with quantity, but no...only two very tiny olives on some kind of cheap wooden thing. that cost them a star right there.

another defining aspect of rye is the smokers cage that opens to the outside world and has glass windows to the rest of the bar. i never realized how much fun it can be to watch people smoke. it really does look cool...or something... enjoy the scenery without having to put up with the smoke. 

it's seems to be an IN place to go right now which i usually try to avoid, but as it's soooo f'n close to my apartment, and i'm sooooo f'n IN right now, you can probably count on seeing me there again...that is...if you knew what i looked like.

UPDATE: heard back from greg l. about the olives: he promises me that it was just a single occurence due to the fact that they are just kinda starting up. so i'm giving them back one star. isn't that nice?
author: eric g.

description: Rye is an awesome space to hang out and have a really delicious cocktail or a nice dark drink. It's a great place to go to if Bourbon and Branch is too full to breath since it's down the street. I like the open space they have but wished they had a few more seats available. My persimmon sour was so good. I would have never imagined persimmon could be in a whiskey cocktail but, wow! Cocktails are $11, Beers $5 or $6.
author: Laura C.

description: Apparently this place is supposed to be known for the fresh produce they use in their drinks.. hence the partially chopped cucumber I saw on the bar... Honestly, this place is way too small and pretentious.  There were two bartenders when there should have been two or three and besides my friend getting a drink spilled on him we were only able to get one drink =shots to be exact.  After that we weren't looked at again.  Not my favorite place that is for sure.  Then again.. maybe at happy hour it would be more fun because you would actually be able to talk to the bartenders about the snazzy produce drinks.. let me know if you try them...
author: Kylie L.

description: This place is not my typical scene but it was really cool. When your in the mood to get dressed up, drink some cocktails, and hang with friends this is the place to go. The interior has a very industrial artsy feel to it. The bartenders were wonderful and know how to make a great mojito. It does get a bit crowded around the bar so you have to be a bit pushy to get a drink. Also I thought the crowd was very diverse which is sometimes hard to find.
author: Stacy F.

description: Holden Caulfield would definitely resent every black clad, fake person in this little wood paneled hot spot, but he was just angry youth in a fictional novel, so what does he know.  Besides JD Salinger ran off to the woods, so Rye would not be his bag either.  What I'm trying to say is, I like the space, I like the bar, but needs a better mix of characters and a much better sound system/music selection.  Besides that, this place has won me over with each new try, some great drinks and service to boot.
author: JP Z.

description: The only reason I hesistate to give this place 5 stars is because I've yet to come here without SF's favorite local celebrity, none other than "Grandaddy" Nish Nadaraja, and I don't know if I'd be given the same superstar treatment.  But this I will say - I love the decor and the cocktails are really superb.  Fantastic staff and alcohol selection and wonderful, sleek, cool feel.  I love me some exposed brick.  Also, I've yet to come when there's been a crowd that's not a bunch of drunk Yelp Teamers, so I can't really comment on how the usual feel is, but I've yet to have a disappointing drink or time at Rye.  I'm a fan.
author: Sam P.
Josie M.

description: I wish I did not have to give 1 star. Worst bar service ever. 25% full, 2 bartenders and still 25+ min waits without any acknowledgment. Place sucks and needs to go bankrupt.
author: Vladimir V.

description: Rye is a good neighborhood bar with a nice modern look - exposed bricks, metal chairs,  track lights.  Since I went there for happy hour between 6-8 on a Thursday night, it was kind of quiet.  I got a beer so I cannot comment on the bartenders' cocktail knowledge / skills, but they appear what they're doing.  It's a nice, small space, easy to talk (no loud pounding music or anything) and a good location (Nob Hill bordering Tenderloin).  My Stella cost me $4 so it's fairly reasonable.  Parking in that neighborhood is difficult, so expect to park in a garage unless you get lucky.
author: Paul K.

description: What is it about Rye that makes me always want to get totally sloshed? The sleek decor? The fact that Osha is next door? No...it's the dee-licious drinks! Rye creates some of the most inventive, yummy, boozy drinks around, and each one that I have leaves me wanting more...and subsequently gives me a RAGING hangover the next day. Thanks Rye...
author: Brianne K.

description: Caveat Emptor - If you go for the ambiance, prepare for a minimalist, industrial atmosphere with dim lighting. If you're like me, someone who revels in watching someone take pride in their trade and being at the top of their game, you're in for a treat. The bartenders here are nothing short of incredible. The behind-the-bar showmanship and knowledge comes complete with the mesmerizing, deft crafting of ridiculously tasty drinks. I had a Basil Gimlet and a Peat n Ginger - both fantastic. These guys know what they're doing, which makes the price well worth it. I'll be back as long as my wallet can keep up.
author: Giovanni S.

description: I thought I would like this place more. With the same owners as Bourbon & Branch it should have so much potential. Instead it's just an overpriced bar with a poor selection that grabs too much of the tourist crowd to enjoy.  Thurs/Fri/Sat nights it tends to be too packed to get in. There are far better options within a 2-block radius.
author: Michael H.

description: I was totally hammered by the time I got here but I do remember that this bar has a beautiful, minimalist interior. Service was also friendly and quick for a Friday night. Cool place!
author: Donna V.

description: nice decor, nice mixed drinks
author: Michael E.

description: Ok so I walked in here for a split second then I hightailed out of here.  This place has really changed since I have last gone here...I don't even remember what this bar was called before.  The set up was nice but not much people inside to keep me there.  I'll have to try my luck again next time.
author: Allison T.

description: Came here after Swig and my very very simple Grey Tonic tasted minty...at the time I ignored it since I didn't want to be a B****, myself having been exbartender.  I figured, oh well the shaker was rinsed fully.  But then..the sober me today, realized...dude, Grey Tonic is poured from the bottle, so it must have a dirty glass...or that the bartender made my drink wrong...which is crazy cuz it's so easy.  I didnt know about the raves about the fruity drink so next time I'll definitely try them...I did pick at their fruit though (sorry yelpers...my drunk fingers were in the fruit)  Gross...sorry...
author: Jenny K.

description: Rye = Love this bar... bartenders rock, are always friendly and serve great cocktails. Although lately during the weekend it has been getting a bit toooo packed---guess the other half is finding out what a great bar it is. (yea you know who you are... stay on the other side of the city ok? deal? or at the very least go across the street to the Ambassador)
author: Rachael Z.

description:
